PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I inform honourable senators that the Senate (Quorum) Bill 1991 received royal assent on 27 September 1991, reducing the quorum of the Senate from 26 senators to 19 senators.
—-Mr President, I wish to inform you and the Senate that, following a ballot of the Australian Democrat members, I have been elected the Leader of the Australian Democrats.
—-How many votes did you get?
—-A clear majority. Senator Meg Lees has been elected to the position of Deputy Leader and Senator Vicki Bourne has been elected to the position of Party Whip.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to calls by the Premier of Victoria, Joan Kirner, last Wednesday in the Victorian State Parliament for a national jobs policy and her comments that:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . any government in Australia, ours included, that does not address a national jobs policy that includes consultation with industry, unions and the States, is not facing up to the issue--

that is, the issue of unemployment. Does the Minister agree with Mrs Kirner that the Federal Government currently does not have a national jobs policy? If so, what level will unemployment have to reach before the Government decides to adopt one?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I do not think, on a reading of what Mrs Kirner said, that she said that the Federal Government did not have a national jobs policy. Senator Alston's glib footwork has turned what Mrs Kirner said into that particular statement.

ANSWER.PARA: On the question of consultation with industry, unions and various governments, the Government is doing that, as Mrs Kirner well knows. There have been consultations already with the Victorian Government and there will be further consultations on some of the issues which she was talking about. There will also be consultations with the unions and other concerned groups, just as I have had a number of consultations with business about these issues in the last week or two.

TALK.START.PARA: —-What is she squealing about?

—-If Senator Alston, by way of interjection, wants to know what Mrs Kirner `is squealing about'--as he puts it--I suggest that he get one of his colleagues in the Victorian Parliament to ask her that question.

—-Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Apropos of the consultation with the Victorian Government which the Minister has just referred to, will the Federal Government repudiate recent Prime Ministerial threats of financial retribution to Victoria if David White is not rebuked for the heinous crime of merely introducing a couple of political soul mates?
—-That is not a supplementary question and I decline to answer it.

—-My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the ongoing tragedy of the civil war in Yugoslavia and the consequent destruction and dislocation in that country. Can the Minister advise the Senate what assistance the Australian Government is making available to the victims of the conflict? What is the Government's current assessment of the situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-As all honourable senators will be aware, there is a deeply unhappy situation currently prevailing in Yugoslavia. There have been some indications, just in the past few hours, that the Yugoslav Army will observe the cease-fire agreed on 4 October, conditionally at least, for the next 24 hours. But one has to acknowledge that, on the basis of the history of the dozen or so previous cease-fire agreements, there is no great cause for optimism.

ANSWER.PARA: On behalf of the Australian Government, I want to condemn in the strongest possible terms the air attack on Zagreb which was directed at the official residence of President Tudjman in the past 24 hours. It was only through very good fortune that President Tudjman, Federal President Mesic and also Prime Minister Markovic, I think, with whom he was talking at the time, were spared.

In response to the blockade of army installations by Croatian forces, the Yugoslav National Army has been attacking civilian targets throughout Croatia. That is quite contrary to the precepts of international humanitarian law. Moreover, it is the case that Serbian representatives are attempting to take full control of Federal institutions, such as the presidency and the Parliament, in a manner which does seem to be unconstitutional.

Having said all that about the Serbian side, I also have to make the point that all sides must bear some responsibility for the continuation of the fighting that has occurred. Certainly there have been a number of occasions when the Croatian side has engaged in very provocative actions against the Yugoslav Army and simply not contributed to the maintenance of an agreed cease-fire. All sides have to understand that they cannot impose a military solution to resolve the kind of ethnic conflict that exists in that country, that conquest is simply no substitute for negotiations.

The Australian Government continues to support the efforts of the European Community to bring about not only a cease-fire but also sensible negotiations to produce a lasting solution. We have also very strongly supported the bringing of this matter into the United Nations to get the full weight of that body behind the peacemaking efforts. We can only hope that something positive will flow from that.

In the past 24 hours, the European Community has threatened to implement certain trade sanctions against Yugoslavia should the parties not prove to respect the most recent cease-fire negotiated by Lord Carrington. I indicate that Australia would certainly wish to support international moves to impose sanctions in these kinds of circumstances.

Having said all that, I can only end with a plea to the leaders on all sides in Yugoslavia to demonstrate a degree of courage and resolve and to find a better way for their people than to plunge them into a civil war that will have catastrophic consequences for them and from which no-one will benefit.

The other part of Senator Loosley's question went to what assistance the Australian Government might be able to offer in terms of humanitarian assistance or aid. As the Senate will be aware, the Government announced in early September the provision of $100,000 to the International Committee of the Red Cross for relief assistance to victims of the Yugoslav crisis. Currently, the ICRC has an on-ground presence in Croatia and Slovenia, as well as in Belgrade, and therefore, in our judgment, continues to be well placed to reach those most in need. However, some further assistance is, in our judgment, required, and I am pleased to announce today that Australia will provide a further $100,000 for emergency relief. This amount will be available to support suitable emergency aid proposals from Australian non-government and community organisations which wish to assist in providing assistance of this kind.

To qualify for assistance, such organisations have to be voluntary, not for profit and identifiably Australian. Decisions on the allocation of the funds by AIDAB will be made on the basis of the capacity of each organisation to deliver needed assistance effectively to those suffering as a result of the conflict. An example might be funds to assist in the transport of needed medical supplies collected by a local community organisation here in Australia. We are aware that various community organisations have indicated a willingness to play a part in the provision of relief assistance. We hope that this latest contribution by the Government will contribute effectively to their efforts.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I want to ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade a question on Yugoslavia arising out of an earlier answer given by him. In particular, there is some ambiguity in relation to a statement that Australia would support trade sanctions. I ask the Minister whether Australia has urged or will urge the UN Security Council to address now the prospect of trade sanctions and, in particular, an oil embargo against Yugoslavia to add to the pressure that the European Community is seeking to impose in that regard, particularly bearing in mind the effectiveness, sadly, of the arms embargo imposed by the Security Council.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The only proposal on the table at the moment is one from the European Community. It may well be that that will be followed very rapidly in order to secure its international effectiveness should that be implemented by an appeal through the UN for a full internationalisation of any embargo or sanctions economically that the Europeans might impose. I simply indicate that, should that happen, Australia will be happy to go along with that. We will give consideration to taking some initiative in this respect.

ANSWER.PARA: Until now we have taken the view, which I know has been shared by the Europeans, that economic sanctions are highly unlikely by themselves to have much more than a marginal impact in an environment where tensions are running as high as they are. Nonetheless, there is an argument, particularly so far as oil is concerned, that that is so obviously needed to fuel the engines of war that perhaps a selective and effective embargo just focusing on various strategic materials of that kind might in fact have some degree of effectiveness.

I do not want to make any commitment about any Australian initiative in this respect; I am simply indicating support for a pattern of response that is evolving in Europe. We will certainly give further consideration to the best way in which we can help.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Arising out of the Minister's answer, I ask him: why will Australia not take the initiative and join with other parties in urging the Security Council to address the matter forthwith, bearing in mind the extent of damage, the escalation of the violence and also the fact that it clearly takes the Security Council some little time to get these matters into an official form?

—-Mr President, we do not need the Opposition to tell us how to go about these things, although it can hardly stop giving its advice on these matters. We did take an initiative to bring the whole question before the Security Council. We were the first country to formally raise the issue with the Secretary-General or anyone else in the UN system. We are very conscious of the utility and the role that the UN is capable of playing here. I simply want to give the matter of the potential utility of this kind of exercise some further thought before committing Australia to taking any initiative in this respect. I am not ruling it out; I am just saying that we want to take further advice on what is happening at the moment, what is likely to happen elsewhere, and what we can usefully add to the process.

—-I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Would the Minister comment on the Australian Government's response to proposals for sweeping cuts in nuclear arms made recently by the governments of both the United States and the Soviet Union?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Australia very warmly welcomes both the initial announcement by President Bush, on 27 September, of major unilateral nuclear disarmament measures so far as the US is concerned, and the highly positive response of President Gorbachev in the past few days. The Prime Minister wrote to President Bush congratulating him on the original initiative and he will now be writing to President Gorbachev expressing Australia's appreciation for that swift and constructive response.

ANSWER.PARA: Rather than burden the Senate with the detail, at the end of this answer I will seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a list of the respective measures that the United States and President Gorbachev have now put on the table. I say, by way of commentary on those measures, that there are very significant convergences between the Bush proposal and the Gorbachev response. It seems that, effectively, President Gorbachev has met all the major unilateral proposals or commitments that the United States made and has indicated a willingness to enter into negotiations on the other matters that President Bush suggested would be appropriate for agreement.

There are some matters on which the Soviet Union in turn seems to have gone a little further. One clear such area is in the Soviet's announcement of an immediate unilateral moratorium on nuclear testing. This kind of response to stopping nuclear testing has been a longstanding Australian disarmament objective. We are yet again negotiating a resolution to this effect with the UN this year. We accordingly call upon the United States and all other nuclear testing states to join the Soviet Union--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Including France?

—-Including France. We call upon those countries to join the Soviet Union in this moratorium. It is very important that all the nuclear states now commit themselves to the urgent negotiation of a comprehensive test ban treaty which would ban all testing, by all states, in all environments, for all time. The one-year moratorium is certainly a good start and we hope that it will be repeated elsewhere.

ANSWER.PARA: There are a number of other things that are currently the subject of analysis, so far as the effect of these respective proposals is concerned. By way of conclusion, I just say that our own assessment as a government, on the material available to us, is that if President Bush's unilateral commitments are fully matched by the Soviet Union and if the matters which have been identified by President Bush as appropriate for negotiation are the subject of agreed negotiated results, we will see the removal from the field of about 20,000 nuclear warheads. On any view that will be a major achievement, indeed, and a huge step forward towards getting some nuclear sanity into this world.

At the same time, as a note of caution I make the further point that that will still leave nearly 30,000 nuclear warheads in existence, including a great many strategic warheads which are matters of huge continuing concern. It is a little early even to say that we are witnessing the beginning of the end of the era of nuclear weapons. Notwithstanding that note of caution, this is obviously far and away the biggest step towards nuclear disarmament and arms control that has been taken since the beginning of the nuclear age. It is a step by both sides that Australia unequivocally welcomes and endorses.
Mr President, I seek leave to have the document incorporated in Hansard.
On 27 September President Bush announced that the United States would unilaterally:
eliminate all nuclear artillery and all short range ballistic missiles and associated warheads
withdraw all tactical nuclear weapons from
all ICBMs scheduled for destruction under START
accelerate the START schedule once ratification takes place
terminate mobile Peacemaker ICBM and the mobile portions of the single warhead ICBM programmes
and cancel the replacement programme for tactical missiles for strategic bombers.
President Bush also proposed that the Soviet Union agree to bilateral negotiations which would be aimed at
permitting the limited deployment of non-nuclear defence against limited ballistic strikes (including co-operation in ballistic missile early warning)
enhancing co-operation on the handling, control security and safety and destruction of nuclear weapons.
Like other governments we are still studying the detail of the President Gorbachev's response. The main elements of that response seem to indicate that President Gorbachev is prepared to:
destroy all land-based tactical nuclear weapons and remove all such weapons from surface ships and submarines
return all mobile strategic missiles to garrison
stand down all Soviet heavy bombers from alert and store their nuclear weapons
cut strategic offensive weapons by 50% more than the START Treaty envisages
begin immediately a one year moratorium on nuclear weapons testing
reduce the Soviet armed forces by 700,000
and co-operate in taking concrete steps to permit the limited deployment of non-nuclear defences against limited nuclear strikes.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Is the Minister aware of a report in today's Australian newspaper that Memtec Ltd has been forced to take its state-of-the-art waste treatment technology offshore to the United States, France and, possibly, Japan because of our lack of high water quality standards and the uninterest of State governments and because water authorities have kept local demand too low? Does the Minister acknowledge that Memtec's move calls into question, firstly, the new federalism which would institutionalise the process of setting mediocre pollution standards; secondly, the multi-function polis, the promise of which has been unable to convince Memtec to stay in Australia; and, thirdly, the development of Australia as a clever country in which the Government hoped Memtec would play a prominent role? Finally, will the Minister push for the Federal Government to take the lead and set high national pollution standards to benefit the Australian environment and ensure that leading edge technologies can be developed here on the strength of domestic demand?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I have not seen the press reports of what Memtec said about this issue, but I have been familiar with its position for some time; it is nothing new to me. To begin with, might I say that the Federal Government, in one way or another, has been very supportive of Memtec's research and development program. The amount of research and development money which has gone to Memtec runs into several millions of dollars. It is through that sort of assistance that Memtec was able to develop the technology which offers the prospect of very high quality waste water treatment for city and country areas.

ANSWER.PARA: In the light of the Sydney sewerage problem, Memtec has received some publicity because its technology offers an alternative to offshore disposal of inadequately treated sewage. I just make the point that Memtec has a subsidiary company in Japan and one in the United Kingdom. There is great advantage in a company such as Memtec, with the sophisticated technology it has, operating close to the market.

As I recall it, Memtec has a business association with a number of water authorities in the United Kingdom. It is probably also fairly successful in respect of its business operations in Japan. It is a substantial company with a lot of interest in its technology coming from various sources.

With regard to whether this announcement by Memtec calls into question the so-called new federalism policy, the answer is no. Memtec was considering some of these issues well before the new federalism policy was formally on the agenda of the Premiers Conference, and I do not think that any judgment by Memtec has been made on that basis. What Senator Coulter has done--which is not unusual--is to read a subjective view into that announcement from Memtec which he believes might suit his political purpose, having in the last week or so identified a possible new role for his Party as distinct from the traditional role which the Australian Democrats have had.

The second point relating to standards which arises from the new federalism point, if I might call it that, is that a number of factors affect the adoption of new technology such as Memtec's in Australia: for example, the extent to which water authorities are required to generate economic returns on their operations; certainly slowness on the part of water authorities in adopting new technology; the difficulties associated with the demonstration phase of new technology from a pilot plant to a full commercial plant, and so on. Memtec has been engaged for some time with a pilot plant at Blackwater and is now in negotiation with the Sydney Water Board on the installation of a commercial scale plant at Cronulla but there have been a lot of delays in negotiating these matters with the Sydney Water Board. My Department has been pursuing the issue with them to see how the tenders can best be handled to support home-grown technology.

In conclusion, it will be a matter of some regret and concern if Memtec does, in fact, carry out the intention which was announced in the press report to which Senator Coulter referred. However, I am sure that Memtec will remain substantially an Australian company. It has been very much supported by the Government in its endeavours and will continue to be so.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Button typically obfuscates and deflects the central point of the question. Let me make it clear to him and ask: is it not a fact that Australia has one of the most expensive water supplies in the industrialised world? Is it not a fact that we have one of the poorest standards in relation to water quality? Consequently, in view of the fact that Memtec finds it economic to invest overseas to improve the quality of water there, where the price of water is much lower than here, would it not be fairly obvious that the application of adequate water quality standards in this country would solidly encourage Memtec to stay here?

—-Mrs Kelly, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, has been very strongly pursuing the question of national water quality standards and will no doubt continue to do so.
—-That is where the new federalism fits in.

—-Any assumptions the honourable senator wants to make by way of interjection about the so-called new federalism are not necessarily valid; they are as hypothetical as any other idea which comes into his head. So far as the question of whether we have a costly water supply system is concerned, I cannot answer that. I will obtain an answer and let Senator Coulter know.

—-My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence. In light of the recent changes announced by the United States and the Soviet Union with regard to deployment of nuclear forces I ask the Minister whether or not there will be any fundamental reassessment of the role of the so-called joint facilities in Australia. I further ask whether there will be any evaluation of the whole rationale for the ANZUS alliance, given that it was signed at the height of the Cold War and as part of the containment of the Soviet Union? Finally, I ask whether the Minister agrees with the assessment that there is now some serious doubt over the relevance of the Anzac frigates as well as the Collins class submarines, and that these programs should be replaced by others geared to combating low level threats to Australia rather than primarily operating with the US Navy anti-submarine forces in the Pacific?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-It is not the Government's policy to comment extensively on the role of the joint facilities or to speculate publicly about their future roles. It is clear, however, that the joint facilities at Nurrungar and Pine Gap will continue to make important contributions to peace and stability through their missile early warning and intelligence functions, including arms control and verification. It is my view that the importance of these contributions, if anything, will increase.

ANSWER.PARA: On the question of the ANZUS alliance, I simply observe that it has proved its durability and relevance over a period of 40 years of changing strategic circumstances. I am confident that it will prove just as durable into the foreseeable future.

Finally, I believe it would be misguided to suggest that the characteristics that we are incorporating in the Anzac frigates and the Collins class submarines were determined by a need, primarily, to operate as US anti-submarine forces in the Pacific--or anywhere else for that matter. As has been made clear on many occasions, the basic requirements of our force structure are determined by priority needs of the self-reliant defence of Australia. To suggest otherwise, one would be guilty of fundamentally misreading the Government's defence policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Why does the Government continually refuse to acknowledge the most important and recently observed function of the so-called joint facilities, which is their war fighting role, Pine Gap and Nurrungar having been very instrumental in the recent debacle in the Gulf war? Why does the Government continue to ignore that role in public? As for the submarines and Anzac frigates, would the Government not find it difficult to renege on existing agreements, irrespective of whether they are relevant or otherwise to the defence of Australia?

—-It has been my privilege to point out to Senator Vallentine on many occasions in such questions that she should refer to the Prime Minister's statement made in the House of Representatives in 1988. I again bring that to her attention. That is as far as this Government will go in public to explore the roles and functions of the joint facilities. As regards the submarines and frigates, they were not determined by Cold War ideology; the decision to proceed with those particular vessels was made on the basis of Australia's proper defence self-reliance.

—-Does the Minister representing the Treasurer support the public call by his colleague the honourable member for Blaxland, Mr Keating, for an immediate further one per cent reduction in interest rates?
—-No.
—-Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. What conditions would have to be met for the Government to lower interest rates?
—-That is not really a supplementary question. As I have said before, the circumstances in which interest rate changes are made are determined by a whole range of factors.
—-Like who is the Prime Minister.

—-Yes, that is certainly a factor. There is a whole range of other factors which ultimately determine whether a change in interest rate, tightening or otherwise, is made. When those factors have been judged appropriate a change will presumably be made.

—-Can the Minister for Industrial Relations inform the Senate of the differences between the Government's policy on workplace bargaining in the wages system and the Opposition's policy on enterprise bargaining?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The difference is between chalk and cheese. We have a balanced and an orderly system of transmitting the centralised wage fixing system to a more decentralised focus, being supervised by the Industrial Relations Commission, and recognising in that process the legitimate role of trade unions. The Opposition has a policy which is best described as the law of the jungle. The Opposition's policy will mean a wages system which is largely unregulated and pays no recognition at all to the interests and rights of the parties. It is a thinly veiled attempt to denigrate trade unions and is a turning away from the cooperative approach of industrial relations that this Government has developed back to the Fraser era of conflict in industrial relations.

ANSWER.PARA: It resembles the New Zealand textbook proposal in which textbook theories are being played out in New Zealand workplaces to the cost of employers and employees and, ultimately, at high cost to the New Zealand economy. It seems that that type of model is being sought to be transported to Australia. Our model involves the Industrial Relations Commission playing a central role in hopefully handing down guidelines that enable the transition to take place, and monitoring those guidelines to see that the outcomes are fair to all parties. It recognises a need to preserve a standard core of conditions relating to hours of work, annual leave, sick leave, long service leave and superannuation.

On the other hand, the Opposition policy talks about voluntary private contracts as if the negotiations between a single employee on the one hand and a large company on the other can in any sense be equal, and as if an employer saying to an employee in such a circumstance, `If you do not agree with what I am putting to you, you are dismissed', can somehow be the basis of a fair contract and cannot be seen as a contract which, in the classic sense, would be harsh and tyrannical.

In an interview reported in the Bulletin, Mr Howard was asked a question similar to that, and he said words to the effect that that would be a problem, that is, a blip in the policy. It seems that the Opposition has no answer to the question of how fairness is to be introduced in a free for all, law of the jungle system. If the New Zealand model is anything to go by, and if the Opposition ever got the chance to introduce such a system, it would wreak on Australia the havoc that has been wreaked on New Zealand. It would be a system that would serve this country very badly indeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I remind him that Mr Keating has indicated that he will not return to Cabinet while Mr Hawke is Prime Minister because he will not serve a person who `cannot keep their word'. Do the Minister and his Cabinet colleagues accept that Mr Hawke is a man of his word and, if not, why do they continue to support him as Prime Minister?

—-The short answer would be something like `Mind your own business', but I would not give such a terse answer to a person of Senator Vanstone's guile and charm. I note the view of the honourable member for Blaxland, which is perhaps based on some personal experience, but I have no comment to make on that. As to whether this Government or members of the Government believe that the Prime Minister keeps his word, the answer is yes.

—-Subject to the usual political qualifications which apply to all political leaders and political parties, namely, that when circumstances change dramatically it is frequently necessary for there to be a policy change.

—-My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is Australia, because of sanctions, missing out on important trade opportunities, including the export of agricultural produce to South Africa, as claimed by the shadow Minister for trade and trade negotiations, Mr Downer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-It has been the case that the shadow Minister, Mr Downer, in a series of press releases in recent months, has been claiming that the Government's sanctions policy is losing Australia valuable trade opportunities, including the opportunity to sell mutton, lamb and wheat to South Africa. He was at it again yesterday in a further press release saying that we had lost something like $55m per annum worth of wheat sales to South Africa since sanctions were introduced in 1986.

ANSWER.PARA: I have to say that, in respect of the export of agricultural produce to South Africa, Mr Downer, as he ought to be by now well aware, is profoundly and comprehensively mistaken. There is no restriction, and there never has been any restriction, imposed by the Australian Government, pursuant to sanctions policy, on the export of any farm products to South Africa. There has been a prohibition on the import of agricultural products. There has been a prohibition on the export of products to governments--

TALK.START.PARA: —-There has been no Australian Government support.

—-I will come to that in a moment. There has been a prohibition on government procurement activity--things of that kind--but there has been no prohibition on the export of agricultural products. In fact, after being approached by South Africa late last year, the Australian Wheat Board sought and obtained from the Australian Government in December last year confirmation that it could tender for the supply of wheat. The AWB was successful, in fact, in two tenders on 29 January and 5 February this year for up to 99,000 tonnes worth some $24m in total. In fact, South Africa is usually a minor exporter of wheat, so it does not in itself offer a significant future market opportunity. It will commence its harvest around October and is not expected to import any more wheat before then.

ANSWER.PARA: The South African market for meat certainly exists, as Mr Downer claims, but it has been virtually blocked by the high import tariffs which were imposed by South Africa on 1 November last year on both frozen beef and mutton.

As to the broader question of Australian and Commonwealth trade sanctions, we have made our position quite clear--I have made it clear again to Mr Botha during his current visit here--that these sanctions, in our view, must remain in place until the South African Government has taken further substantial steps down the reform path. That position was spelt out and agreed to at the last meeting, in recent weeks, of the Commonwealth Committee of Foreign Ministers on Southern Africa in New Delhi, and it will be considered by the Harare meeting of CHOGM next week.

The final point I make is that this is not to say that we cannot do some useful things by way of preparing for a post-apartheid trading environment with South Africa. Indeed, there have been recent expressions of support from the ANC and other black organisations for such preparatory activity taking place. It was with that in mind that we considered sending an Austrade official to South Africa to discuss and explore market conditions there for both trade and investment so that Austrade would be in a better position, upon the removal of sanctions, to effectively advise Australian business as to market opportunities. That visit did not proceed for reasons that were linked with reciprocal conditions that were sought to be imposed.

For the record, I want to indicate now that this has been the subject of further discussion in my conversation with Mr Botha yesterday. I am very confident now that this issue will be able to be quickly resolved and that a reciprocal visit will take place shortly between respective trade officials, again not by way of trade promotion but simply by way of market research type activity, which is an important step in preparing ourselves for what we hope will be a very quick lifting of trade sanctions as soon as there is some major progress on the constitutional front.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister to the advice given to the Government by Professor Ross Garnaut in August to lift sanctions against South Africa in order to boost the South African economy so that it can cope with the transition from apartheid to democracy. I ask the Minister: why, having sent Professor Garnaut to South Africa to look at first hand at the needs of the South African economy, has the Government ignored Professor Garnaut's advice?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-That is not my recollection of the terms of Professor Garnaut's advice. Certainly the point was made in his group's report to the Government that the lifting of sanctions, in particular investment and financial sanctions, was an important precondition to the restoration of growth in the South African economy--a point Mr Botha has made quite vigorously, publicly and privately, since he has been here. We have never been in any doubt about that.

ANSWER.PARA: The question is as to the continuing utility of such sanctions in keeping pressure on the South African Government, in particular to ensure that the process of achieving fundamental constitutional change rapidly comes to fruition. We saw, all too unhappily, the situation in the first half of this year when, flushed with the success of a too rapid easing of sanctions by an important element of the international community, namely, the EC, the South African Government was far from active in its promotion of the reform process during that period.

We believe there is a continuing connection between that external pressure and effective constitutional change. I do not understand Professor Garnaut or anyone else advising the Government to take a fundamentally different view of that. In any event, Professor Garnaut's mandate in his trip to South Africa was not to advise the Government on sanctions policy so much as to advise us on how best we could assist black South Africans, who are going to play an obviously important role in government post-apartheid, in preparing for the responsibilities of economic management that would go with that.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Has the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade seen the criticism by the Save the Children Fund that the Government has done nothing to follow up its endorsement of the World Declaration on the Survival, Protection and Development of Children? What action has the Government taken towards following up its support for the declaration?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Government unequivocally rejects the criticism that has been coming from one or two sources that we have not done anything since I signed on behalf of the Prime Minister the World Declaration on the Survival, Protection and Development of Children in May this year. The current overseas aid budget for 1991-92 includes increases in specific sectors relating to our international obligations under the declaration on children, which were commitments made precisely with those obligations in mind.

ANSWER.PARA: Those increases exceed the overall increase of one per cent that was achieved in the aid program. For example, UNICEF will receive $4.1m in core funding this year, which constitutes a 7.3 per cent real increase over the previous year; other international children and maternal related programs will receive $4.2m, a 2.1 per cent real increase. I remind the Senate of how impossible it would be to meet those kinds of targets in an environment of aid reductions of the kind that the Opposition is now saying very publicly and shamelessly it will engage in.

Other significant aid contributions will be made to maternal and child health projects through a number of bilateral programs. For example, in this year's Budget we will be continuing our contribution to a major maternal and child health project in the Philippines costing $4.9m over four years. Moreover, I am pleased to say--and particularly pleased to say it on the occasion of today, being Universal Child Immunisation Day--that Australia's contributions to UNICEF and to the WHO expanded program on immunisation have been important in helping those organisations achieve the UN goal of universal child immunisation. Later today the UN will announce that it has surpassed its 1990 target of immunising 80 per cent of children against the six preventable diseases: measles, whooping cough, tetanus, poliomyelitis, tuberculosis and diphtheria. Reaching that target is a magnificent achievement, and we certainly congratulate UNICEF, WHO and the developing countries on that success.

I add further that the Australian aid program includes a $20m four-year health initiative, a significant part of which is directed to improving vaccines and their delivery. So in supporting UNICEF and WHO programs, the Government is demonstrating Australia's commitment to the goals expressed in the UN world declaration on children. We are examining further proposals in the fields of immunisation, maternal and child health, education, water and sanitation as options for Australia's plan of action under that UN declaration. Funding for that will be further considered in the 1992-93 Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I ask the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support: how can the Government objectively assess the third runway EIS when one of its own Ministers and a team from Caucus are actively and publicly campaigning against the findings of that report?
—-Easily.
—-Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. How long will this latest outburst of tribal warfare in the Labor Party delay the start of the third runway?
—-Not at all.

—-My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. What effect is the golden nematode having on the Australian horticultural industry, particularly the potato industry? How was the nematode introduced to Australia and how long has it been here? What measures is this Government undertaking to deal with the pest and any problems associated with it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I may have to take the first part of that question on notice because I cannot authoritatively answer fully what impact the potato cyst nematode is having in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: I can say that I know that some questions have been raised about the importation of the disease from New Zealand. I am advised that, since the New Zealand agricultural and fisheries department passed on to industry the responsibility for maintaining area freedom of the disease in various regions of New Zealand, the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service has expressed a lower level of confidence about disease protection and prevention and, therefore, has applied much greater scrutiny to the importation of unwashed and unprocessed potatoes into Australia. As a consequence of that greater scrutiny, now only processed potatoes--that is, washed, peeled and processed potatoes--come from New Zealand. No unwashed potatoes, no ware potatoes, have come from New Zealand since those measures have been taken.

The potato cyst nematode is a disease against which this country is concerned to guard. But I have to take on notice the particular question Senator Bell has asked, if I may, and reply in authoritative detail to him later.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. In view of the extensive and generous funding of the Australian Conservation Foundation by the Federal Government, I have no doubt that the Minister's attention has been drawn to the political article in the latest edition of the ACF's Forest Reporter in which a feature writer states:

QUESTION.PARA: Many people have asked who, from an environmental perspective, would be the better PM, Hawke or Keating? One view is that with Keating we would win and lose more. In other words, Keating's style would be more decisive as opposed to Hawke's tendency to defer making decisions.
The article goes on to say:
Clearly, there is a change in the balance of forces in cabinet. Right faction heavyweight, and Social Security Minister, Graham Richardson, is no longer as influential, having backed Keating.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Ask the question, Senator Tambling.
—-I ask the Minister: does he agree with those quotations?
—-No.

—-My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. I refer to the announcement today by one of Australia's largest stevedoring companies, National Terminals, about the benefits of its new training program. Can the Minister advise the Senate how this announcement relates to National Terminals' involvement in the Government's waterfront reform program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I attended a ceremony this morning at National Terminals' facility at Port Botany where I presented certificates to watersiders who have just completed a training program which was designed to complement the new award restructuring arrangements which will come into effect in the terminal next week, reducing the dozens of previous work classifications to a very simple structure.

ANSWER.PARA: It was a rather novel ceremony in the sense that the Australian waterfront for the last half a century has not fared very well in international comparisons in terms of the training that has been provided by employers to workers. I am pleased to say that situation is changing. I hope that this morning's arrangements in Sydney are going to be the first of many.

National Terminals is at the forefront of pursuing reforms in the stevedoring sector and this company has now concluded its enterprise agreements for all of its mainland terminal facilities, including Melbourne, Sydney, Fremantle and Brisbane. The changes that have been made to the work practices, for which these new courses are designed, are being supported very aggressively indeed by the company's investment program which encompasses a $60m redevelopment of its Port Botany facilities and a $8m redevelopment of its Fremantle terminal facilities. The company is also at the forefront of introducing electronic data interchange provisions at its terminals with the aim of being able to offer electronic trading at all of its container facilities in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I ask the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support whether the reason for spending hundreds of thousands of dollars in taxpayers' funds to bribe 45-year-old wharfies to become redundant was to save his own neck.

—-That is a particularly stupid question, but I will answer it nonetheless. As I have pointed out before in this chamber, the redundancy packages were not set at levels determined by the Government; they were set at precisely the levels determined by the Inter-State Commission in its recommendations, upon which the Government's reform program is firmly based. These redundancy packages were designed with the existing redundancy arrangements in the industry well in mind. The agreement reached in Sydney last week after extensive consultations with the employers and the unions is designed, with the full support of the employers, to accelerate the pace of reform, which of course is the fundamental difficulty that the Opposition has. Not only do those opposite not want to see it accelerate but they do not want to see any reform by negotiation at all.

—-Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister recall explaining to us that the purpose of the original and overgenerous package, I might say, was to get rid of about 3,000 older workers and to employ about 1,000 younger workers? How does that fit in with offering redundancy packages to 45-year-olds? I remind the Minister that he is representing the people of Australia and not the employers and the unionists in this organisation. What about a bit of compulsion? With nearly one million Australians on the unemployment scrap heap as a result of this Government's economic policies, will the Minister explain to the unemployed people of Australia why he is willing to spend hundreds of thousands of dollars trying to make 45-year-old wharfies redundant? How will that help the unemployed people of Australia? What contribution will that make to this nation's economic recovery?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I welcome Senator Lewis's latter-day interest in waterfront reform, but it would benefit him and the Senate if he did five minutes of homework first. With regard to the package which has been put together, the Government has absolutely resisted all attempts by unions and some employers for some 18 months to short-circuit this reform process and provide redundancy packages without reform. Rather than take up any more time of the Senate unnecessarily, I simply assert to Senator Lewis--because he obviously does not know--that the arrangements which were reached in Sydney last week to provide additional redundancy packages are precisely in accordance with the formula laid down in the in-principle agreement that established this waterfront reform process. Those arrangements were put in place to anticipate the very problem we have now.

ANSWER.PARA: It is an interesting example of just how various the labour demands are in any kind of waterfront system, but particularly in Australia. At the time the in-principle agreement was negotiated, there was a national shortage of labour. As a result of the recession and the significant downturn in business on the waterfront over the past 12 months, we now have a significant surplus of labour. Arrangements were put into place. They are encapsulated in the in-principle agreement, a copy of which I will send to Senator Lewis. The arrangements reached last week are precisely in accord with those laid down in the in-principle agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. I refer the Minister to his strong statements of support for clear and identifiable country of origin labelling for imported food products when he said on eight occasions in the Senate and once to a group of farmers at the Great Aussie Breakfast that identifiable labelling on imported food was needed to allow informed choice by consumers; to prevent misleading information to consumers; so consumers can exercise power in the marketplace to support Australian farmers; and for the advantage of Australian farmers putting their own products on the Australian market in competition with overseas products. Does the Minister concede that the present minimum requirement of 1.5 millimetre country of origin labelling, with no requirement for it to be placed at the front of the label, does not meet the commitment he gave to farmers and consumers for clear and identifiable labelling? Is the Minister aware that the Australian Food Standards Committee has recommended no change to the pinhead-size labelling on imported food products, ignoring the Minister's previous directions? Will the Minister be prepared to stand up and fight for Australian farmers and consumers and his own considerable integrity by convincing Cabinet that a promise made by one Minister should be honoured by another, even if the responsibility has changed to another portfolio?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-It is a fact that as Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs I have very vigorously promoted the idea that shoppers and consumers ought to be presented with as much information as possible in order to make choices in supermarkets and elsewhere which will benefit Australian farmers and orchardists by enabling the--
—-All rhetoric and no action.

—-The interjection is that I have taken no action. That demonstrates Senator Olsen's profound ignorance in these matters because the Australian Food Standards Committee, at my initiative and instigation, determined in relation, for example, to orange juice concentrate that was flooding into Australia, being diluted with Australian water and peddled as produce of Australia, that in those situations the imported orange juice concentrate was to be clearly advertised as such on the label. I believe that that proposal comes into effect on 1 January 1992, at my initiative.

ANSWER.PARA: Again, in relation to unpackaged food--for example, fruit, vegetables, nuts and fish--imported unpackaged food in those categories will have to bear a label indicating that it was derived from an overseas country. I believe that that comes into effect on 28 February 1992. So, at my instigation, a lot has been done to inform Australian shoppers and consumers. However, it is a fact that, in relation to unpackaged food, the label is to be 4 millimetres high.

TALK.START.PARA: —-No, it is 1.5.

—-In relation to unpackaged food it is 4 or 4.5 millimetres. In relation to packaged food, the Australian Food Standards Committee did not take up my suggestion and has determined that 1.5 millimetres should remain the required minimum size. I mention that in relation to the minimum because the fact is that Australian producers of packaged foodstuffs should take the initiative and put `Country of Origin' or `Australian Produce' in much larger lettering, and on the front of the label, if that is what Senator Boswell wants. By that sort of advertising and promotion of Australian produce, they can help Australian shoppers and consumers to purchase foodstuffs, which will in turn aid Australian farmers and orchardists. It is up to Australian producers of these packaged foods to take advantage of that possibility and to do that.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that that minimum requirement of 1.5 millimetres was taken by the Australian Food Standards Committee to be adequate, as a minimum, as an information standard. In relation to health warnings and so on, of course, the required minimum size of labelling is much higher. These matters have passed out of my immediate control and the National Food Authority, which was the subject of intensive examination in this chamber when the legislation was passed and in the Estimates Committee, now has the question of food standards in Australia under its aegis and supervision. I believe that it would be appropriate for it, as it carries out its first major review and survey of the rules relating to labelling, to examine the matter of print size on labels for country of origin information.

I could suggest to the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services that he request the National Food Authority in its review to once again undertake that sort of examination of the minimum size of labelling for country of origin information. I believe that Australians do deserve to know what is the country of origin of the food that they purchase. As I say, I will make that representation to the National Food Authority, through the Minister, to further that process.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I concede that the Minister has made some headway on orange juice and packaged food. The problem that we now face of $2,134 billion worth of food coming into Australia, much of it processed, is that many people cannot identify what are Australian and what are overseas imports. The Minister has given a commitment on various occasions to the farmers and once directly to them at the Aussie Breakfast. Will the Minister go into Cabinet and be prepared to fight for--
—-He is not a member of it.
—-At the Ministerial Council.
—-Will he be prepared to fight for it in the Ministerial Council and will he be prepared to fight for his word and support the farmers on this very major issue?

—-Of course I, on behalf of consumers and therefore on behalf of farmers and orchardists, am prepared to advocate that this labelling question should be looked at again by the National Food Authority. Senator Olsen, who seems to be Senator Boswell's supplementary interjector and helper in these matters, quite rightly pointed to the fact that it is not the Federal Cabinet but the Ministerial Council where State and Territory Ministers make these decisions. Senator Boswell ought to focus not only on me but also on State and Territory Ministers responsible in this area for his considerable lobbying expertise.
—-Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-On 4 September, Senator Spindler asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question relating to the vesting provisions for superannuation contributions. I have an answer from the Treasurer, which I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: To meet the prescribed standard under the Superannuation Guarantee Levy arrangements the prescribed level of employer superannuation support will be required to vest immediately and will be fully preserved. These are the same requirements which currently apply to award superannuation contributions.

Superannuation schemes which do not currently provide immediate vesting to the level required under the Superannuation Guarantee Levy arrangements will need to be modified if contributions to these schemes are to be counted for the purposes of the Superannuation Guarantee Levy.

The Superannuation Guarantee Levy is intended to come into effect on 1 July 1992. In finalising the detailed arrangements for the Levy the Government will consider whether there is a need to provide additional time for funds to comply with the vesting requirements.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Senators in the Senate assembled:

The petition of the undersigned shows the very deep concern of people in the community against the proposed AIDEX exhibition of weapons of war in our country. We firmly believe that it is not in Australia's interest to become dealers in death and destruction. Particularly at this time when our planet's environment is in a parlous condition and demands statesman-like leadership to the world on its rehabilitation. We therefore ask that:
The Exhibition to take place be one which shows instead the ways in which we aim to overcome the dangers to our world from poisoned soil, air and water by high-lighting the need for tree-planting,
solar-powered homes, electric cars, etc. as a means of attacking the global warming and other hazards to our fragile environment.
And we, your humble petitioners will as in duty bound, ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Alston (from 20 citizens), Senator Bolkus (from 20 citizens) and Senator Tate (from 20 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Smokefree International Flights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned,
(i) are alarmed at the health and safety hazards that arise from the smoking of cigarettes and other tobacco products on international airlines, a dangerous practice banned within Australia;

(ii) call for the International Civil Aviation Organisation (IACO) of which Australia is a member to set a standard for smokefree international flights; standards set by IACO must be agreed to by its 162 member nations.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Bolkus (from 80 citizens), Senator Crane (from 105 citizens) and Senator Robert Ray (from 60 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Tobacco Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we the undersigned call for urgent action by our Federal Parliament and all government agencies concerned with Health and Sport to impose an immediate ban on the incidental advertising of tobacco products on television and provide for alternative funding to replace tobacco sponsorship. That tobacco sponsorship of sporting events and participants openly flouts the 1976 Federal law prohibiting tobacco advertising on TV and radio. That our Parliament immediately end this association between healthy sports and the deaths of 18,300 people in Australia each year from tobacco-related diseases.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the senators in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life.
That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect.
That in 1987/88 taxpayers funds through Medicare provided Medical Benefits for 61,879 abortions totalling $6.4 million.
That in the same year Federal Government grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: 0055 Services
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned draw to the attention of the Senate:
The readily available range of sex and fantasy audio text services transmitted via Telecom through the use of the 0055 prefix.
We request the Senate to move to disband this "adult" information and entertainment service because of the affect these messages have on our youth and Australia's moral standing.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium: Mining and Export
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: 0055 Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
(1) Telecom is selling 0055 telephone networks to private contractors who provide offensive and sexually explicit recorded messages to the public.

(2) The providers of these services are advertising in the pages of Australian newspapers in a manner which is designed to titillate and attract calls from the whole community and thus play on the curiosity of children.
(3) These services degrade and humiliate women and portray them as sex objects, and they destroy the innocence of children.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, immediately call on Telecom to remove these services so that women are no longer portrayed as sex objects, degraded or humiliated and that the innocence of children is protected.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully call on the Government to withdraw its endorsement from the arms bazaar, AIDEX `91, scheduled to be held in Canberra, 26-28 November, 1991, and to ensure that no government department or company takes part in the aforementioned event.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Political Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth:

That we call upon the Senate to reject legislation denying Australians the right to advertise electoral material on radio and television, believing such bans amount to a refusal of free speech, an unfair advantage to an incumbent government, and a denial of information to print-handicapped Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GILES

TALK.START.PARA: —-by leave--I present to the Senate the following petition, from 382 petitioners, which is not in conformity with the Standing Orders as it is not in the correct form, requesting that the Government establish diplomatic and trade relations with the legitimate representatives of the republics of Croatia and Slovenia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully shows:

That 92% of Croatians who voted in a referendum on 25 April 1991, supervised by the Constitutional Court of the Republic of Croatia, declared their support for Croatia as a sovereign and independent State and their opposition to Croatia remaining in the Yugoslav Federation;
That 88% of Slovenians who voted in a referendum democratically expressed their support for Slovenia as an autonomous and independent State;
That both Slovenia and Croatia have declared themselves to be independent Republics and that each Republic is prepared to defend its territorial integrity.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should request the Australian Government to:

Establish diplomatic relations with the legitimate representatives of each Republic and of any currently subjugated country whose residents by a democratically expressed popular vote have declared their wish to be independent; and
Established trade relations with the Croatian and Slovenian Republics, to take advantage of the very favourable attitude which exists between the people of these Republics and the Australian people.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: X-Rated Television Computers and Television Services

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BROWNHILL

TALK.START.PARA: —-by leave--I present the following petitioning letter, from eight petitioners, which is not in conformity with the Standing Orders as it is not in the correct form, requesting that the Senate oppose the availability of X-rated television computers and television services:

SPEECH.PARA: 16 August 1991
The Secretary,
The Senate Select Committee on Community
Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services
Utilising Telecommunications Technologies,
Parliament House
Canberra.
Dear Sir
It does not take a war to destroy a nation--in fact from defeat often comes a great upsurge of unity and strength for its people, i.e. West Germany and Japan since World War II.

The most successful way to bring a nation to its knees is from within, by destroying the moral fibre of its people--witness the downfall of the Roman Empire. Australia is following this road right now.

Since the advent of the permissive society in the `Seventies', acceptable standards of behaviour and the breakdown of family life are being eroded fast enough without the advent of video and television pornography.

As for a number on which to phone in and get an earful of porn, we are frankly horrified. We are not young, but we are not senile, and we care about the community in which we live, and we care deeply about the world which our grandchildren will inherit through no fault of their own.

The Senate is looked upon as a house of review--we exhort the members to do just that, and prevent a further deterioration of moral standards by refusing to sanction the ready availability of X-rated television, X-rated computers, and X-rated telephones.
We remain
Yours faithfully
Josephine Staughton
Petitioning letter received.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I give notice that on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate--
(a) notes with concern the increasing severity of drought conditions in southern Queensland, northern New South Wales and parts of Western Australia;

(b) further notes that the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics has forecast that farm incomes will fall by 24 per cent in 1991-92, following a 34 per cent drop the previous financial year; and

(c) calls on the Government to put in place measures to alleviate the hardship that the population of these areas will no doubt suffer as a result of this drought, which will add to the already disastrous level of unemployment in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I give notice that, four sitting days from today, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the determination by the Minister for Social Security of directions under subsection 1237(3) of the Social Security Act 1991, dated 8 July 1991, and tabled in the Senate on 13 August 1991, be disallowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate--
(a) notes the continuing public campaign for the Prime Ministership by the discredited former Treasurer (Mr Keating);
(b) notes the deep divisions this campaign is accentuating within the Hawke Government;

(c) notes Mr Keating's statements calling for an immediate cut in interest rates, arguing for less emphasis in Government policy on inflation and more on growth and jobs, and describing Labor Party and union opponents of these proposals as `crawlers to the Prime Minister';
(d) expresses its concern at the policy paralysis resulting from Mr Keating's attacks and from other differences within a deeply and bitterly divided Government;
(e) condemns the Government for allowing this policy paralysis to lead to further economic hardship and loss of hope for average Australians; and

(f) demands that the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, either use the authority of his office to exercise effective leadership or resign, on the well-established principle that if you cannot govern your party you cannot govern the nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That leave of absence be granted to Senator O'Chee from 8 October 1991 to 18 October 1991, inclusive, on account of absence overseas on parliamentary business.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate--
(a) notes:

(i) the continual and totally discredited forecasts about unemployment by a Prime Minister whose word, according to his former Deputy Prime Minister, cannot be trusted, particularly his forecast in November 1990 that unemployment would not reach 10 per cent and that by mid-1991 we would see the Australian economy recovering, and recent claims that unemployment would soon begin to fall under a `surge' in employment,

(ii) that expert forecasters such as the National Institute of Labour Studies predict that unemployment is almost certain to reach one million compared to the present 840,500 and will remain high for years, and
(iii) that the latest job advertisements survey by the ANZ Bank reveals that there are now fewer than two job vacancies for every 100 unemployed Australians;

(b) further notes the total policy reversal in the call by the former Deputy Prime Minister and Treasurer, Mr Keating, for a change in government policies to reduce these unacceptably high levels of unemployment that Mr Keating's policies have created; and
(c) calls on the Government to recognise that the only solution to this problem of high unemployment is provided by the Coalition's radical economic and tax reform packages.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate --
(a) notes:

(i) the strong support being given to discredited former Treasurer, Mr Keating, in his leadership challenge to Prime Minister Hawke by the Secretary of the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union, Mr Wally Curran,
(ii) that this is the same Mr Curran whom both Mr Hawke and Mr Keating have correctly described for years as a leading member of the `looney left', and
(iii) that Mr Curran has been directly responsible for the virtual decimation of the meat industry in Victoria in recent years; and
(b) recognises that, despite their apparent differences, Mr Keating and Mr Curran have in common the claim to be two of the greatest destroyers of the jobs of average Australians in our history;

(c) notes the unholy political alliance that has existed for many years between Mr Curran and the Victorian Premier, Mrs Kirner, to the extent that Mr Curran is widely credited with having been largely responsible for Mrs Kirner's elevation to the position of Premier; and
(d) expresses the fervent hope that Mr Curran does not have the same success in elevating Mr Keating, with his massive record of economic policy failure, to the Prime Ministership of Australia.

This will permit the Committee to table its report on Wednesday, 16 October 1991. I understand that the extension of time sought by the Committee will not cause any disruption to the timetable for consideration of the Appropriation Bills by the Committee of the Whole House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The list read as follows--
