DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-by leave--On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, I present the Committee's report on the Aboriginal and Islander Electoral Information Service, together with a video recording and minutes of proceedings. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, I present the Committee's report entitled Aboriginal and Islander Electoral Information Service. I also present a video on the report produced by the Committee and the Parliament's Sound and Vision Office specifically for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. The video deals with those aspects of the report which address ways in which the Aboriginal and Islander Electoral Information Service could be improved to provide better service for those people.

The Aboriginal and Islander Electoral Information Service, run by the Australian Electoral Commission, was set up to provide Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in traditional and remote communities with electoral information and education and to encourage their enrolment. AIEIS differs from other similar programs which preceded it in that it gives responsibility for the delivery of electoral information and education to Aboriginal and Islander people themselves. This is done by educating selected community members, called community electoral assistants, as resource people for their own communities.

The Aboriginal and Islander Electoral Information Service was reviewed by the Australian National University's North Australia Research Unit in 1987-88. The NARU report was referred to the Committee of the Thirty-fifth Parliament by Senator Robert Ray, then Minister for Home Affairs. It was re-referred, with expanded terms of reference, to the Committee of the Thirty-sixth Parliament by Senator Bolkus, the Minister for Administrative Services.

The work of the Committee has been greatly assisted by those who made submissions and particularly by the contributions of the many Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people with whom discussions were held both in Canberra and during two site inspections in north Queensland and Western Australia. These site inspections were a critical source of information to the inquiry and gave the Committee the opportunity to meet the members of Aboriginal and Islander communities and to talk with some of the people who are served by AIEIS and many of the community electoral assistants who work with AIEIS. The site inspections were undertaken so that the Committee could test, out in the field, the observations that were made to it in submissions.

A primary question facing the Committee was whether there is a need for the service provided by AIEIS. The inquiry has convinced the Committee that such a need does indeed exist. As a group, Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders are electorally disadvantaged. Factors which contribute to this include a lack of general education, restricted access to general electoral education services offered by the AEC, and remoteness of location. We must also remember that compulsory enrolment for Aborigines was introduced only in 1983. It is because of this electoral disadvantage of Aboriginal and Islander people that the AIEIS program is necessary.

The Committee has therefore recommended that the program be continued. It has also recommended that the program's name be changed to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Electoral Information Service so as to reflect more accurately its target clientele.

The AIEIS program's objectives include both electoral education and enrolment. There has been to date a conflict of views within the AEC concerning the relative importance of these objectives. This conflict has affected relations between AIEIS officers and other AEC staff and, in part, hampered the efficient operation of the program.

While the Committee certainly endorses the importance of enrolment, it believes that enrolment is of limited use unless it is accompanied by education. Accordingly, the Committee has recommended that the AEC formulate a clear policy giving priority to education and information in the AIEIS program.

The conflict over the focus of the program is symptomatic of other problems faced by AIEIS. The Committee noted several deficiencies in the AEC's management of the program which are not conducive to the efficient and effective delivery of service. AIEIS has been adversely affected by inadequate staffing, insufficient management commitment to the program, vague lines of authority and poor program evaluation.

The Committee has made a comprehensive series of recommendations which address these concerns. They relate to the full and continuous staffing of the program; the demonstration by the AEC's management of an appropriately supportive attitude to AIEIS; administrative changes which will establish clear lines of authority and control; and improvements to reporting and accountability mechanisms.

Another matter of concern to the Committee is that, because of its limited area of operation, the AIEIS program is not reaching the majority of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. To ensure access to the service provided by AIEIS for all Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders, the Committee strongly recommends that the Aboriginal and Islander Electoral Information Service be extended to the States not now covered, that is, New South Wales and Victoria, and to urban areas; and that the AEC seek funding for this from the Federal Government.

The Committee is pleased to be able to report that its inquiry has already resulted in some favourable outcomes in respect of the program's expansion. A submission to the Committee by ATSIC prompted the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner) to approach Senator Bolkus concerning the possibility of extending the program. At Senator Bolkus's request, the AEC developed, and has received budgetary approval for, an extension of the program, and extra funding. Sufficient funding will now be available to employ at least two more field officers.
The Committee would also like to see the program's scope expanded to include information on state and local government and the role of political parties, and has made a recommendation to this effect.

Certain aspects of the way the program operates in the field could also be improved to make electoral information and education more accessible to more people. The Committee has recommended that there be greater emphasis placed on fostering wider community support for the program and developing greater community participation. There should also be greater use made of visual media such as videos, comics and T-shirts, as these have been identified by Aboriginal and Islander people as valuable educational aids.

During the Committee's investigation, it heard much about the role played by AIEIS in the conduct of the first ATSIC regional council elections held on 3 November 1990. Many regional returning officers and ATSIC officials told the Committee that AIEIS played a vital role in the success of those elections and that, in fact, polling could not have gone ahead in many places without the presence and dedication of AIEIS field officers and community electoral assistants. The information, education and enrolment functions of AIEIS were also crucial in preparing people for the elections. The Committee strongly believes that access to electoral information and education is the right of all Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. Only with the provision of such education and information will they become full participants in the government of this country.

In addition, this inquiry impressed upon the Committee that in places where AIEIS has operated well there is among Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders a new enthusiasm for democratic processes and an eagerness to participate in them, both as electors and candidates. This has left the Committee in no doubt that the Aboriginal and Islander Electoral Information Service is a worthwhile program. Accordingly, it urges the AEC to address the problems identified in this report and to take steps to improve AIEIS so that it provides all Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders with an efficient and effective electoral information, education and enrolment service.

The report embodies the unanimous views of the subcommittee comprising Senator Kernot, from the Australian Democrats in Queensland; Mr Miles, MP, a Liberal from Tasmania; and me. It is unfortunate that when the report was considered by the full Committee it ran into opposition from two members of that Committee--Senator Kemp, a Liberal from Victoria; and Mr Cobb, MP, a National Party member from New South Wales--neither of whom participated in the subcommittee's public hearings and site inspections.

Their criticisms are contained in a dissenting report, and they focus on two broad areas. The first is the claim that insufficient evidence is provided to support the report's conclusions, and the second is that the report was unduly critical of the AEC. There is a certain irony in the fact that the dissenting report provides very little detail to support the criticisms which it mounts; in other words, the dissenting report fails to meet the standards which it insists the majority report should have applied.

On the question of evidence, I believe that adequate evidence has been provided to support the recommendations made and every effort has been made to refer to transcripts of public hearings, where appropriate, or to information gleaned from site inspections. However, it should be noted that, firstly, committees are not obliged, as suggested in the dissenting report, to respond in their reports to every submission made and, secondly, committee reports are not written like PhD theses. They are more practical documents which, unlike academic theses, we hope people will read.

It is also worth noting that the recommendations of the majority report are broadly in line with the NARU report, which I have already referred to. In other words, the ANU's northern research unit, staffed as it is by academics, arrived at similar conclusions independently of the Committee. Its findings are regularly referred to in the report.

On the dissenting report's criticism of the Committee for failing to provide adequate survey information concerning the enrolment of Aboriginal and Islander people, the following is made clear in the report at paragraph 1.4:
It is not possible to calculate Aboriginal enrolment levels because enrolment data do not include information on ethnicity.

The dissenting report also criticises the report for recommending an expansion of the AIEIS program into urban areas without, it claims, adequate information demonstrating the need. I draw the attention of honourable senators to paragraphs 3.12 and 3.13, table 1 and paragraph 4.33, which outline the need to expand the program into urban areas. In addition, it is outlined in the NARU report at page 21 that not providing the program to Aboriginals in towns and urban areas is based on the false assumption that those Aboriginals are taking advantage of sources of information available to all citizens. Many of them are not, because they are isolated socially just as much as the rural Aboriginals are isolated geographically.

Finally, paragraph 3.18 of the report clearly recognises the claim that the Committee has been unfairly critical of the AEC and that it fails to recognise the problem of inadequate resources faced by that body. In paragraph 4.3, it is made clear that the AEC provided inconsistent evidence on the way in which it allowed the operation of the program to be dictated by the program reviews, particularly the NARU report and the investigation carried out by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters.

In short, I believe that the Committee has made every attempt to be fair and balanced in its view, and has supported the conclusions it has drawn in a manner which is both adequate and consistent with the nature of normal parliamentary reports. I am satisfied that the criticisms levelled in the dissenting report are not matters of substance. I look forward to Senator Kemp and Mr Cobb applying to other parliamentary reports the same standard that they appear to want to apply to this one.

To conclude, I wish to thank the Committee secretary, Bev Forbes; Pattie Tancred, who was assigned specifically to this subcommittee; and Frances Coates and Judy Jurek of the Committee staff, all of whom did an excellent job. I commend the report and the video to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-As a member of the electoral matters subcommittee, I am delighted to speak to the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. The subcommittee Chairman, Senator Beahan, has already clearly outlined the reason for the inquiry. He has covered its main recommendations and the response of the subcommittee to the dissenting report.

SPEECH.PARA: In the brief time available to me, I want to focus on some personal observations and to comment on some of the recommendations. My first observation is that it has been very important to give to Aboriginal and Islander people the responsibility for the delivery of electoral information and education. Our site inspections in northern Queensland and Western Australia certainly confirmed this.

As the report points out in its introduction, field officers and community electoral assistants play a key role in ensuring that Aboriginal and Islander peoples develop basic electoral skills. The voluntary community electoral assistants we met were competent, enthusiastic and hard-working. They had the respect of their communities and they were very successful in ensuring a good turnout on polling day.

It was interesting to note that the majority of community electoral assistants were women. It is worth noting, too, that many of these women already played a very important role in nurturing and educating their communities in health, housing and other matters. Their role in maintaining social cohesion in their communities cannot be underestimated. I think particularly here of the women from Turkey Creek in the Kimberleys. These community electoral assistants clearly recognised and communicated to their communities the link between participation in decision-making and ensuing action.

This leads me to my second observation, a matter on which Senator Beahan touched, and which I would call the rekindled interest of Aboriginal and Islander people in the whole electoral process because of their recent experiences in the ATSIC elections. Although there were varying levels of turnout, ranging from 75 per cent in non-urban areas to 10 per cent in some urban areas, the clear impression I gained was that, as ATSIC regional councils have been and are meeting regularly, many Aboriginal and Islander people are determined to be candidates and to participate in the process next time around.

I think it is certainly true that the AIEIS program has played a very important role in supporting not only the ATSIC election but also all recent elections in which Aboriginal people have been involved. That is why I think it is extremely important that the program be continued, as the Committee recommends. It is more important, as has been recommended, that the Australian Electoral Commission formulate a policy for the extension of this valuable program into more settled areas, including major metropolitan regions.

Aboriginal and Islander witnesses who spoke to the Committee had many constructive comments to make, particularly on how we can communicate more effectively with Aboriginal and Islander voters; hence, our innovative use of the video to communicate the recommendations of this Committee to the various Aboriginal and Islander communities in Australia.

I commend the Government for its continued support of this program. I commend the work of the subcommittee's Secretary, Ms Patti Tancred, for her organisation of the very comprehensive site inspections. Although the subcommittee looked specifically at electoral information services, I think it was in a position to note many other signs of progress being made in Aboriginal and Islander communities. We must not underestimate the very important role that the Aboriginal and Islander Electoral Information Service plays in Aboriginal communities in communicating and in improving the communication skills and the participation rate of Aboriginal people. I commend the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I would like to speak briefly to the report. As has been mentioned by Senator Beahan and Senator Kernot, there were some concerns in the Committee about the report. It was as a result of these concerns that Mr Cobb and I filed a minority report.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that it is worth while briefly going through some of the matters we raised. Senator Beahan, in his remarks on the report, referred honourable senators to the particular concerns which I raised in the minority report and the particular pages in the body of the report and asked them to judge whether the criticisms were valid. On that particular comment by Senator Beahan, I think that is certainly an appropriate course to follow.

When we went through the report in the Committee, and when we went through the criticisms which were outlined, I think it was reasonable for us to look and see on what basis these particular assertions and criticisms were made. It became apparent in a couple of areas--and they were in some key areas--that the report had arrived at conclusions which certainly Mr Cobb and I did not feel were sustained by the evidence that was given to the Committee. It was quite right that we were not there as part of all the hearings and we were not there as part of the discussions. This was, as Senator Beahan pointed out, a report that was essentially prepared by a subcommittee. Nonetheless, in view of the fact that the Committee had to turn its mind to the report ultimately and the Committee had to approve the report, it was appropriate that members of this Committee look very closely at the conclusions which were arrived at in the report. Senator Beahan has said that there were conclusions which were made in the report which I found simply could not be sustained by the evidence which I was able to read and which was presented to me. I think that the ultimate test is for honourable senators to read the report, to read the criticisms of the report which Mr Cobb and I have made, and to assess whether the matters that we raised were valid.

It seems to me that one of the difficulties that the Committee had to address was the key objectives of the AIEIS program. As I read the objectives as laid down by the AIEIS program, one seemed to be particularly important. That was the fourth objective, which is listed in the report at page 7. This objective of the AIEIS program reads:. . .to facilitate, directly or through Aboriginal and Islander communities and organisations, the enrolment of Aboriginal and Islander people and the maintenance of electoral rolls.
It is a very important and key objective and certainly one which I think all of us in this chamber could thoroughly endorse.

The difficulty with this report is that this objective, at least in my mind, was never assessed properly. I think that the Committee and, I regret to say, the subcommittee failed in their work to assess carefully whether that key objective of the AIEIS program was being met. I am sorry that that happened. As I said earlier, it is an important objective and one would have hoped that the subcommittee would look at it very closely and assess the evidence to see how that program was going.

This brings me to the next point I wish to make. It was very clear, upon reading the evidence, that there is deep division between at least some of the officers who are involved in the AIEIS program and the officers in the AEC who either had direct management responsibility for this program or were involved with it in some other way. There is no doubt that the AEC management saw this objective as a key objective and was very concerned that, in some areas at least, the officers involved in the AIEIS section of the program had a different view of their role. To my mind, the Committee's report never came to grips with that issue. That fourth objective is an important objective which should have been considered more carefully by members of the subcommittee.

The second major criticism we had of the report concerned the proposed major expansion of the AIEIS program into urban areas. Frankly, I do not think the case was well made out for that important and, in my view, extremely expensive proposal. Again, the evidence was simply not presented in the report.

It is not good enough for people to come into this chamber and state that all of these things are good and worthwhile and should be expanded, without doing the job which they were asked to do which was carefully to assess the program to see where it was performing weakly and to make proposals as to how it could be strengthened, based on hard evidence, not on good feelings.

As I said in the minority report which I presented, we recognise and, indeed, support the program. Many submissions were made which clearly supported the program and, certainly from my point of view, the objectives of the program are eminently worthwhile and deserve to be supported. The tragedy of this report which Senator Beahan has presented to the chamber is that I do not think the subcommittee looked, in a proper and careful way, to see whether those objectives were being met.
Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.

Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs--(3.44 p.m.)--I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows--

The Student Assistance Amendment Bill (No. 2) seeks to make three minor changes to the Student Assistance Act 1973. The Act gives the legislative basis for the Austudy scheme and provides a debt management regime for the other student assistance schemes.
Appropriations Clause

Student assistance schemes are demand driven, with the overall expenditure depending on the number of full time students applying for assistance. It is therefore more appropriate to provide a special appropriations clause in the Student Assistance Act than to deal with the schemes through the normal appropriation legislation.

Accordingly, the Bill proposes to insert a section into the Student Assistance Act to appropriate the funds needed to pay allowances under the Austudy, Abstudy and assistance for isolated children schemes.
Cocos (Keeling) Islands

The Bill will also extend the application of the Austudy scheme to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. This reflects the move to normalise the application of Australian laws to the territory, including the phasing in of normal income tax arrangements.
Living Allowances for English as a Second Language Scheme

A third measure in the Bill concerns the living allowances for English as a second language scheme. This is a small scheme which provides living allowances to migrants undertaking Commonwealth funded courses in English as a second language at TAFE colleges. About 1,400 students were assisted in 1990 at a cost of approximately $3.7m.
From 1 July 1991, the scheme has been integrated into the social security payment system, though the scheme is included as a separate budgetary item in the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1991-92.
In view of the new arrangements, it is no longer appropriate for the debt management regime for the scheme to be provided for under the Student Assistance Act and the Act will be amended accordingly.
Financial Impact

The Bill will have no significant financial impact on overall expenditure. The extension of Austudy to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands is expected to cost about $20,000 a year. The other provisions are cost neutral and involve improved arrangements for paying the same amount of assistance to students.
Conclusion
I present the explanatory memorandum for the Bill, which gives additional details on the proposed changes. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-During the debate on the Loan Bill (No. 2) 1991 in the last parliamentary session, I was discussing the regrettable sequence of events that had led to the need for a loan Bill and the lack of direction given in the Budget to turn events around. At the time, I had finished discussing the Government's about-face in relation to fiscal policy and will now debate wages policy--or the lack of wages policy.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Senate that during the late 1980s the Government frequently arranged wage trade-offs so that employees' wage packets were often increased without the employer having to meet the cost of the higher disposable income which resulted. The Government's idea at the time was to restore profit share--a noble objective--by giving business money to invest in its own business or elsewhere in the business market. So the story went. But that is where the rhetoric ended because, at the same time, the Government introduced a series of measures to bring forward the collection of corporation tax and, through the Australian Taxation Office, set up a system whereby it brought revenue to account earlier than in the past--we had the Coles-Myer decision, for example. At the same time, in some cases the Government tended to deny the deductibility of expenses--or certainly deferred that to a greater period of time. One example was the depreciation regime.

Whilst there is no agreed percentage for wage increases in the Budget, negotiations are certainly taking place outside that context. Unfortunately, in the Budget there is a very substantial increase in the on-costs of employment through the proposed legislative superannuation requirements. I point out to the Senate that this will act as a major disincentive to employment so far as employers are concerned. In fact, the impact could be just as devastating as that iniquitous payroll tax which is levied by the States--a tax on employment in a time of recession. There would be severe criticism of the Government and the Australian mentality if we were to accept such taxes on employment.

While the Government may say it has a wages policy, there does appear to be a lack on the other side of the coin in that there is no policy in relation to jobs. This lack of commitment to jobs is a most stinging criticism of the Government. In fact, this lack of commitment is so strong that it has raised a point of conflict between the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Premier of Victoria, Mrs Joan Kirner, and that conflict also extends to some of her Ministers. The threat of retribution from the Prime Minister is indeed a bitter pill to be placed in the mouths of so many Victorians. The threat of cuts to Victoria is a sad reflection of the attitude of a Prime Minister when approximately one million people are unemployed. We on this side of the chamber have drawn attention on more than one occasion to the Prime Minister's appearing to be more interested in the security of his own job than in the security of the jobs of a million other Australians.

If we come back to the question of monetary policy and the undue emphasis that the Government has placed on it, we find that some few weeks ago the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) announced a one per cent decrease in interest rates. I think the Government is building up the atmospherics for a further decrease in interest rates. But the easing of interest rates runs contrary to the earlier rhetoric from the new Treasurer and the Reserve Bank in the weeks preceding the original announcement, which stressed that lending indicators in the economy were recovering and that easing rates could not take effect until 1992, when the recovery was well under way.

Unfortunately, if we look at the statements of Mr Kerin, we will see that there has been a complete failure to explain to the public why this interest rate drop has occurred. In fact, the Australian Financial Review was astute enough to note that, in tone, interpretation and selection of the facts, the Government's statements are completely at odds with all that it has been saying about this so-called medium term approach to controlling inflation.

In another area, I remind the Senate that the recent surge in the exchange rate of the Australian dollar vis-a-vis the American dollar reflects the very high real interest rates which prevail in Australia. If real interest rates happen to fall--and they could--there is the chance of a chaotic situation with the exchange rate, which could have a monumental impact on the Government's ability to manage the economy.

I suggest that these moves in interest rates, which will occur as a result of the move the Government is now contemplating, will now put the Government in very grave danger of throwing away the opportunity to lock in the recessionary fall in inflation. If we closely read the statements of the previous Treasurer, we can believe that he is prepared to sacrifice that fall in inflation. That is part of a continuing saga of conflict between the new Treasurer and the previous Treasurer, which is unfortunate at a time of such severe recession.

The 1991 Budget is the Government's third attempt in the past six months to address the economic plight of the country. The first attempt was last year's Budget and the second was the failed March industry statement. I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that we do not have a legislative base for any of the items in that statement. Hence, that document was essentially just a pile of rhetoric. It is only in recent days that one feature--the depreciation regime--has been finalised. Even then, the Government failed to acknowledge the need of the asset to have an economic life vis-a-vis a physical life. It is a matter that is certainly recognised in all regimes which are sophisticated and determined to ensure that there is an appropriate deductibility regime for plant in this country.

In April 1990, the OECD report on the Australian economy suggested that action needed to be taken which would boost export growth, domestic savings and productivity and dampen inflation. On the whole, that advice was basically ignored. This is a tragedy for Australia. We are very cocksure in the way that we can provide advice to other governments around the world. It is regrettable that the Government shunned the economic advice that was given to it by such authorities as the OECD and went full steam ahead on basically a monetary policy that has had such devastating effects on the Australian economy, particularly for jobs and employment.

When the economy showed no signs of recovering in the last half of 1990, the Government decided it should have a second go at getting it right by issuing the March industry statement, which, I must say, ended up being a further disappointment. I suppose the only good news was that, by some means which the Government did not fully explain, inflation dropped. That was a result of the great recession. The emphasis therefore moved from the current account deficit being the primary economic concern to maintaining a low inflation rate. The emphasis now seems to have changed again. It is now October 1991, and unemployment has not yet reached 10 per cent but, by the Treasurer's own admission, it will certainly do so in the not-too-distant future. Inflation has, until perhaps a few weeks ago, been held in check. There are now ominous signs of its rising.

Despite the high sounding urgency of the 12 March industry statement, there is still no legislation. Hence, where is the Government's commitment and where is the Government's priority in trying to change things around? Where is the Government's priority in trying to get more jobs and in creating a proper business environment that is conducive to employment and job creation? The only activity that the Government really is good at nowadays appears to be kite flying and rhetoric.

The question that begs to be asked is: where to now? Passing these loan Bills, while legally required and very easily done, is the soft option that this Government has consistently followed. When it attempted to overcome the last recessionary difficulties, it attempted to borrow its way out of the problem. This is reflected in the fact that we had a high interest rate regime as a result of emphasis on monetary policy, and at present we have a national indebtedness of $165 billion or $166 billion. It is a situation that reflects a steady lowering of the standards of living of average Australians. This is the price that the Australian community has had to pay for a government that is not prepared to tackle the hard economic consequences facing Australia, which the world is telling us about but which we choose to ignore. That is, we are burying our head in the sand and are prepared to allow our own kith and kin, our own peoples, to suffer the consequences.

This Loan Bill is basically the soft option. In fact, I would rather be giving this Government credit for another year of Budget surplus. I think we will find ourselves debating yet a further loan Bill in six months time. This is the tragic scenario that we are getting into. We have taken the attitude that by borrowing money we can spend our way out of trouble. Instead, we are getting ourselves deeper and deeper into debt with consequent lowering standards and little hope for the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —-In speaking to the Loan Bill (No.2) 1991, I simply wish to draw to the attention of the Senate a matter that has caused me some concern since the Budget details were announced, and it is an aspect of the Budget which appears to have escaped the attention of the public at large. A setting down fee has been introduced within the Attorney-General's Department on all matters now being set down for trial before the Federal Court, the Family Court and the various tribunals which come within the jurisdiction of the Federal Attorney-General's Department.

SPEECH.PARA: At a time when there is a great concern about the costs of justice generally around Australia, this Government has chosen to introduce another fee--a hidden tax--of $500 every time a matter is set down for hearing before any of the Federal courts. That provision was pretty well hidden in all of the Budget Papers. It was so well hidden that, when inquiries were raised about it, it appeared that the notification within the Budget that the amount of $500 would apply to all matters being set down in any Federal court or tribunal was, in fact, not correct. The Budget Papers said that, but on further inquiry at one of the Estimates committees it was ascertained that that did not apply to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, where the fee was to be only $200. That $200 is, of course, on top of a mandatory $300 filing fee, so I suppose the total payment is much the same.

There is one very unfair result. When people wanted their income tax assessments to be reviewed in the old days they were able to ask the review board to reassess the assessment and it cost $2. If several years came up at once, it would have cost $2 a year. As I understand the proposal--although there seems to be a scant amount of information on it--it will now cost a $300 filing fee plus a $200 setting down fee for every single income tax assessment that people want reviewed. That can become an enormous impost, particularly if the amount being argued about is less than $500. That is just one aspect of the issue.

Every single matter that people want to raise before any Federal court now will cost a $500 setting down fee, in addition to other fees. It absolutely amazes me that, in times when everyone is concerned about the cost of justice, when it is so difficult to get before courts and to get before them at a reasonable price, this Government imposes a $500 tax on people before they can seek relief and justice from the courts.

What further concerns me is that some of the people who administer the Acts within the Attorney-General's Department and who administer the courts seem to see nothing particularly wrong with loading Federal Government charges onto court fees. It was my experience as a practitioner in the law before I came to this chamber that, to be able to afford to seek justice in the Australian courts at the moment, one has to be either a pauper or a very wealthy national or multinational company. It seems that the middle range of Australians is being excluded. It just becomes impossible for middle Australians to afford to prosecute a case in a court. I raised that concern at the Estimates committee hearing. The officer who was dealing with the matter indicated that he did not agree with me at all when I said to him that people with an income of between $20,000 and $50,000 would find it almost impossible to go to courts these days, but that has been my experience.

I am concerned about what some of the officers who deal with and advise the Government, and make recommendations on these matters, understand about the whole range of middle Australians who are now being squeezed out of justice. The examples are myriad where people enter into legal matters but are forced out because of the costs of the system. The court costs of some lawyers--and I emphasise some; it is certainly not all and certainly not the majority--and the way the cases are prosecuted makes it too big a risk to proceed to seek justice. So there is an enormous number of people in Australia, particularly in the middle income group--the middle Australians--who are excluded by economic circumstances from being able to seek justice in Australian courts.

The underprivileged and those without incomes are able to prosecute who they like and to continue as long as they like because they are not footing the bill. I do not deny them that opportunity; it is good to see that they do have access to the courts and do have the right to seek justice. But the middle Australians who do not qualify for legal aid--and one does not have to be earning much not to qualify for it--are practically excluded. What has this Government done about that? It has simply exacerbated the situation by imposing another $500 fee on those who want to seek justice before the courts.

There has not been a lot of publicity about this. I understand that the fee is to start on 1 October. I do not think too many lawyers have heard about it yet, and that makes me think that I must have the date wrong. I see the Minister is sitting in the chamber; maybe he could elucidate on that later. The matter was raised by me in the Senate Estimates hearings on 5 September but, apart from that, I have not heard much about it.

This morning I received a letter from the Law Council of Australia, which has become aware of this matter. It is very concerned at the additional costs that will be imposed upon litigants. The Law Council particularly notes the fee in the Family Court. A person entering an application in the Family Court for relief has to pay the $500 fee every time a determination is sought by the Court. It will be particularly serious in this area, where the breakdown of relationships can often lead to dramatic consequences necessitating more than one application to the Court for relief. For example, is it the case that a fee will be payable every time a spouse needs to approach the Court to seek an order to restrain the other spouse from physical abuse, abusing a child or destroying or hiding property? Will a fee have to be paid on a spouse's application seeking urgent maintenance before his or her case can be heard?

The Law Council strongly opposes the imposition of these fees, as I do, particularly as it increases the whole cost of justice at a time when there is a real concern in the community about the cost of justice. It has a more serious aspect than just the economic one. It is getting to a situation where, whilst we as a nation with a common law history brought down to us through our English heritage, place so much emphasis and so much faith on our ability to get before courts and to seek justice, there is now a real danger that the vast majority of middle Australians are being forced out of any remedy they might have to proceed to the courts simply because of the cost. As I say, that is a wider concern than simply the economic one. It does mean that justice is being taken from the vast majority of middle Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I rise in this debate because of my concerns about the level of unemployment and what should be done to resolve it. We have seen the most extraordinary debate in recent days about welfare and compassion, as if the only way to resolve the disaster of unemployment is to have a bigger and bigger welfare bureaucracy and to throw more and more money at welfare. The reality is that the best way to resolve the problem of unemployment is to create jobs, and that appears to be the last item on this Government's order of priorities. It is certainly the last item on the debate over welfare that takes place in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: It is remarkable that in that debate there have been accusations that, for example, the Greiner Government in New South Wales lacks compassion. In fact, it is the only State Government that is genuinely doing something about the disaster of unemployment. It has limited enormously the impact of this Federal Government-induced disaster around Australia, so that New South Wales has had the lowest level of job loss and the lowest unemployment rate of all the States. In other words, it is showing practical compassion by trying to keep jobs in existence instead of going down the track of all the State Labor governments which have, apparently quite happily, been prepared to put their political position above the real need, the evident need, for the sorts of policies that will keep the economy vibrant and effective and able to provide jobs for Australians.

It is interesting to note the dramatic difference in New South Wales between this recession and the 1982-83 recession. The unemployment rate of about 9 per cent in New South Wales is far lower than in all the other States, some of which have a rate of well over 11 per cent. The average rate of youth unemployment in New South Wales of about 27.6 per cent, while still an horrendous level, is well below the Victorian level of 34 per cent or Tasmania at 30.7 per cent. Compare that situation with the 1982-83 recession, when there was a so-called compassionate State Labor Government in New South Wales: the New South Wales unemployment rate was 10.7 per cent--the highest of all the States.

It is remarkable that New South Wales--the normally heavily industrialised State and therefore the most vulnerable State to economic downturn--under a Labor government suffered worse than the other States but in this recession is suffering least. It is not simply a coincidence; it is a result of much sounder, much more restrained, much more effective policies, and I will deal with those policies and their consequences individually. So we have a total turnaround, a total reversal of the situation in the 1982-83 recession compared with this recession in terms of the impact on New South Wales.

Let us look at the indicators. In 14 of the 15 quarterly indicators of economic activity in Australia, New South Wales performed better on average than the other States. In terms of unemployment, there are over 50,000 more people in jobs in New South Wales than would be the case if New South Wales had an unemployment rate equal to the average level of the other States. There is effective concern for the unemployed--not the phoney concern, if I can use that expression, of those people who see the only answer being in bigger and bigger welfare spending, bigger and bigger welfare bureaucracies, and more and more schemes that are aimed largely at hiding the true level of unemployment rather than doing the job properly, trying to generate greater skills, greater ability and greater job opportunities.

Let us look at these indicators of how New South Wales has performed better than the other States. According to the latest available figures for motor vehicle registrations, the fall in New South Wales was just half that for the other five States, on average. Retail turnover has gone up considerably more in New South Wales: 7.5 per cent in the latest period to July compared with 6.8 per cent for the other States. Residential building approvals in the other States are up by 13.9 per cent, but in New South Wales they were up by 26 per cent in July. The number of unemployed people in New South Wales had fallen by 7 per cent in August compared with August the previous year, as against a 2.9 per cent drop in jobs in all the other States. Bank deposits in the other States have gone up 9 per cent, while in New South Wales they are up 11.9 per cent. Bank loans in other States are up by 6.6 per cent; in New South Wales they are up by 12.7 per cent.

If we look at the great bulk of these economic indicators, we see that New South Wales is far outperforming the other States. That does not mean that one should sit back and say, `Everything is wonderful'. Of course it is not. Of course the levels of unemployment throughout Australia are appalling, and they are appalling because of the policies Mr Keating introduced and the recession he deliberately engineered. That is his own expression: his engineered recession. How extraordinary it is that Mr Keating, having engineered this recession, is now providing gratuitous advice to Mr Hawke and his Government about what should be done to correct the unemployment Mr Keating himself generated, with Mr Hawke's total support.

We should remember that the continual promises of Mr Hawke--whom Mr Keating finds sufficiently untrustworthy to say in public that he would not work with a man whose word could not be trusted--about how unemployment would fall have been shown to be totally, consistently false. Last year Mr Hawke said that it was not a prospect that unemployment would reach 10 per cent. We now know that to be false as the figure approaches 10 per cent--it is now 9.8 per cent--and further figures will come out on Thursday of this week showing the level of unemployment for September.

We look forward, unfortunately with nervous anticipation, to what will happen to unemployment levels when the school leavers start coming into the labour force in the new year. We have an unacceptably high level of unemployment. The only way to resolve that high level of unemployment is to undertake the radical reforms--particularly of labour reform and economic reform and certainly of tax reform--that the coalition is proposing and has in fact been proposing for some time. This Government has chosen continually to ignore the warnings of impending disaster if it persisted with its failed policies and to dismiss the policy initiatives that the coalition has continually said are needed. The Government has continued to ignore those policies by failing to introduce our initiatives.

What is particularly galling to the Opposition is that, having created a disaster, the Government, and particularly those of its supporters in organisations whose structures are financed by it, are saying that the Opposition lacks compassion and is hard-hearted in its policies when it has been demonstrated that these policies are the only way to provide what the unemployed really need, which is not handouts, more schemes or bigger bureaucracies but jobs. Our policies are jobs and growth oriented--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Which one?

—-I am glad to hear the interjection. I refer to the whole structure of our reform package--economic reform, labour market reform and infrastructure reform, which has gone right off the boil because the ACTU will not allow the Government to do it. Let us look at the latest association that the former Treasurer has with the man who has destroyed more jobs in Australia than any other single person, referring to the man who runs the Victorian meat unions. Let us look not only at this Government's continuing failure to acknowledge the need for radical reform but also at its policy of continually attacking the Opposition's proposals, which are so soundly based and have a genuine capacity to reduce the levels of unemployment, which are simply unacceptable in Australia. When we look at a coalition government at work in New South Wales and see at the time of this recession an enormous reversal of what happened in the previous recession, when Mr Wran and his Labor cohorts were in power and New South Wales was the worst State--it is now the least worst State--we see that management is a vital part of any effective delivery of a compassionate policy aimed at reducing the burdens on Australians, particularly those whose jobs are either lost or at risk.

SPEECH.PARA: The way to solve the problem is to create more jobs and to follow the coalition's very determined and complete package of radical reform. The coalition's reforms to the tax system are an essential and central part, as most of the Labor leaders recognised, of course, when they were arguing in favour of them in 1985. The present Government is failing in its duty. It has failed its major area of support, which is the working people of Australia. It has generated this disastrous level of unemployment and has deliberately engineered an economic recession. The coalition provides the only way out of this mess.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I thank honourable senators for their contributions to the debate on Loan Bill (No. 2) 1991. I will refer in a moment to the amendment moved by Senator Short and spoken to by others and also to the comments made by some of the later speakers. However, I want to deal first with some of the questions asked by honourable senators in the course of the debate and some of the substantive points that they raised.

SPEECH.PARA: The Loan Bill is intended, purely and simply, as a means of financing a prospective shortfall in the Consolidated Revenue Fund. Loan Acts have been used by governments of all political persuasions since 1911 to fund such shortfalls. There is nothing particularly unusual about the requirement to have two such Bills during the same calendar year. For example, there were two in each of 1962, 1966, 1968 and 1982, and in fact three in 1976.

The Loan Bill is, as Senator Short pointed out, a machinery financing measure which is required where payments from the CRF are expected to exceed moneys available to that fund. During the debate Senator Spindler sought an explanation as to why expenditure from the CRF must not exceed money available to it. The reason is that legally the fund is a collection of moneys. It is inherent in the nature of a fund that it cannot consist of a negative amount. In effect, the Government can spend only as much as it has in the bank. If the Government requires more money, it must borrow it; hence the requirement for the Loan Bill now before this chamber.

The main components required to fund the estimated deficit of $10.2 billion in the CRF are identified in table 4 of Budget Paper No. 2, the Commonwealth Public Account. This shows on the payments side the $5.5 billion in defence expenditure estimated to be charged to the loan fund and on the receipts side $4.7 billion estimated to be received from the loan fund. These payments will be authorised by parts 2 and 3 of the Loan Bill respectively.

Senator Watson asked for details of receipts and payments of the CRF which, because they are classified as financing transactions, do not impact on the Budget outcome. These amounts are shown in aggregate in table 1 of Budget Paper No. 2 and amount to some $3.1 billion of payments and $4.9 billion of receipts. I will detail these transactions in the same order in which Senator Watson sought the information. The major components of the estimated $3.1 billion CRF payments are, firstly, $3.1m to discharge the principal component of loans originally issued by the former Canberra Commercial Development Authority; and, secondly, a $1.7 billion payment to the national debt sinking fund to finance the repayment of securities issued on behalf of the Commonwealth in accordance with the provision of the National Debt Sinking Fund Act 1966. As it is estimated that there will be no surplus in the CRF this financial year, it is not anticipated that any funds will be transferred to the loan consolidation and investment reserve. In addition, $1.3 billion will be paid in superannuation payments to former employees of public trading enterprises and $72m for Comcare benefits to employees of public trading enterprises.

The major receipts of the CRF are expected to be $3m from the investments of former superannuation schemes; $4.7 billion from the loan fund under the provisions of part 3 of the proposed Loan Act (No. 2); $118.6m in superannuation contributions from public trading enterprises; and $57.7m for Comcare premiums from public trading enterprises. This Bill becomes a necessary part of the Budget strategy and reflects the fiscal responsibility in the face of current economic circumstances. For that reason, we reject the amendment moved by Senator Short and spoken to by some of his colleagues.

One can see that the Opposition is feeling somewhat dogged by the emergence of some economic good news. It is clutching at the remnants of the bad news as the economic recovery commences. The amendment is internally contradictory, as were some of the arguments put in support of it. The Opposition feigns concern about unemployment, yet it seeks to cut outlays in the manner outlined by the shadow Minister for Finance, the shadow Treasurer and the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), which would lead to the loss of 46,000 jobs. As is usual with the conservatives, those opposite exhibit their concern about unemployment by getting rid of jobs, just as they exhibit their concern about inflation by putting up prices. The amendment talks about a reckless deficit, a concern that Government expenditure is too high and a concern that we should not even allow the automatic stabilisers to work to cushion the effects of the recession.

We have in this amendment and the arguments for it the underlying rationale for the attack on ACOSS, which is an organisation made up of some of the most respected, responsible and decent citizens in Australia. It is being attacked because there is a concern that it may--I am quite confident that it will--deliver a message when the Opposition's package of measures is outlined, expose the inadequacies of that package and show the ice-cold heart of the Opposition, which is trying to shoot the messenger before the message can be delivered. I regret to say that that is not exactly elevating the standard of debate in Australian public life. I am pleased to say that it will fail.

I do not believe that the amendment ought to be carried by the Senate. It is not going to break anyone's heart if it is carried, because it is a statement of pious views by the Opposition which is so transparent that nobody would be concerned about it. We will be supporting the amendment to that amendment because it is a minor improvement. It seems to me that the Democrats have actually missed the point of some parts of Senator Short's amendment or they too would be opposing it. That is their concern, not mine. We will vote for their amendment but, of course, we will oppose the Opposition's amendment, even should Senator Spindler's modification of it be carried. I thank honourable senators for their support of the Bill.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Spindler's to Senator Short's amendment) be agreed to.
