SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Aussat Repeal Bill is an important Bill which comes at an historic moment in the reforms of the telecommunications industry in this country. It is also historic in the sense that it brings to an end the Aussat satellite service as a service in its own right. As a result of this Bill there will be a legislative regime put in place to prepare Aussat for sale, with Aussat becoming the core of the second carrier. As a result of the selection procedure that has been devised, an applicant for the licence will be required to buy Aussat.

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, this is yet another example of the contortions and distortions that have flowed from the original decision by the Government to pander to Telecom Australia and to its unions and to ignore what at least some in the Government, including Senator Cook's patron, Mr Keating, believed was the right course and one which we certainly adopt. That course is that Telecom should have been competing against the Overseas Telecommunications Corporation (OTC) and Aussat--not simply going down the path of creating a mega-carrier, one which combines an efficient OTC with a very inefficient and pampered Telecom.

As a result of that artificial combination, we now have the other side of the coin. In other words, in order to establish a second carrier to provide some sort of viable alternative, not only did the Government have to countenance the entry of foreign carriers--and we now have two consortia, both of which have substantial components of American carriers providing the expertise, with Australian companies more or less bringing up the rear--but we would not have got even to that stage unless the Government had forced the pace in a sense by structuring the entry conditions so that Aussat had to be bought in this way.

There is no doubt that no-one in his right mind would have been interested in buying a carrier such as Aussat which has been so unproductive in terms of profit-making that its debt at the current time is around $689m and by June next year is expected to be in the vicinity of $800m. That comes about not because Aussat has been inherently uncompetitive or overtaken by new technology, but quite the opposite. Once again it is the result of the disgraceful manner in which the Government has continued to favour Telecom, as a result of an incestuous arrangement whereby it not only continued to hold 25 per cent of the shares in Aussat but also its managing director and another director were on the Aussat board and therefore privy to all its decisions.

At the same time that they were nobbling Aussat from within, they were ensuring from without that Aussat was never able to compete on fair terms. Aussat was thoroughly constrained, was not able to enter into switched services, which resulted in something of the order of 90 per cent of the potential market in that area being denied to it. Telecom even went to the point of contesting vigorously a court action in the Northern Territory whereby the local Aboriginal communities had the temerity to want to get access to the best carrier service in the shortest possible time, but were told that they had no right to treat with Aussat. They simply had to get in the queue and wait their turn and Telecom would decide when and where it would lay ground cables through to those communities.

That is simply one small example of the way in which Aussat has been constrained from the outset, has been hidebound by political compromises and has been squashed by Telecom whenever the opportunity arose. I find it deeply disappointing that Telecom not only felt no shame during that period, but has shown no remorse since. While it has now been forced to face up to market realities, it has certainly been dragged screaming and yelling to that position. At no time did Telecom even concede that there was a potential conflict of interest. Indeed, it clumsily threatened anyone who had the temerity to suggest that there might have been a compromise or a conflict of interest. That again is an indication that at the highest levels of Telecom management there was not only a lack of appreciation of the virtues of competition but also a desire to pander to the government of the day and not to have any concern in terms of the national interest as to whether Aussat should survive.

We are now brought to this sorry point where the Government, realising that it could not give Aussat away with a debt burden of the order of $600m to $800m, is effectively to pay out the debt by allowing it to be absorbed by the Commonwealth and then to insist that any applicant for a second licence buy Aussat and presumably make whatever it can of its existing satellite technology. The bulk of the debt was incurred because Aussat had the foresight to come to the view that it could participate in the delivery of pay television and as a result that it would be necessary to contract for the B series satellites.

Having done that, the Government is still dithering over pay television, which has now been on its agenda ever since it came to office. We are probably somewhat closer to it than we have been in recent times, but a succession of Ministers for clearly political reasons have declined to introduce any form of pay television to date. I think that technological forces ultimately will overwhelm political resistance and that the Government will be forced to a position where pay television becomes a reality in this country. Once we are in that situation one would expect, but could never take for granted with the way in which the Government politicises these decisions, that the acquirer of Aussat would then be in a position to take advantage of that new market opportunity.

It is this Bill which brings to an end the Aussat satellite service as we have known it. Aussat has had this debt burden around its neck virtually since its inception in 1981, but in particular since this Government came to office in 1983. That debt burden has never been addressed until the present time, thereby further crippling Aussat's efforts to expand its market coverage. All that happened in that regard is that last year the Government made a decision to provide $100m to Aussat to keep it operational because technically it was almost bankrupt. The directors were not prepared to sign Aussat's accounts unless a decision was made by the Government to ensure that it had a reasonable capital base. Again, it was only when the Government recognised that Aussat was in such desperate financial straits that it was prepared even to bail it out to that extent, but merely as a holding operation.

What we see in this Bill is the result of a series of politically flawed and politically motivated decisions, which have resulted in the Government coming up with, at very best, a second-best alternative in terms of restructuring the arrangements for telecommunications services in this country. It is a solution which does not meet any of the recognised criteria for micro-economic reform and one that simply creates a duopoly environment with the potential to compromise the development of a truly competitive telecommunications sector. I suspect that the combination of new technology and the demands of consumers for a much higher quality of service than they have had available to them to date will transform the environment and there will be some significant price offerings by the new carrier. I certainly foresee a much better quality of service than we have had to date from Telecom.

It has been one of the great disgraces of the history of government business enterprises that an outfit such as Telecom, with the sorts of massive profits it has been able to make year after year, has never felt obliged to take account of customer concerns in any respect. By way of example, in my home State one of the busiest suburban shopping centres is Burke Road, Camberwell. Saturday morning sees every shop in that shopping strip open for business except the Telecom shop. It, of course, is open only from nine to five.

TALK.START.PARA: —-They weren't even open at the Show last Monday in Perth.
—-Nothing has changed, except that the advent of competition--
—-Nothing has changed. The Liberals still bash Telecom all the time.

—-I would have thought that Senator Kernot would be on the side of the consumers. Therefore, I would have thought she would deeply regret the fact that, if someone wants the phone fixed at a weekend--
—-I don't think what we are putting into place will automatically assist consumers.
—-It certainly cannot be argued that what we have had for the last eight years has in any way been in the consumers' interest.
—-But it's not all bad.

—-All I can say is that I regard it as a second-rate service. I have not seen any significant indication that Telecom has been willing to give people access to the sorts of services that are taken for granted overseas. Overseas, people can get new phones not only within 24 hours but also, quite often, within a matter of hours. They can be guaranteed that they will not have to wait for inquiries or information for more than 10 seconds instead of constantly being put on hold and now, I think, being subjected to the ultimate insult of having to listen to further Telecom propaganda. Those who are interested in sporting services used to dial 1187 to find out the half-time football scores but are now told that that service is out of business and that they have to dial some fancy 0055 number and, of course, pay heavily for the privilege.
—-How terrible! It's not a lot of money. It's quite cheap.
—-The point is that people used to get that service for, presumably, 22c or 30c. It provided all they needed to know.
—-There's no such thing as a free lunch.
—-Or a free call.
—-It is all a matter of what the cost of the call is.
—-And providing the service in this case.
—-Do those opposite know what service is being provided? Telecom is foisting on people a service that they do not want.
—-Then don't call them.

—-That is exactly what will happen. In other words, people will not be able to get the service they want and the only service that will be available is the one that they do not want. They dial in on the circuit and may then have to listen for five minutes until the item they are interested in comes up. In other words, it is just another example of Telecom being interested in making mindless profits rather than having any real concern for the customers. I hope that this new environment will go some way towards forcing Telecom into the new realities. Hopefully, the new carrier will be able to bring in a whole series of new initiatives which we have not seen in this country to date.

SPEECH.PARA: The Aussat Repeal Bill will bring about some significant changes. In many respects, we will still not see the most made of the satellite systems in this country. We will have to await the initiatives of the new carrier in that regard. There is still a great deal of uncertainty about the interconnection arrangements that will apply and operate in relation to the new carrier. That will impact very significantly on the extent to which it is able to make use of the satellite services. Whilst we do not oppose this Bill, I will be moving a second reading amendment, which I understand has been circulated in my name.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Has it?

—-I do not have any proof of that fact either, but I am assured that it has. It simply condemns the Government for not taking steps to address the issue of the high debt of Aussat at any time in its term of office, and condemns the Government for choosing structural arrangements in telecommunications which do not satisfy the requirements--
—-Like selling everything, presumably. The structural arrangements--what are you suggesting instead?

—-Structural arrangements such as merging OTC and Aussat rather than merging OTC and Telecom--in other words, the most fundamental misalignment of organisational structures that one could possibly imagine and which could only conceivably have come about because Caucus, in its wisdom, thought that somehow this was going to protect the monopoly of the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association for a bit longer. That is what it is all about, as the Minister well knows.

SPEECH.PARA: It was only Mr Keating and a few other brave souls in the course of the cabinet debate--which got so furious that we had Mr Beazley's submission leaked in its entirety to the Australian Financial Review, which is how we know what the argument really was--who recognised economic reality and were prepared to push for what was clearly the optimal arrangement. But, of course, no, political compromise and expediency prevailed and we have this ridiculous camel that will probably drown under its own weight. I move:
At end of motion, add ", but the Senate:
(a) condemns the Government for not taking steps to address the issue of the high debt of Aussat at any time in its term of office;
(b) condemns the Government for choosing structural arrangements in telecommunications which do not satisfy the requirements for full micro-economic reform; and

(c) notes that the bill prepares Aussat for sale with the purpose that it forms the basis of the Second Telecommunications Carrier in a duopoly environment, which has the potential to compromise the development of a truly competitive telecommunications sector".
I indicate that we will otherwise be supporting the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My interest in the financial details of Aussat is reasonably well known. It is my belief that the Aussat Repeal Bill 1991, which appropriates $800m to cover Aussat's debts, should come with an apology to the taxpayers of Australia, who are now expected to foot this $800m bill for a service that we did not need and which, we have said in the past, we have had imposed upon us.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, I indicate that the Australian Democrats will be reluctantly supporting the appropriation. I think it is time to get Aussat off the taxpayer's back. We acknowledge that we have lost the major battle. As none of the fundamentals of Aussat's operation have changed and the satellite would only continue to lose money, we think that the burden might as well be passed on to the second carrier.

Before I take a moment to put on the record yet again the details of Aussat's history, I want to deal with another matter arising from this Bill. Since the Government first floated its concept of telecommunications micro-economic reform back in 1989, the Minister has argued that the establishment of a telecommunications duopoly was not a front for unburdening the Aussat debt. I have to say that I remain unconvinced by protestations to the contrary. Sure, it was not the only reason, but it was a significant reason for the decision.

The first section of this Bill paves the way for Aussat to be sold unencumbered to the second carrier. The second section, dealing with telecommunications, paves the way for the Minister, without parliamentary scrutiny, to arrive at some private agreement over licence conditions with the new carrier, be they complex technical regulations or on the level of foreign ownership.

The Australian Democrats are not happy to accept the proposed new section 407 which, if enacted, would allow for the application, adoption or incorporation, with or without notification, of `matter contained in any other instrument or writing whatever'. The theory of what the Government is attempting to do is fine. Certainly, Parliament's time is too valuable for it to be bogged down with changes, adoption and incorporation of technical specifications and regulations, especially in the fast paced area of telecommunications development--and we accept this position.

When the Government introduced the Telecommunications (Regulatory) Bill exposure draft, consumer organisations and the Minister's advisory panel pointed out that the Bill needed to discriminate between second carrier licence conditions that impact on the lives of the community and those secondary conditions that relate specifically to updating regulation. It was the Minister's decision not to separate the licence conditions into two specific categories or to give them separate priorities.

When the Senate was faced with allowing the Minister absolute discretion over the determination of the licence conditions, it voted to subject the licence conditions to parliamentary scrutiny. I suspect the Minister may have been slightly annoyed that we had done so.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Which one?

—-Not Minister Collins; Minister Beazley. I do not object, obviously, to the Government's attempts now to rectify a problem it may have added to in the first place. The Democrats will accept that instruments under this Act may provide for matters by reference to any other instruments. However, we are not happy about what we see as issuing the Government with carte blanche to write any instructions it likes to the new carrier without parliamentary scrutiny, especially since the network carrier licence is watertight and cannot be revoked.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills report on this Bill highlights, it is important for people in a democracy to know or to be able to ascertain what the law is. If there is to be scope for, say, international standards to apply `as they are in force from time to time', can the Minister tell us when and how these will be notified to those to whom they apply?

Aussat exists because of some bureaucratic wish to dish it up to Telecom Australia and the Telecom unions, right or wrong. However, it must not be forgotten that the decision to launch the first generation satellites was a grandiose vision of the Fraser Government. As early as 1975 the Government of the day was warned by Telecom's predecessor that expensive satellite technology would have been superseded by cheaper telecommunications. It was warned that satellite systems for national applications in a country of Australia's demography and geography were not economic. But did the Government listen? No.

If Aussat had been a commercial enterprise and not simply a matter of expediency or misjudgment, the A-series satellite would never have left Earth. Some eight years and $800m of taxpayers' money later, Aussat has managed to capture less than 2 per cent of Australia's total communications market. Where are the itemised accounts to show which particular drain the $800m fell down? In passing this Bill, I suspect the Government thinks it can bury its mistakes and get away from any focus on its incompetence in managing the taxpayers' money.

What went wrong with the projections that indicated that between 1989 and 1992 the system should earn sufficient revenue to cover the costs of the first generation satellites and provide a $300m surplus for reinvestment? The projections were in error because of the assumption that the transponder take-up leases would be very rapid: 100 per cent of the 12 high power transponders by 1986-87 and 100 per cent of the 33 low power transponders by 1989-90, they said. In fact, the actual occupancy was 72 per cent in October 1988. The assumption of rapid take-up of all transponders seems curiously imprudent. Was it really feasible that 100 per cent of all high power transponders would be yielding standard revenue within one year of satellite launch? This ignores normal marketing margins, particularly given the institutional decision making and technical lead times of users.

The 1987 financial background briefing which supported the request for tender for the second generation systems also made some outrageous predictions of $15m dividends by 1992-93. The first generation satellite system was not economically viable on any realistic assumptions, but this Government was prepared to give Aussat a Treasurer's guarantee. Thanks to the work of many, but particularly Dr Sam Paltridge at CIRCIT, we now know that these preposterous occupancy estimates in some ways reflected the heady prospects we saw in television networking and distribution before the industry troubles became visible after the 1987 share market crash. In other words, this Government made precisely the same mistakes as Messrs Skase, Lowy and Bond--and we know what happened to them. But unlike them, this Government has Consolidated Revenue to bail out its mistakes. Instead of using the $800m to do something else with--and people often point to job creation, hospital funding and public sector housing--for our $800m we got what I think is an almost useless piece of space junk.

What concerns me is that the full extent of the Government's bad management and lack of supervision is still not known. At Senate Estimates committee hearings earlier this year we tried to ascertain some of this information. I do not believe we were successful; in fact, I think we were fobbed off.

Since the sale of Aussat without debt is going to be the entry price for the new telecommunications carrier, it is only right and proper that Australian taxpayers know how Aussat's finances got into such a deep mess. Aussat's original bad planning cannot be laid at this Government's door, that is true, and I am happy to repeat that; but in 1986, when the expensive designed B-series was planned, the Hawke Government could have pointed to the Fraser Liberal Government's folly of pursuing this and walked away with only a minor debt--some suggest less than $100m. It did not, and the Hawke Government compounded the mistake by pouring good money after bad.

Against all expert advice, the second generation satellites were commissioned and ordered at a cost of $440m to the taxpayer. Can we now assume that the bid from the new telecommunications carrier will reflect the $800m appropriation we are agreeing to today or is the Government going to base its decision on the second carrier on a broader range of concerns other than strict commercial viability? After all this time, we are still left wondering what is the true value of gaining entry into Australia's lucrative telecommunications market. The fact that we are still left wondering is clearly most unsatisfactory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Aussat Repeal Bill appropriates $800m to pay out Aussat's outstanding debts and ensures that any new owner cannot claim tax losses. From what Senator Kernot said, it is obvious that she lives in a high population area and not in a remote area where satellite technology is necessary for telecommunications.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, since the Aussat satellite was put into action by the Fraser Government its usage and return on capital has not quite come up to expectations, as was ably pointed out by my colleague Senator Alston. Aussat went into action with one arm tied behind its back. There was no way in the world it could compete with either Telecom or anyone else under the conditions on which it was allowed to operate.

Australia is the ideal country for satellite technology. Probably no other country in the world needs satellite technology as much as Australia, with the exception of Canada, with its extensive remote northern region, and Russia, with its enormous area. However, Aussat, with one hand tied behind its back, was not able to make use of the technology available, which was advanced technology at the time. I believe that the Fraser Government made the right decision to put up those satellites in the first place.

Then, of course, we had the Telecom fiasco; it made sure the Aussat system did not work. Of course, Telecom in later years was greatly helped by the advent of optic fibre so it did not have to build such expensive landlines as it used to. It was able to completely take over the communications in Australia so many years down the track because of that optic fibre. Unfortunately, that is how things have gone. We are debating this Bill to give Aussat $800m to wipe off those debts.

I would like to move away a little from Aussat into the modern-day light satellite type of system. There was a conception by which Motorola Electronics Australia Pty Ltd and Transfield (Australia) Pty Ltd were to launch some light satellites at Woomera. Last week, as part of a committee, I visited the Woomera area where this opportunity provided by Motorola and the Transfield corporation to launch those light satellites was lost. Unfortunately, without help forthcoming from the present Government, that has gone by the wayside.

The idea was to launch, say, 11 in seven bands, making 77 of these light satellites that would virtually then bring us into another phase of mobile communications whereby one could use a cordless phone type of operation in remote areas at any time of the day or night. Of course, that would be much cheaper than the first generation Aussat and the second generation. Unfortunately, in one way or another, the Government failed to realise the opportunity and here we are again with another opportunity having gone out of the door.

Of course, we could have gained a lot of export income by carrying on with getting the light satellite system off the ground. I do not believe that we have lost the technology forever though; I believe that other corporations will, in time, come along and take over where Motorola and Transfield left off. I am wondering whether Telecom played a part in Motorola and Transfield not getting off the ground, just like it did with Aussat.

While we looked at Woomera last week, I could not help noticing with concern the run-down state of the Woomera rocket launching range. Woomera still has a population of 2,000 people who are in highly skilled professions. It has about 600 Americans living there, servicemen and families, and the Australian construction corps is there as well. I observed from our visit that the Government has certainly let the range run down. I know there are problems because there were some joint ventures with the British Government which has not been too forthcoming in helping to clean up what happened in the past. But I think the Government has to look at getting Woomera back on stage again so that it can be used in the launching of these light satellites. I believe this is a technology that the whole world has to have, not just Australia. Then, we can--whether it is at this place or at the one in north Queensland, at Cape York--launch satellites. The satellites launched at Cape York would be travelling in an east-west direction, whereas the ones launched at Woomera would be the polar ones.

I call on the Government to have a good look at Woomera again and see what can be done. I believe that the allocation for this space office was only $5m in the last Budget, as it has been for many years. It is time the Government greatly increased that if we are to make the best of opportunities. As I said, Woomera and Cape York are ideally situated to take part in the coming technology. I support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-It has been said in this Parliament on a number of occasions--and it was alluded to by Senator Kernot--that Aussat Pty Ltd was, in fact, the only telecommunications initiative that the previous conservative Government ever did launch. I think it would be fruitless to spend any unnecessary time debating the pros and cons of that decision or indeed what may or may not have affected the final result of Aussat's profitability. I will ensure that Senator Panizza's comments about Woomera are drawn to the attention of the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Beazley.

SPEECH.PARA: In response to Senator Kernot's inquiry about how there will be public dissemination of these changes, that explanation is contained in the letter from the Minister that has been sent to the Chairman of the Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee, Senator Cooney. Point 3 of the letter states:

Under the Telecommunications Act 1991, Austel's technical standards are disallowable instruments which must be published in the Gazette. Public comment and review form a major part of the process of disseminating information to relevant individuals and organisations on any changes to standards.

Austel and various other interested parties are members of CCITT work groups and any changes to international standards are notified to the relevant parties in Australia. Austel would be the main disseminator of such information in its capacity as ITU signatory.

In conclusion, I indicate that the Government will be opposing the second reading amendment moved by the Opposition. Clauses B and C, of course, make the Opposition's motives in moving this very clear. We are well aware of its `let it rip' philosophy so far as telecommunications is concerned. We disagree. We think the staged and careful approach that the Government is proposing to provide competition to Telecom is the appropriate way to go at this period of time. I know and accept that the Australian Democrats do not accept that should be done at all. But we certainly believe that the Opposition's `let it rip' approach is not appropriate for Australia at the current time. For those reasons, we will be opposing the second reading amendment.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Alston's) be agreed to.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I table the supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the new clauses to be moved by the Government to the Aussat Repeal Bill 1991. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: After clause 5, page 3, insert the following new clauses in Part 2:
AUSSAT not within the shield of the Crown
"5A. To avoid doubt, AUSSAT:
(a) is not, does not form part of, does not represent, and is not an instrumentality or agency of, the Crown; and
(b) is taken never to have been, formed part of, represented, or been an instrumentality or agency of, the Crown.
Clarification of AUSSAT's status for income tax purposes
"5B. AUSSAT is not, and is taken never to have been, a public authority for the purposes of paragraph 23(d) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936.".

During negotiations with bidders for the sale of Aussat, which are currently under way, doubts have been raised about Aussat's status, both in terms of its relationship with the Crown and as a taxpayer. These doubts are based on the argument that, notwithstanding the fact that Aussat Pty Ltd was incorporated as a company in 1981, the subsequent passage of the Satellite Communications Act 1984--now the Aussat Act 1984--either transformed Aussat into an emanation of the Commonwealth or made it a public authority exempt from income tax under section 23 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. If the doubts are correct, past claims by Aussat under taxation provisions dealing with everyday matters such as trading stock, depreciation, deductibility of expenses and repair costs may at some time be reassessed by the Commissioner of Taxation and disallowed. In addition, claims by third parties arising from arrangements entered into with Aussat on the basis that it is a taxpayer also risk reassessment and disallowance.

There is no question that since Aussat's incorporation it was always the Government's intention that Aussat be a taxpayer and it has always been treated as such by both the Government and the Australian Taxation Office. While the Government's legal advice is that Aussat is probably not an emanation of the Crown, the Attorney-General's Department considers that its tax status under section 23 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 does require clarification.

In any event, unless both matters are put beyond doubt now, continuing doubt on the part of bidders for Aussat may impact adversely on the sale price for Aussat as they seek to make provision for the risk of reassessment and disallowance. With the Aussat Repeal Bill currently before the Senate, there is an opportunity to remove this doubt quickly and effectively and with no delay to the Aussat sales process. I commend the amendment to the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Firstly, I ask the Minister whether these proposed changes have any financial implications.

—-The answer is no, they do not. As I have already explained, it was the position of the Government that there probably was not any doubt about whether Aussat is an instrument of the Crown, but these doubts have been raised by people who could be potentially bidding for Aussat and this was an appropriate opportunity simply to put these doubts completely to rest. There are no Budget implications.

—-I note that under clause 6 of the Bill Aussat's tax losses, presumably accrued, are not able to be carried forward by the purchaser. What is meant by Aussat never having been a public authority for the purposes of section 23(d) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936? The supplementary explanatory memorandum says that bidders are concerned that they may not obtain the benefit of taxation provisions dealing with trading stock, depreciation, et cetera. Presumably they want to obtain the benefit of certain deductions. If the provisions are not in relation to tax losses, what are they? Are they existing deductions that have already been claimed by Aussat that it is feared might somehow be removed from Aussat in the future?

—-I am advised that there is a difficulty with third parties that have contracted with Aussat in the past on the assumption that Aussat is a taxpayer, which is how it has always been treated by the Government and the Australian Taxation Office. It will not affect the situation that Senator Alston has canvassed. It is simply designed to remove the risk that subsequently the point could be made that Aussat was not a taxpayer. That would open up the possibility, potentially, of putting the past treatment of tax in doubt and perhaps being reassessed by the Taxation Office--if there was a legal determination requiring that--even though the Taxation Office to this point has always been treating it as a taxpayer. It is simply designed to clarify that situation and to put it beyond doubt that Aussat is not tax exempt.
—-In other words, it can keep the deductions it has already achieved; is that right?
—-The answer is yes.

—-The last part says that the bidders are also concerned that Aussat may be liable under indemnities to other persons who contracted with Aussat on the basis that it was not exempt from tax. Are there any such persons who have contracted and who might be at risk?
—-I know that the answer to that question is yes, there are third parties. I can certainly obtain advice on who they are if Senator Alston wants them.

—-Without breaching any commercial-in-confidence arrangements, it would be helpful to have a better understanding of the implications of this change. I am content that that be provided subsequent to the passage of the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-There will be no difficulty in providing Senator Alston with that advice.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 September, on motion by Senator Richardson:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Senate has before it today the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1991, which has arisen as a result of an announcement by the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) in the Budget Papers. The intent of the Bill is to amend the wholesale sales tax to change the current exemption for certain goods and motor vehicles for use by people with disabilities.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition supports the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill. This Bill is based on a report tabled by the Industry Commission on 18 July 1990 entitled Aids and Appliances for People with Disabilities. The Minister said in his second reading speech:
The Government has already made decisions on the Industry Commission Report . . .

The measures in this Bill deal with the sales tax issues considered in the report. The Bill implements the majority of the Industry Commission proposals but with some variation in detail and extension.

The first of the Commission's sales tax proposals is that, in view of the confusion amongst participants as to the rules concerning the sales tax treatment of particular goods, the ATO should publish a leaflet explaining the available sales tax exemptions for people with disabilities and claiming procedures. The ATO subsequently advised the Commission that it was in the process of publishing a leaflet which it intends to distribute widely. I have not come across such a document personally. I would be interested to hear from the Government whether the leaflet is available and the manner in which it has been distributed. Perhaps the answer could be given at the conclusion of this second reading debate.

The Commission's second proposal is that exemption on motor vehicles in item 135A be limited to vehicles which cost less than the luxury car threshold under the current income tax arrangements, and that an exemption should not be approved if the person concerned has received an exemption in the previous four years. The Government has taken up the first part of this recommendation, extending it to include items 135 and 135A, but it has not taken up the second part relating to the four years. Items 135 and 135A provide wholesale sales tax exemptions conditional upon the type of user. Item 135 provides exemption for the purchase of motor vehicles to be used by veterans who have lost the use of a leg or both arms. Item 135A concerns vehicles purchased to transport to and from gainful employment persons who have lost the use of one or both legs to the extent that they are permanently unable to use public transport.

As a result of this Bill, items 135 and 135A will be renumbered as 135(1) and 135A(1). The Bill does not amend the wording of the former items in any way. Thus, I anticipate that the Australian Democrats will be moving to amend the proviso in item 135A regarding limitation of transport for the purpose of travelling to and from gainful employment. We have yet to see the nature of those amendments, but earlier signals indicated that this was to be the case.

Items 135(1) and 135A(1) place a limit on the sales tax exemptions available for new motor vehicles. Sales tax exemptions under these items will be available only for motor vehicles with a wholesale sales value which is equal to or below the luxury motor vehicle threshold of $30,505. For the purpose of these calculations, the sale value is to be the value prior to any modifications required expressly to adapt the motor vehicle to enable the person specified to drive or to be transported in that vehicle. Thus, the limit on sales tax exemption places a cap--that is, a maximum sales tax benefit--on purchased vehicles covered by items 135 and 135A. This cap will be equivalent to the sales tax payable on a motor vehicle with a wholesale sales value equal to the luxury motor vehicle threshold.

I remind the Senate that in 1991-92 there will be a cap of $6,101, which is the tax payable at the rate of 20 per cent on a motor vehicle with a wholesale sale value of $30,505. Those persons who qualify under item 135(1) and item 135A(1) by buying a vehicle which has a wholesale sale value in excess of the luxury threshold will pay sales tax equal to 30 per cent of the wholesale sale value less the cap amount of $6,101. As a result of this amendment, the financial implications, as estimated by the Government, will be a revenue gain of $0.5m in a full year.

At its initial public hearing, the Commission received evidence from people with disabilities replacing their cars every two years. Using the sales tax exemption to offset the depreciation of the vehicles, they are able to exploit the concession. Thus, in the Commission's view, it saw increasing the period of exemption from two to four years as removing the opportunity to use the concession for unreasonable personal benefit.

The Government has chosen not to pursue this line in this Bill. I would be interested to learn whether it intends to pursue this line at all and its reasons for not pursuing it in this Bill. Many participants in the Industry Commission inquiry called for a broadening of the sales tax exemption to cover certain goods not specifically designed for people with disabilities but considered necessary to enable them to enjoy a more independent lifestyle.

Participants there argued that this is an unnecessary tax on people with disabilities, that it impacts most heavily on the lower income groups and that it deters people from acquiring goods which would make a significant difference to their independence or well-being by partly ameliorating the effect of their disability. For example, electric beds and hoists were said to be necessary for some people with disabilities, such as those suffering from motor neuron disease, but they are classified as general use goods for taxation purposes. A letter sent by the Australian Taxation Office to a Mrs Lindupp is quoted by the Commission. In its report the Commission states:

Although the Tormo electric adjustable bed offers therapeutic relief for people suffering from spinal problems and other body ailments, it is considered to be goods of a kind ordinarily used by persons not suffering from a disease or disablement. Accordingly, the Tormo electric adjustable bed is taxable . . .
The Lindupps appealed that decision but were told by the ATO that:

From the literature forwarded by your supplier, the product is designed to provide greater comfort for normally healthy people in addition to use by persons suffering from sickness, disease or disablement . . . Whilst the bed is distinguishable from a `normal' bed, the distinguishing characteristics--its adjustability--are not expressly designed for disabled people but rather to enhance the bed's general level of comfort--to provide more comfort, less stress, more relaxation and more versatility . . . Item 123 as it is worded is limited in its application by both the use of the word `expressly' in the context of the design and manufacture of the goods and by the qualification to exclude `goods of a kind ordinarily used by persons not suffering from sickness, disease or disablement'. Both of these factors preclude exemption applying to the Tormo bed.

It is not surprising then that the Industry Commission's third proposal suggested amending wording such that goods `designed and manufactured expressly for use by people with sickness, disease or disablement' had added to them `but occasionally used by others' and goods `not ordinarily used by persons who are not suffering from sickness, disease or disablement' be altered to read goods `of a kind predominantly used by persons with sickness, disease or disablement'.

The change of emphasis from comparing the use of goods by healthy people to those who are sick, diseased or disabled, would make a significant difference. Obviously, the Government also felt that there was some cause for change. Hence, in the Bill as originally proposed, paragraph 4(b) omits from subitem 123(1) the second part of a two-part test which goods had to pass in order for them to be included for tax exemption. However, I understand that proposed paragraph 4(b) is to be rescinded by a Government amendment due to a perceived wider impact than originally intended. As a result, this Bill will make no change at all to item 123.

The Commission's fourth and final proposal arose as a result of several participants requesting that computer equipment required to operate electronic communications aids be exempt from sales tax. These are costly items necessary for profoundly disabled people to ameliorate the effect of their disabilities. The Commission noted that most communications equipment which is specifically designed for people with disabilities is already exempt under item 123. Notwithstanding this fact, it recommended, firstly, limited extension to the list of goods eligible for sales tax exemption by adding, to item 123(1), computer equipment used as or in conjunction with electronic communications equipment where certification is provided by a doctor or a therapist. Secondly, it recommended that a time period should be specified during which the exemption may not be claimed again.

The equipment which the Commission recommended this exemption should cover included the computer and other items of related hardware such as the disk drive, the printer and the mouse. This recommendation has not been dealt with by the Government in this Bill. Yet again I seek from the Government's representative an indication whether it is its intention at some stage in the future to address this recommendation. No doubt my colleague Senator Patterson will further this argument.

One amendment which the Government has made in this Bill, without any recommendation from the Industry Commission but no doubt with some pushing from some other quarters, is to item 42C. Item 42C currently covers components or parts, such as special foot and hand controls, which are incorporated in a new or second-hand motor vehicle to permit it to be driven by somebody with a disability. It is conditional in that it applies only to goods for use in modifying vehicles. The effect of this Bill, if passed, will be to extend the exemption to include goods to be used in the modification of a motor vehicle solely for the purpose of adapting it for transporting a passenger suffering from a physical impairment. The example given in the explanatory memorandum states:

. . . an exemption would be available for a general purpose tailgate loader or hoist installed in the rear or the side of a second hand passenger van solely to allow access for a passenger in a wheelchair. Similarly, heavy duty springs and materials used to reinforce the floor of the van because of the additional weight would be exempt. Clamps and brackets fitted to the vehicle to hold the wheelchair in place would also be exempt.
The Government anticipates that this last amendment will come as a cost to revenue of $4m in a full year.

Any honourable senator who has familiarised himself or herself with the Aids and Appliances for People with Disabilities report and the associated correspondence which has been circulated with regard to this Bill, would be aware of the issue of sales tax exemption for the conversion of vehicles by taxi companies for transporting disabled persons. Despite this issue being discussed at length in the Industry Commission's report, no recommendations arose. It has been put to me that, as a result of this amendment to item 42C of the existing Bill, which will occur as a result of this legislation being passed, the cost of the modifications of vehicles to make them suitable to transport disabled people will now be sales tax exempt and that this exemption applies to vehicles such as taxis as well as to private vehicles. I therefore ask the Minister in charge of the Bill whether this is, in fact, the case. The net cost of the proposed changes in this Bill will be $3m for 1991-92 and $3.5m for a full year. The Bill is said to apply to any taxable dealing that occurs after 3 p.m. on 20 August 1991. The measures contained in this Bill are designed to remove a number of anomalies in the sales tax treatment of various goods and motor vehicles designed for people with disabilities. The measures are welcome in themselves in that they do improve the operation of a small area of what is, generally speaking, an extremely inefficient and discriminatory wholesale sales tax system. This Bill is only one of many tax Bills that, under this Government, we inevitably seem to pass each year in a vain effort to patch up a very unsatisfactory wholesale sales tax system, particularly in the area of exemption for people with disabilities.

The Commission noted that, for those exemptions that are conditional upon the type of buyer or on the number of items bought, the Australian Taxation Office's administrative costs and the private sector's compliance costs in observing these exemptions are extremely high. High compliance and collection costs are amongst the major problems associated with the wholesale sales tax system generally but more particularly with the income tax system.

The Industry Commission has also made the important point that sales tax exemptions are `not the optimum way to provide assistance to people with disabilities'. Direct cash assistance would be a far more efficient way to compensate people with special needs who are reliant on these goods. However, since we are stuck with the wholesale sales tax system under this Hawke Government, and this system is widely used for social welfare purposes, it is necessary to ensure that sales tax laws operate in the most equitable way possible for people with disabilities and those in other special circumstances.

What this Bill really does is to highlight the need for the wholesale sales tax system to be scrapped lock, stock and barrel and be replaced with a broadly based goods and services tax. The wholesale sales tax system has virtually become antiquated and an inefficient means of raising revenue. From our position in politics we recommend the approach of direct assistance that was put forward by the Industry Commission. I therefore move an in principle amendment to the motion for the second reading of this Bill in the following terms:

At end of motion, add ", but the Senate condemns the Government for its ramshackle and inefficient wholesale sales tax system, and its failure to replace it with a fairer, broad-based goods and services tax".

The Government has increased the amount of revenue raised through sales tax from $3.5 billion in 1982-83 to $9.4 billion last financial year. This figure would have been much higher had it not been for the recession, which has served to depress sales such that sales tax collections last year were down 7.6 per cent on the previous year.

The impact of the Government's sales tax grab on households has been particularly severe. Sales tax receipts under the Hawke Government have increased in real terms by 53 per cent per adult since 1982-83, the year it came into office. Of course, average weekly earnings have declined in real terms over that same period. Under the wholesale sales tax system, Australians are significantly worse off than they were in 1983.

The wholesale sales tax is a hidden consumption tax on the purchases by all Australians. Few consumers are aware of which goods are taxed under this system or at what rate they are taxed. Accordingly, sales tax was described by Tony Thomas in the Business Review Weekly some years ago as `the sneakiest weapon in Treasurer Paul Keating's arsenal'.

Sales taxes are levies on a narrow range of goods at three separate rates of 10 per cent, 20 per cent and 30 per cent. These differing rates apply to a small range of goods and severely distort production and consumption decisions, particularly because the commodity listings in the rates and exemptions schedules have failed to keep pace with changing consumer preferences. The fact that the Australian Taxation Office was asked to provide special schedules for the purposes of disabilities indicates the confusion in that area for people with disabilities.

Items that were once deemed luxuries and so worthy of a high rate of sales tax are now considered to be necessities for which Australian households are forced to pay through the nose. Although wholesale sales taxes are levies on only a small range of goods, many of these goods are everyday household items which make up a relatively large proportion of a family's weekly budget. Sales taxes are also levied in a highly inequitable way. For example, caviar, mineral water and oysters go untaxed while chocolate biscuits, soft drink and ice-cream are each taxed at one of the various sales tax rates.

The important point is that the trend under the Hawke Government has been for the operation of the wholesale sales tax regime to become even more inequitable, not fairer. Dr Neil Warren, from the University of New South Wales, has examined the changing incidence of Federal indirect taxes since 1975-76 in a paper prepared for the Economic Planning Advisory Council. His conclusions about the changes in the incidence of wholesale tax that have occurred since 1984-85--in other words, under this Government--are particularly damning. His paper concludes:
The changes to the wholesale sales tax appear to have increased the regressivity of this tax, both through changes to the effective rates of the tax and from changes in other factors.

This conclusion exposes the hypocrisy of the Government's scare campaign against the coalition's proposal for a broadly based goods and services tax. While the Government has been running around scaring little old ladies and others about the alleged inequities of a goods and services tax when it does not know the full details, it has been hitting those very same people with an alarmingly inequitable sales tax regime and has been significantly increasing sales tax collections year after year. The wholesale tax is also a major burden on Australian businesses which along with households are labouring under the effects of the recession. Sales tax falls heavily on goods that many businesses use in their production processes.

In a study entitled `A Broad-based Consumption Tax for Australia' conducted by the Centre of Policy Studies at Monash University, it has been estimated that nearly half of all sales tax is levied on intermediate business inputs. In other words, the wholesale sales tax is a significant addition to the costs faced by many businesses. Another 14 per cent is levied on sales of investment goods, adding to the cost of capital growth, while only 37 per cent is paid by final consumers.

The same report found that some 10 per cent of the final incidence of the wholesale sales tax, equivalent to about $9 billion, falls on goods for export. This translates into an average export tax of 2 per cent at a time when improved export performance has never been more important. The study concludes with this particular observation:

There is a general consensus that the wholesale sales tax system has also lost any economic merit it may once have had and remains only as a politically expedient but economically inefficient revenue raiser.
The Hawke Government stands condemned for ignoring the consensus against the wholesale sales tax system and in favour of a broadbased goods and services tax.

Every major business organisation one cares to name basically supports a broad based goods and services tax. There has not been a single major newspaper in Australia that has not, at some time in the last 12 months, editorialised in favour of a broad based goods and services tax. The Government deliberately ignores the massive weight of opinion behind the concept of a goods and services tax in favour of what it considers to be an opportunity to launch a shameless scare campaign at the next election and in the interim, based on our proposals for comprehensive tax reform. It is imperative that the wholesale sales tax system be scrapped as part of any attempt to reform the tax system in this country. The coalition is committed to a complete overhaul of the Australian taxation system as part of a much larger package of economic reforms which are designed to return Australia to sustainable economic growth over the longer term.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Bill 1991, which is before the Senate, provides a degree of recognition to the additional costs borne by people with disabilities. The most important benefit people with disabilities will derive from this Bill relates to the extension of the motor transport related exemption from wholesale sales tax.

SPEECH.PARA: Previously, the exemption for modifications was only applicable to those vehicles which were actually being driven by the person with the disability. This Bill will extend this exemption to motor vehicles used to transport people with disabilities. It will mean any modification made to a motor vehicle to be used to transport a person with a disability will be exempt from the payment of wholesale sales tax. My understanding of the Bill is that this exemption applies to the modification of commercially run motor vehicles, such as taxis, as well as privately used vehicles.

This Bill will also restrict the sales tax exemption available on the purchase of new motor vehicles for personal transportation of people with certain disabilities in certain circumstances. The total exemption will apply only to vehicles which have a sale value below that which the Government deems to be the sale value of a luxury vehicle. If the unmodified sale value of the vehicle is above the luxury vehicle sale value level of $30,505, which is indexed, two-thirds of the sale value of the vehicle up to the threshold will be exempt from the tax.

Previously, an open-ended wholesale sales tax exemption was available on the cost of motor vehicles used to transport certain veterans as well as people who had lost the use of one or both of their limbs. This open-ended exemption applied only in certain very specific circumstances and to certain specified disabilities. A veteran had to be totally and permanently incapacitated, to be blind or to have lost the use of a limb. If the person was not a veteran, he or she had to have lost the use of one or both legs and be unable to use public transport. In the case of a non-veteran, the exemption was available only if the vehicle was used to transport the person with the disability to or from that person's place of work.

The wholesale sales tax exemption on the cost of the vehicle, as it is being amended by this Bill, will still apply only in these specific circumstances. It will be available only for work related purposes for non-veterans. It will apply only to people with certain specified disabilities. The only change that is being made in relation to the wholesale sales tax exemption on the unmodified cost of vehicles used for the transport of people with disabilities involves the placing of a cap under which 100 per cent sales tax exemption will apply. This cap is set at a retail value of $45,462.

Originally, the Government sought to use this legislation to make a third amendment to the current wholesale sales tax treatment of people with disabilities. This amendment would have removed one of the two tests that a product which is designed and manufactured expressly for people with disabilities would have to satisfy if it were to attract a wholesale sales tax exemption. It would have removed the so-called second test, which required that the goods must not ordinarily be used by persons who are not suffering from sickness, disease or disablement. However, the Government has reneged on this amendment because it is concerned that the removal of the second test would have opened a Pandora's box of sales tax exemptions on everyday goods such as microwave ovens, televisions and fridges.

Obviously, the Opposition supports the thrust of the changes that the Government is making in this legislation. The Opposition has always contended that people with disabilities should be provided with real and tangible incentives that will assist them in establishing themselves and remaining actively involved in the community.

The Opposition has openly advocated the extension of the mobility allowance to areas of activity which are not related to employment. The coalition policy is based on the premise that people who have disabilities should be encouraged to participate fully in every facet of community life and not just employment. While the Opposition and I remain disappointed that the Government has not seen fit to extend the mobility allowance outside the employment arena, we applaud the increase in the allowance which accompanied the recently legislated disability reform package.

When debating this Bill it needs to be recognised that, just as the mobility allowance is a means of providing incentives for people with disabilities through the welfare system, these initiatives are examples of incentives that can be provided through the taxation system. As well as being positive incentives for people with disabilities, these initiatives also recognise the fact that the living expenses of a person with a disability are often higher than those of someone without a disability. Both the mobility allowance and these taxation incentives provide some recognition of the additional financial costs borne by people with disabilities in their employment.

While applauding the general thrust of these initiatives, I believe that this Bill raises two very important issues in the ongoing debate about government recognition of the needs of people with disabilities. The first is the vital issue of the extent to which government should subsidise the additional living expenses which emanate from a person's disability. In the last few years there has been the Cass report, the Ronalds report and the inquiry of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs, all of which have looked at the financial cost of disability. There is now a departmental inquiry looking at the same issue. From all of these reports, reviews and inquiries, as well as from the State-Commonwealth disability agreement that was signed on 1 July, I sincerely hope that the Government can find a sensible and coordinated approach to the treatment of the additional costs experienced by people with disabilities.

While this Bill is a step in the right direction, because it recognises some of these costs and provides a degree of incentive to people with disabilities, it does not resolve the central issue. For instance, it fails to resolve whether government subsidisation of the cost of disability should be widened to non-employment related expenses. I believe that the Australian Democrats will move an amendment to extend the wholesale sales tax exemption to vehicles used for reasons that are not employment related. While the coalition is sympathetic towards the wider recognition of the costs of disabilities, we cannot support this amendment because it is absolutely necessary to undertake a comprehensive assessment of the practical and financial implications before such an extension is supported.

The Bill fails to resolve the complex question of what financial benefits the Government should provide through the taxation system to businesses which offer their services to people with disabilities. An obvious example is the modified taxis that transport people with disabilities, particularly those who are restricted to wheelchairs. At present, the owners of these taxis receive no sales tax exemption for either the basic sale value of their vehicles or for any modifications made to them. It is quite valid to argue that these taxis offer a much needed community service to those people with disabilities who often cannot afford to own their own car.

With the onset of an ageing, more disabled society, this service will become more and more important. Its growing importance can be measured by the fact that all London taxis are now required to provide wheelchair access. On the other hand, we must also recognise the countervailing equity argument of whether commercial enterprises should be provided with preferential treatment by the Government simply because they manufacture a product or provide a service which is used by people with disabilities.

My understanding of the effect of this Bill is that the owners of modified taxis will now be able to claim a sales tax exemption on these modifications. To an extent, granting this exemption could set a precedent whereby any costs borne by an enterprise in modifying a product to suit the special needs of people with disabilities could be subsidised by government. I am not saying that that is a good or a bad thing, but it possibly sets a precedent.

The second major question that this Bill raises is whether the wholesale sales tax system is an appropriate and practical means through which the Government can recognise the additional expenses that are borne by people with disabilities. This Bill does not come to grips with the general question of whether goods that are manufactured specifically for and used by people with disabilities should attract a wholesale sales tax exemption under the sales tax Act.

In the 1990 report titled Aids and Appliances for People with Disabilities, the Industry Commission alluded to the problem of goods required by people with disabilities that are classified as `general use' goods for taxation purposes; for example, the Tormo electric adjustable bed. I will not go into the detail of that because my colleague Senator Watson outlined it most ably and in very great detail. The argument that is put forward to extend the sales tax exemption to the Tormo bed can be made in relation to items such as computers, as Senator Watson said, air conditioners and other equipment which is required by people with disabilities if they are to have the opportunity to lead a normal and fulfilling life.

In an attempt to solve the problems of people with disabilities not being able to claim important material aids such as the Tormo bed, the Government sought to do away with the sales tax Act requirement that goods must not ordinarily be used by people with disabilities. However, it has now reneged on this proposal because of the loopholes that it would have opened up. By maintaining the status quo, the Government has refused to recognise that many items which may be considered luxury items for people without a disability may well be necessities for someone who has a disability.

By dropping the amendment, the Government has admitted that it is unable to solve this problem by way of the current ramshackle wholesale sales tax system except by opening up another myriad of anomalies and inequities. The clear message from the Government's back-down on the removal of this exemption requirement is that the unfair, anomalous and unintelligible wholesale sales tax system is not an appropriate mechanism through which to recognise the additional cost borne by people with disabilities. Thankfully, this silent tax, to which Senator Watson referred and which has crept up on unsuspecting Australians and increased almost threefold since 1983 to $10 billion, would be abolished by the coalition.

This is a matter that is not talked about. Labor mentions the imposition of a goods and services tax, but those opposite do not mention a reduction in personal income tax and the abolition of a wholesale sales tax, or ways of ensuring that people in lower income brackets, on fixed incomes or in receipt of welfare will not be disadvantaged. None of those things is talked about. We hear only that there will be another tax--not about tax reform in toto. Fortunately, after the next election this ramshackle wholesale sales tax will disappear and a more equitable and just tax system will be put in place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Today we are debating the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1991. Once more the Senate participates in the annual ritual following a Federal Budget of tinkering with our outdated, unjust form of consumption tax--the wholesale sales tax. It is true that this year we are simply ratifying a very minor and generally beneficial adjustment, but the significance of the Bill lies in the fact that it changes so little.

SPEECH.PARA: We were very hopeful that the Government would take up some of the issues that we have now been raising for many months about the punitive nature of the wholesale sales tax, the tax on exports and the tax on business inputs. But the Government has refused to bite the bullet and has taken the soft option. The coalition is not opposed to the exemption from sales tax of a range of goods purchased by disabled Australians. However, we register our opposition to a system that is subject to continual adjustment in legislation and where, once again, the Hawke Labor Government has avoided necessary reform. It is at times like this that we should all remember the words of the former Treasurer on 5 June 1985:

It is now well recognised that the Australian tax system is unfair. It is also widely appreciated that it encourages inefficiency and is extraordinarily complex. Clearly there is a need for action: for reform.

That was said by the then Treasurer, Mr Keating. He claimed that the current taxation system was unfair, that it needed reform, that it was inefficient and extraordinarily complex. We have agreed--and for nearly two years now Dr Hewson has offered this Government bipartisan support to reform the tax system, to take away the unfairness, to clear up the inconsistencies and inefficiencies and to make it less complex--that we should have a real reform package. But this Government has walked away from that offer time and again. Obviously, it is up to the coalition to do it and to do it on its own, and to make sure that Australia has a tax system that the former Treasurer was hoping for on 5 June 1985.

With regard to the former Treasurer's wonderful words back in 1985, the rest is history. The Hawke Labor Government missed its own declared opportunity for reform of indirect tax in 1985 and will now resort to cheap politicking. It was the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) who in February 1985 said that income tax marginal rates were too high, that they created disincentive and must be brought down through `a substantial increase in indirect taxation'. Of course, he has done that: he has increased dramatically the indirect taxation system.

The other component of dramatically reducing levels of personal income tax has not been brought about. He has the bonus of increasing the hidden consumption tax, the wholesale sales tax system, but he has not given one cent to the hardworking PAYE taxpayer and he has not given any compensation packages to those on welfare. But, as my colleague Senator Patterson said a moment ago, the Government has had the temerity to have sales tax at the level of nearly $10 billion a year. But has this Government given any compensation to anybody? The answer is no.

Before somebody from the Government side of the Senate has the gall to say that certain levels of personal income tax have been reduced, let me make the point crystal clear that those opposite cannot have it both ways. They cannot say that they have given reductions in personal levels of income tax to offset the dramatic increases in sales tax and then also say that they agreed to those reductions in personal levels of income tax in lieu of wage increases--another grubby little deal done with the ACTU and Mr Kelty.

TALK.START.PARA: —-You are just being spiteful. Say something nice about us for a change.

—-Senator Bolkus can only have it one way; he cannot have it both ways. Did this Government decrease personal income tax levels as a trade-off for wage increases or to offset the increased burdens of wholesale sales tax? Senator Bolkus does not know the answer because he is tax illiterate, but that is understandable. It is now more than six years since the Prime Minister said that personal levels of income tax had to be reduced, and over three million taxpayers are paying marginal rates of 38 per cent or more once they earn more than the princely sum of $20,700 a year.

SPEECH.PARA: It was not so many years ago that before taxpayers paid the top marginal rate of income tax they had to be earning some 14 times average weekly earnings. But now people have to earn only about 1 1/2 times average weekly earnings before they are on the top marginal rate of taxation. Surely that indicates that there is something wrong with Australia's tax system.

Australians are also spending between $2.8 billion and $3.8 billion just for the compliance costs of personal income tax, as much as 11 per cent of total revenue, yet this legislation reminds us that in one respect the Prime Minister did carry through his undertaking in February 1985 by making sure that we all paid far more indirect tax. Since this Government came to office, its receipts from wholesale sales tax have risen dramatically. Unreformed sales tax, because of its lack of visibility and the comparative ease of legislative manipulation, has been a valuable source of revenue at the expense of the economic health of Australia.

This Government and the media have the audacity to say to us, `Will you give a commitment never to increase the goods and services tax once you bring it in?'. Members of the Government never ask themselves, and the media never asks this Government, `Will you never increase the wholesale sales tax system again, as you have done over the past eight years?'. Up until the last Budget the Labor Government had increased it by 206 per cent. An increase of 206 per cent in hidden consumption taxes is a fair increase, yet those opposite still say to us, `Will you ever increase it?'. The difference is that, if ever we increase the goods and services tax by 0.1 of a percentage point, the whole world will know about it. The Labor Government has managed to increase it, up to the last Budget, by 206 per cent and virtually no-one has known about it. Most in the Australian community still do not know what they are paying in hidden consumption taxes. This Government has been able to increase it on many goods that were previously untaxed, and still members of the community do not know about it. Why does this Government not come up front and say, `We also will do what the Prime Minister and the Treasurer said back in 1985: we will have a fair tax system and take away the inefficiencies and complexities'?

In considering this Bill, we should take note of the Budget Papers as they concern sales tax. As I said before, it is a fact that receipts for 1990-91 total $9.4 billion rather than the projected $10.6 billion from last year. It is highly significant that, among the reasons given for reduced sales of goods, a clear indication of the effects of the recession we had to have is a shift away from items on which 30 per cent tax is paid, because people simply have not been able to afford to buy goods. The recession has hit the purchasing power of ordinary Australians and they simply have not been able to buy the goods they would otherwise have bought. Another reason given is the failure of the 1990-91 experiment of a 50 per cent punitive rate on luxury vehicles. We said from the word go that it would not work, and it did not work. Such a manipulation of indirect taxation is ultimately self-defeating in its effect on revenue.

While this Labor Government continues to oppose the reform of indirect taxation, $5 billion continues to be paid on business inputs. The Government had opportunities in the March statement and in the August Budget to review the huge cost of $5 billion on business inputs, but it has chosen not to do so. Australians are entitled to ask: how deep is Labor's commitment to economic recovery and export growth with exports carrying a sales tax burden of $1 billion per annum? The Government had an opportunity to change that and has walked away from it.

Our trading partners do not have such an imposition on their exports. Is it any wonder that we are not competitive? Is it any wonder that our balance of payments continues to be a problem, that we are importing more than we are exporting? This Government is determined to make sure that it imposes its hidden consumption tax on exports to the tune of $1 billion. Under a coalition government, the taxes on both business inputs and exports would be removed along with the wholesale sales tax. They would be replaced by a broad-based goods and services tax. Business would be able to flourish. Exports without a tax attached to them would be more attractive to overseas buyers.

Telecom, an institution that Labor professes to support, paid $375m as a conservative estimate in sales tax on its capital equipment purchases in 1990-91, including $346m on plant and equipment and $24m on motor vehicles. Under the coalition's goods and services alternative, the goods and services tax that replaces the sales tax paid on such equipment will be rebatable; thus, the consumer will no longer be picking up the hidden tab for $375m, amounting to $50 a year for Telecom's eight million subscribers. Every subscriber of Telecom pays an additional $50 just to cover the cost of sales taxes paid by Telecom.

We hear enough from the Australian Labor Party about those who are supposedly evading tax, but in one more Budget it does nothing to combat the cash economy, estimated at $40 billion, through the means of a broad-based goods and services tax such as the one the coalition is advocating. Labor periodically tries to convince us that it cares about small business, yet once again it leaves in place a sales tax designed for administration by larger business. Business pays the price of holding costs for stock on which sales tax must be paid. Having come from the business sector, I know what an impost that is.

When one buys goods and 21 days later has to pay the sales tax on them, invariably one has to borrow the money to buy the goods in the first place. Many companies borrow the money to pay the sales tax, and they are paying interest on the borrowings for both. The goods may well sit in the warehouse for many months, not sold, but business has already paid the sales tax and the Government already has its money. That would all change under a coalition government. The coalition would have businesses at least buy their products, sell them and collect the tax before they had to remit it to the Government. Businesses would have collected much of the tax before their returns were necessary.

In contrast, the goods and services tax of the Liberal and National parties will give business a positive cash flow advantage through the lag between collection of the goods and services tax and the submission of returns. We have just seen an example of wishful or, one might say, muddled thinking by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) when he told Parliament that sedans and motorcycles used primarily in farming were sales tax exempt.

TALK.START.PARA: —-He does not know what he is talking about.

—-That is exactly right. As my colleague Senator Panizza says, he would not have the faintest idea of what he was talking about. Most farmers would say, `If only it were true'. Only certain four-wheel drives and specialist bikes are exempt. The fact is that most necessary items used on farms, such as vehicles, are not manufactured specifically for agriculture and are therefore taxable. Only this idiotic system of sales tax would exempt a chainsaw from sales tax if it were to be used only for cutting fence posts and not for clearing fallen timber. There is another anomaly, just like the other crazy anomalies at the moment whereby a pornographic magazine can be tax-exempt, yet 20 per cent has to be paid for a baby's teething ring. How much more absurd does the situation have to get?
