SPEECH.PARA: The coalition is glad that disabled Australians will pay less for some necessary items under this Bill, but I remind the Senate that this Bill and the whole Budget will still result in Australians paying 30 per cent tax on television sets; 20 per cent on tool boxes, cassettes, talcum powder, detergent, pet food, tourist maps, bicycles and aluminium foil; and 10 per cent on all household furniture, toasters, cutlery, linen and bathroom fittings. This is from a government that says that we do not have a consumption tax. It is rot!

We have the most insidious form of consumption tax, which goes on and on and spreads its tentacles throughout the whole community. The selection is totally random, but what all these items have in common is that they are necessities to a great cross-section of Australian families. Indeed, 72 per cent of the gross sales of goods subject to sales tax is at the 20 per cent rate. In 1989-90, Western Australians paid $400 per head in sales tax, a contribution of $650m to tax revenue. That is in addition to their super-high levels of personal income tax. Of this, $211m was collected on vehicles and parts; $42m on machinery; $34m on building materials and tools; $35m on furniture; and $25m on household appliances and furnishings. This all comes from a government that says that we do not have a consumption tax, but we do. It is known as the wholesale sales tax.

Even those foodstuffs on which sales tax is not directly paid have their price affected by its application to the transport system that delivers them and the packaging around them. Even so minor an alternation to the sales tax as in this Bill is another reminder that Australia is overdue for indirect tax reform and a change towards consistency and logic. It is absurd for this Government to say that the less well-off will be worst hit under a goods and services tax.

The more well-off people can quite easily get on a plane, travel first-class to anywhere in Australia and not pay tax. They can stay in five-star accommodation and not pay tax. They can go for a harbour cruise and not pay tax. They can go to the opera and not pay tax. They can have a wonderful meal at a gold plate restaurant and not pay tax. But a less well-off guy buys a motor vehicle and pays 30 per cent tax. If he buys a four-wheel drive, he will probably pay 40 per cent tax. If he buys a caravan, he will pay 30 per cent tax. The tyres have a tax of 30 per cent on them. If the television is his form of entertainment and not the opera, he pays 30 per cent on that. Instead of having a meal at a gold plate restaurant and paying no tax, he will sit in front of his television with a can of Coke, on which there is a 10 per cent tax, and a bag of potato crisps, on which there is another 10 per cent tax.

Is it right that we do not have a consumption tax at the moment? No, it is not. It is about time this tax system was reformed and that Australia had an opportunity to have a fair and equitable tax system that makes sure that all Australians pay less tax and that it is not just the PAYE taxpayers who are hounded to the ground.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill proposes to implement some sales tax decisions announced in the Budget. There were originally three matters dealt with in the Bill which concern the exemptions available to disabled people in respect of goods used in modifications of motor vehicles to transport disabled people, goods designed and manufactured expressly for people with disabilities, and new motor vehicles purchased by disabled people. However, the Government amended the Bill in the other place to remove the proposed modification to subitem 123(1), which is the general exemption provision for goods designed and manufactured expressly for people with disabilities. I will return to this matter later.

SPEECH.PARA: Currently, an exemption is available for goods used to modify a motor vehicle for driving by a disabled person. The law is to be liberalised by allowing an exemption for goods used to modify a motor vehicle to transport a disabled person. This is a very worthwhile initiative and it has the full support of the Australian Democrats. In addition, the Bill proposes to exempt from tax that part of the value of a motor vehicle purchased by a disabled person or veteran which relates to modifications made to the car to transport the disabled person. The Australian Democrats strongly agree with this measure but think that it should be extended. Again, I will be moving some amendments to achieve this in the committee stage of this debate.

The second amendment that I will be moving deals with the modification of motor vehicles to transport disabled people. The Bill does address this topic, but only in a limited way. The Bill exempts from sales tax the goods used to modify a motor vehicle for disabled people. We completely agree with this provision, and I think support for it is unanimous in this chamber. However, where a significant structural alteration is made to a motor vehicle, that process is considered to be manufacturing and is therefore subject to sales tax at the rate of 20 per cent. Senator Patterson, who spoke earlier on this Bill, stated that she believed that modifications such as those made to taxis by firms such as SPV were to be made exempt by this Bill. I do not believe this is correct. I am not criticising her for saying that; this is a particularly complex law.

There is no doubt that serious structural alterations of cars to allow for the transportation of disabled people are taxable at 20 per cent and that tax applies to both the goods used in the modification and the labour and other costs associated with the modification. This has been confirmed to me by Australian Taxation Office staff. Indeed, the Taxation Office treats such modifications relatively generously by imposing sales tax only on the value of the modifications made instead of on the total value of the modified motor vehicle. I commend the Tax Office for this approach. However, we believe that such modifications should be exempt from sales tax altogether. It appears that the Opposition agrees with this exemption and that it may have misunderstood the actual situation. I ask Senator McMullan to confirm this for the record.

We also thought that such modifications were all to be made exempt by this legislation, although we now know that further amendments are needed. Paragraph (3) of subclause 4(c) of the legislation provides an exemption only for modifications to vehicles to which items 135 and 135A of the first schedule apply; that is, no exemption is available to a taxi company which modifies its vehicles in this manner. I ask Senator McMullan to confirm this for the record as well.

My second amendment also contains a related proposal to insert into the principal Act a new section 6AG, which will exempt from tax altogether a motor vehicle which has been modified for transporting disabled people where the cost of such modification exceeds the tax that otherwise would have been payable on the new motor vehicle if that new vehicle had not been modified.

It has not been possible for us to cost the two proposals contained in our second amendment, but we think they would be minimal--probably less than $1m per year. There is no way that they can be rorted by the general public. I apologise for the fact that our amendments have not yet been distributed. There are some obvious reasons why this has happened. The Opposition might like to move for an adjournment of the debate to give it time to consider our proposals, because I think it misunderstood the legislation.

Interestingly, the suggestions concerning the broadening of the existing exemptions came from the Government. They were not amongst the recommendations of the Industry Commission Inquiry into Aids and Appliances for People with Disabilities. The amendments address the fundamental question for disabled people, and that is one of access to transportation. It is this principle which should be paramount in all our law making in the area of tax concessions for the disabled. This is why I am again putting forward a further amendment to the existing exemption provision, which I will deal with more fully in the committee stage. The amendment proposes to remove the current limitation that disabled people may buy a car exempt from sales tax only if they use that car to get to and from work. The other amendment in the Bill seeks to limit the currently unlimited exemption which applies to the purchase of new motor vehicles by certain disabled people. Item 135 provides an exemption for the purchase of cars used by veterans who have lost the use of an arm and a leg or both arms.

Item 135A provides an exemption for the purchase of cars for transport to and from work for disabled people who are not able to use public transport. The Bill proposes to limit the exemption to those cars which are non-luxury; that is, those with a retail value below $45,000. This appears to us a reasonable proposition. There is justification for the Government to assist disadvantaged people with access to services such as cheaper transport but not to luxury services. However, we would argue that all tax exemptions on new car purchases should be examined using a similar criterion.

There are a variety of organisations which are still entitled to unlimited sales tax exemptions, such as universities, Commonwealth, State and local government departments and the Reserve Bank. The Australian Democrats believe that these exemptions should be retained, but we believe that they should be similar to those proposed for disabled people; that is, the other organisations currently entitled to an unlimited exemption should also be subject to an exemption cap in respect of luxury motor vehicles. This exemption is currently valued at $6,106. This should boost the non-luxury car market, the bulk of which is supplied by local industry.

The Industry Commission report dealt with a large number of issues apart from sales tax, such as an exemption from import duty for wheelchairs, which the Government implemented on 1 January 1991. The report's recommendations are slightly different from the Government's proposals. Firstly, the Commission recommended that a further sales tax exemption be granted in respect of certain communication equipment purchased by disabled people. This has not been acted on by the Government because it claims the proposal was too imprecise and that the target group was not sufficiently well identified by the Industry Commission. It has not been rejected by the Government but it has been referred to the disability task force for further consideration. I ask Senator McMullan to inform the Senate what progress, if any, has been made in respect of this matter.

Secondly, the Commission recommended that the exemption for luxury vehicles be terminated completely, whereas a fixed rate of exemption of over $6,000 is proposed for future luxury vehicle purchases. That is, the Bill is much more generous in its treatment of a luxury car purchase than the Industry Commission recommended. The reason for this departure has not been adequately explained by the Government.

Another recommendation by the Industry Commission was to alter the existing practice of allowing a disabled person or veteran to purchase a motor vehicle exempt from sales tax every two years to allowing an exemption only every four years. Whilst we are not advocating the proposal, the Government has not explained why this recommendation was rejected.

The Commission also recommended an alteration to the wording of the general exemption for goods designed and manufactured especially for disabled people. This was picked up by the Government. However, the proposed amendment to subitem 123(1) was removed from the Bill. The Government has apparently been advised that a significant loophole would have been created if the proposed amendment had been proceeded with. The Australian Democrats have previously moved an amendment to achieve this objective, and we are concerned that the existing provision is still too complex and too restrictive in its application. Again, I ask Senator McMullan to explain what further action the Government intends to take to rectify this problem.

The reaction to the Budget announcements from the disabled groups within the community was very positive. Disabled Peoples International (Australia) congratulated the Government on the Budget initiatives. It is disappointed at the Government's amendment, which maintains the status quo. However, it expressed concern that an exemption that is designed to benefit people with disabilities should not be abused and should not be available to people without disabilities.

One method of tackling the problem of modifying goods to gain exemption would be to introduce a general anti-avoidance provision into the sales tax legislation. This has been a longstanding policy of the Australian Democrats, and I hope the Government will consider this in its review of the tax. Such a measure would also attack other tax minimisation schemes and would yield significant revenue to the Government. The Australian Democrats support this legislation, although we propose to try to improve upon it in the committee stage.

I also refer to the Opposition's second reading amendment, which calls upon the Senate to condemn the Government for the existing wholesale sales tax system and to introduce a goods and services tax. There is a real inconsistency here. The Bill deals with amendments to exemptions from sales tax, exemptions that exist to assist the most vulnerable people in the community. The Opposition supports this legislation, yet it will not be providing any exemptions in its proposed new tax, and that is the inconsistency.

TALK.START.PARA: —-How do you know? You wouldn't know.

—-Tell us; please tell us. The preferential treatment of disabled people under the wholesale sales tax is one reason why we do not support the Opposition's policy of a flat rate tax with no exemptions. There are, of course, other reasons, but that is enough in the context of this Bill for us to reject the second reading amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: In summary, the Australian Democrats totally support this legislation. However, we feel that once again the Government has not gone far enough in assisting disabled members of our community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I support my colleagues who have spoken on the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill, which deals with exemptions for vehicles altered for disabled people, a measure the coalition supports. With regard to the so-called luxury tax threshold, I should like Senator Kernot to define a luxury vehicle. No-one else seems to know what it is. The Government set a level of $30,505 wholesale or $45,462 retail above which anything would be classed as a luxury vehicle. However, there is no definition of a luxury vehicle. There is merely a 30 per cent sales tax on any vehicle above the $30,505 wholesale price.

SPEECH.PARA: During the last election campaign, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) introduced on the run a super-jealousy sales tax of 50 per cent on those vehicles to finance the black spots, as they are known, on roads, mainly in New South Wales. The Government saw the folly of its ways because, rather than increasing its sales tax take, that measure decreased it. So the Government made the best of a bad job and eliminated that tax some time ago.

What is a luxury vehicle? Other vehicles, whether passenger vehicles, utilities or trucks, are taxed at 20 per cent. I believe that this is an additional tax. Why should a car worth $30,505 attract a higher rate of tax? I wish someone could define such a vehicle. Aside from the jealousy tax aspect, all I can see is that it is a tax on high class engineering. The better engineered cars, that is, those cars that are safer in a roll-over or whatever, tend to be in that price of over $30,000 wholesale or $45,000 retail.

Four-wheel drive vehicles are necessary in remote areas. I do not know of a decent four-wheel drive passenger vehicle that comes in at much under $45,000. It is a necessity; it is a safety vehicle, yet it attracts a 30 per cent tax. I cannot understand it. This is a tax on safety. The Government imposed it as a jealousy measure, but no-one has explained the reason for keeping that tax differential.

Unless my memory fails me, quite a few other sales tax measures that were announced in the March statement have not seen the light of day. I should like the Government to inform me when those measures will come through. The Government got the kudos for what it said in that March statement it was going to do, but a lot of the legislation seems to have been forgotten. I believe that sales tax is the wrong way to go. The goods and services tax would be a better way to go.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Hear, hear!

—-Senator Brownhill is well aware of the situation in country areas, where four-wheel drive vehicles are needed for safety. I believe that they are needed for safety even in the high density traffic of Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide or Perth, but particularly in the bush. However, if one tries to set oneself up in a safety mode, one is taxed.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Kernot mentioned early in her speech that the Australian Democrats believe that there should be a cap on the threshold for sales tax exempt vehicles. There are a lot of categories where sales tax on vehicles can be exempt, including exemptions for persons who are incapacitated, exemptions for schools and universities, as Senator Kernot pointed out, and exemptions for bodies such as the Reserve Bank of Australia and public transport authorities. To the present moment I have no argument with this, but it may be different under a goods and services tax. But she was saying that we had to have a cap on some. I presume that she meant the cap of $45,000. These exempt ones, or the ones which may be exempt, are mainly used in agriculture and in mining. They are the ones.

How can anyone tell me that one can have for use in a mining site a reasonable sort of four-wheel drive vehicle that comes under that figure? If one needs a four-wheel drive on a mining site or a pastoral lease it has to be a substantial vehicle. Is a person then going to get under that threshold and not pay sales tax by running a two-wheel drive Commodore utility around the mine site? I wish the Australian Democrats would answer this question.

More so, I wish they would tell the mining, pastoral and agricultural industries exactly what they mean by that statement. It is all very well to make a bland statement that there should be a cap on the allowable sales tax exemptions on vehicles. One just cannot buy under that cap a decent vehicle that will stand up to the rigours of a mining site, a pastoral lease or a farm developed 100 years, for that matter. One would only get a toy in its place. I wish the Democrats would tell those industries exactly what they mean.
As I said, I believe the goods and services tax is the only way to go. At least it is straightforward and is at one rate. Everyone knows how it is going and what it is on.

Senator Watson, Senator Knowles and Senator Patterson very ably pointed out the advantages of the goods and services tax as against the out of kilter sales tax. We need a total reform of the tax regime if we want to get Australia moving again. We know that, despite the balance of trade figures trotted out the other day by the Government which tell us we are out of the recession. Are we out of the recession just because exports went by up one per cent? The balance of trade figures look better because the Government has removed any hope the Australian consumer has of being able to afford to pay for any imported goods. If one looks at those figures more closely, one will find out that non-importation in the month of August was because machinery used in the transport and resource sectors, the mining sector, was not imported because we cannot afford the machinery. This Government will not allow resources to get off the ground to use that machinery.

I know I have digressed a bit, Mr Deputy President, but that is the situation. We need a total tax reform if Australia is to get moving again. To the uninitiated, those balance of trade figures may look very well on paper, but do they stand up to scrutiny?
I believe the sales tax is in its dying days. Senator Bishop would agree with me that at the most it has about 18 months to go.

TALK.START.PARA: —-That's about it.

—-That is about it. It has about 18 months to go; similarly, many of the remnants of the Democrats in this place have about 18 months to go. They have gone out and told the world before they have seen a tax package that they are going to oppose it. This is what the Democrats have been telling Australians, hoping to pick up votes. They might pick votes up in certain areas but not out in those main industries that keep Australia going. The mining, farming and fishing industries are the ones which are keeping Australia going and they will at least hold it from sinking altogether until a different government turns Australia around.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said before, sales tax is in its dying days. I believe this Government is also in its dying days if that is all it can give us by way of a tax reform.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill probably epitomises the problems that lie with the whole of the wholesale sales tax system which we call, and I call, `the Government's own GST; the Government's secret tax'.

SPEECH.PARA: Here we have it, a two-page Bill. To accompany it, we have a 12-page explanatory memorandum. Not only that, we have a supplementary explanatory memorandum. In other words, what is set out to be supposedly a simple amendment to a very complex form of legislation has pages and pages to attempt to explain what is meant by the Bill itself.

Is it any wonder then that we have hundreds of public servants who spend all day every day trying to deliberate upon what is meant by things that are covered, things that are exempt and whether it does or does not fit a category? Indeed, when one reads exactly what the Bill says, one realises what a complicated, illogical and inequitable form of taxation it is.

Let us take a look at some of the things that it says. It says that currently many cars are taxed at a 20 per cent rate under the fourth and fifth schedules of the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act 1935. Then there are those vehicles classified under subitem 61(1) of the second schedule which are luxury vehicles and are subject to a 30 per cent rate. The threshold for what is a luxury vehicle is determined by a formula, set out in 61(2) of the second schedule. But it does not end there. This formula is determined with reference to the current motor vehicle depreciation limits under section 57AF of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. Once that calculation occurs, those vehicles exceeding the threshold are subject to a 30 per cent sales tax, while those vehicles below or equal to the threshold attract a 20 per cent rate.

One could be forgiven for saying that that sounds pretty much like gobbledegook. But it gets worse. There are exemptions for those vehicles above the threshold and thus attracting the 30 per cent rate. Subitem 61(3) of the second schedule provides that subitem 61(1) does not apply to vehicles specially fitted out for transporting people with disabilities while seated in wheelchairs.

Then, to complicate this further, there are the changes that are brought about by the Bill itself. Clause 3 of the Bill inserts a new 6AE in the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act to provide that sales tax is not payable on a proportion of the sale value of certain motor vehicles for people with disabilities. Clear?

Clause 4(c) of the Bill amends items 135 and 135A of the first schedule to provide new paragraphs which provide that the exemption is no longer available for vehicles above the threshold. For these purposes the sales value will be reduced by the value of certain modifications to enable a person with a disability to drive or be transported in the vehicle.

Finally, clause 5 amends subitem 61(3) of the second schedule to apply the same treatment to motor vehicles specifically fitted out for transporting disabled persons while seated in wheelchairs where those vehicles are in use by certain veterans and the disabled.
Pardon me for reading that diatribe on the complexities of the Bill, but expecting the ordinary citizen to comprehend that and then apply it in a logical or equitable manner is asking too much.

Such is the complexity of legislation, which raises $10 billion a year out of $90 billion raised by way of taxation revenue. But the really staggering figure is that we raise $50 billion of the $90 billion by way of personal income tax--right out of the taxpayer's pocket. It comes out at source, with the exception of those poor people who have to pay provisional tax when the tax man usually gets the benefit of the taxpayers' money for 12 months before he deigns to give it back as a refund at the end of the year. Quite clearly, the tax mix is wrong. Quite clearly, the incentives to save are negative and the incentives to spend are positive. Quite clearly, there is a need to move away from direct taxation and towards indirect taxation, but by a fair, equitable and clearly understood method.

Our proposals are about tax reform: to lessen the amount of direct income tax that is paid and to use more fairly and equitably an indirect tax, which we call a goods and services tax. But first we would abolish the cumbersome wholesale sales tax. It is interesting to look at the evidence that we gleaned from the Estimates Committee hearings. When the Department of the Treasury appeared before Estimates Committee A--we are yet to have the joy of the Australian Taxation Office--we discovered two things. On the instruction of the Treasurer (Mr Kerin), the Treasury has developed a model. It is a model through which it can test the costs which the Opposition says are associated with the goods and services tax, and how it will impact upon the economy. In other words, the Treasury admitted to Senate Estimates Committee A that it was constructing a model for party political purposes.

TALK.START.PARA: —-You are just too dumb to understand what they really said. If you understood English you would know that wasn't what they said.

—- When the Opposition is working out its figures we pay consultants to work on them; we do not have the ability to order good, honest, toiling public servants to use their talents to perform party political tasks which ought to be paid for by the Labor Party.
—-That is not what they said. You understood that was not what they said.

—-That is exactly what they said. Furthermore, it may well be because they felt incensed that they are being made to do paid party political work that, when I asked for all the reports which had been commissioned by the Tax Office into the wholesale sales tax--surprise, surprise--I actually got them. That was a truly memorable occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: Having ascertained that the Australian Tax Office had spent some $5m of taxpayers' money on consultancy fees in the last financial year, and having ascertained that one report by Quantum Market Research--which was a survey--cost $75,497, when I read the report I found that in it there was evidence which indeed showed that the only way to solve the taxation problems of this economy was to move to a broad-based consumption tax. I will read from that report. It said:

There appears to be a range of complexities and rulings which make compliance with the sales tax laws quite difficult. It was in this context that a number of respondents during the initial research stage saw the ultimate solution as being the introduction of a consumption tax rather than a modification of the current system.

It went on further to say that nearly one-third of survey respondents were experiencing at least some degree of difficulty with compliance under the sales tax system. It said that the major causes of difficulty associated with compliance were difficulties in determining the appropriate calculations to be made and the level of taxes paid, given variable rates and exemptions; rules which were seen to be confusing, difficult to follow, hard to understand and overcomplicated; imprecision in tax guidelines; difficulties experienced in obtaining sales tax exemptions; and the time and paperwork associated with compliance under the system.

When asked to comment on particular problems with the sales tax system, respondents again referred to the matters listed above and, in addition, mentioned problems associated with the timing of the tax payments in relation to cash flow. In other words, when retailers were obliged to pay the wholesale sales tax it was often the case that they had to go to the bank to get a loan--on which they paid high interest rates, forced upon this economy by this Government--in order to pay their tax. They would not get that money back until they finally made a sale for the particular goods on which tax was incurred.

On the other hand, our value added type of system would mean that those same retailers would be able to get a refund of the tax that had been paid at the previous level up front, irrespective of when or if they finally sold that particular item. In other words, to small business it will mean an increase in cash flow--a direct benefit to the small business sector.

But no doubt Mr Secretary will come back and say that somehow I have misinterpreted this report for which the taxpayers have paid $75,000. Indeed, when Mr Secretary attempts to use that curious argument--and we will have an opportunity to look at it more thoroughly on Friday--we will be able to analyse just why he thinks he is able to spend $75,000 of taxpayers' money and then treat it with contempt. In other words, if it does not suit the Government's political purposes, the money is deemed wasted. That is the way this Government responds.

The final details of the survey will help us to understand. The survey was mailed to 3,900 people and 964 interviews were conducted. The survey was across all sections of business: 42 per cent were small businesses employing fewer than five employees, 41 per cent employed between five and 20 employees, and 17 per cent employed more than 20 employees. Overall, 73 per cent were family concerns. The survey came in two parts: qualitative and quantitative. When asked whether they felt that the taxation system worked equally across all types of business, nearly half--45 per cent--of respondents said this was not the case, 26 per cent declined to comment, and only 29 per cent felt that the tax system was working with equity.

I remind Mr Secretary that of those surveyed only 29 per cent of people--less than one-third--felt that the current tax regime was equitable. Those involved in retailing were relatively strong in their belief that some businesses were being disadvantaged. The survey further found that the major area of commitment was to a perceived disadvantage of small business versus large companies, particularly in their access to professional advice on tax minimisation. It is well to remember that when that interesting document, the tax guide, was first published the number of people who used, or were forced to use, a tax agent rose to 70 per cent. In other words, many taxpayers took one look at the tax guide and it frightened them to death. They went straight off to their tax agent.

Quite clearly, the cost of the need for complicated legal and accounting advice adds to the overall cost of doing business. The survey further found that larger businesses could afford expert advice on tax matters. On the other hand, the impact on small businesses was primarily negative in terms of cash flow, time involvement and incentive to effort. The survey stated finally that, `The real solution to the complexities is the introduction of a consumption tax'. That was most important information revealed by the Australian Taxation Office.

There are many and varied reasons why it is necessary to have tax reform. Our package seeks to reduce the rate of marginal tax rates--that is, reduce the dependency on direct taxation--and abolish the wholesale sales tax and replace it with the goods and services tax, understanding that there is now a tax component in every item we deal with. If one averages it out one will find that it is about 7 per cent on every transaction. Even in baby food and bread there is a tax component, because only things which are an aid to manufacture--as defined by rulings of the Tax Commissioner--are exempt. Once they get into the transportation and wholesaling areas they are no longer exempt.

So the fork-lift that might be tax-exempt in the baby food factory has tax paid on it when it is in the warehouse moving the same baby food around for purposes of transportation. The baby food is moved in a truck which has wholesale sales tax paid on it and the truck is filled with petrol on which excise is paid. There is no such thing as an item with no tax component. The only thing is that people have not known it. Therefore, before we bring down the final details of our package, it has been necessary to let the electorate know that it is already paying the Government's secret tax.

I want to make a point about why it has taken so long, in some people's view, for us to get the details of our package released. Let us take a look at what material we have to work with. I have already said that we do not have access to the Treasury and to use public servants for paid party political purposes. We have only been able to use the figures that are on the record and then use paid consultants to interpret and work on those figures with us.

Let us take what figures were available. When we announced that we were to have a goods and services tax as part of our overall tax reform package, there were at least two Government Budgets to be had before we got to an election. People should realise that Budget announcements are merely estimates and remember that, in its 1990-91 Budget Estimates, the Government compounded an error of at least $6.2 billion, a figure that the Opposition did not see until the Estimates for the Budget for 1991-92 were brought down. Had we worked on the figures that were put out by the Government for the 1990-91 Budget, we would have also been out by $6.2 billion. It is only now that we have any real, actual figures to work with so that we at least have a base. We still have another Budget to go, but we cannot wait that long. At least we have some concrete figures to work with, which came out only relatively recently.

We are determined to ensure that, when we bring down our package, it will be a package that is worked out with a degree of accuracy and a knowledge of the difficulties that have to be dealt with so that it is clear, coherent, logical and equitable. The Government will come back with its attacks, using government figures that are worked out by public servants, just as it did in the last election campaign when Senator Walsh, the then Minister for Finance, used the Department of Finance to work out figures to attack our economic action plan. So anyone who has any doubt about the truth of my statement that the Government will abuse the process of using public servants to do what ought to be paid party political work has only to look at the way in which the Department of Finance was used on the last occasion to know that, when the figures come out from this Government, they will have been obtained at taxpayers' expense and will be distorted to the taxpayers' disadvantage.

I said right at the beginning that the Bill to which we are speaking epitomises the inequities, the illogicalities and the difficulties of the Government's secret tax, otherwise known as the wholesale sales tax. This is a two-page Bill with a 12-page memorandum and a supplementary explanatory memorandum. It will be the subject of various rulings of varying thicknesses.

I suppose that my favourite part of the Bill deals with mineral water. If I am somebody who likes to drink still, natural spring water, I pay no sales tax but, if I am somebody who likes to drink natural spring water which has natural bubbles in it or which is carbonated, I pay 20 per cent tax. If I like to drink still natural spring water and published on the label is the fact that it has minerals in it, I pay no tax but, if I like to drink natural spring water and published on the label is the fact that it has those minerals in it and also the words `Mineral water', I pay 20 per cent tax. The bottom line is that I pay 20 per cent tax on home-grown mineral water with bubbles but, if I like to have an imported still spring water with no bubbles, I pay no tax. Where is the logic, equity and sense in any of that, particularly when people who like Coca-Cola, Fanta or any other soft drink pay 20 per cent tax?

Clearly, the option is that there has to be tax reform. As the Government's own report has said, it is not acceptable to tinker with what we have. There has to be dramatic and important tax reform. As I said, the opportunity to speak on yet another tinkering Bill, which may or may not achieve the aim that it thinks it sets out to do because it is subject to interpretation, is just a splendid example of why we desperately require equity and logic in our tax system and why we need a change of government to ensure that tax reform takes place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I thank those honourable senators who made positive contributions to this debate and welcome them. Firstly I say that, unfortunately, although I tried to attend to the many points that Senator Watson raised, I was not able to pick up all of the questions he asked during the early part of his speech. Due to a bit of an information mix-up, officers were not available to pick up all the points that he raised. I reiterate that I will not be able to respond to all the points he raised in the second reading debate because I missed some of them. However, I assure him that I will get the Hansard and give him a considered response to those that I cannot respond to now. I will follow that up as soon as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to raise some of the points raised by Senator Watson, Senator Patterson and Senator Kernot. I will deal with the amendments in detail at the committee stage. Senator Watson and Senator Patterson, if I recall correctly, asked why we were not implementing the Industry Commission recommendation to exempt computer hardware used to operate communications equipment. That is a matter that is under investigation. But at this stage we do not want to make a decision to deal just with computer hardware used to operate communications equipment. I cannot at this stage follow the rationale of the Industry Commission's position of isolating it. We are looking at the position of computer equipment for all uses by people with disabilities. That is being assessed at the moment. It has been referred to the disabilities task force. When the response comes back from that, we will try to give a more comprehensive response. I cannot indicate the nature of that response but at this stage we are looking at it more broadly.

The question regarding the position of specially modified vehicles for use by taxi companies was raised. Let me make it clear that the Bill does not exempt these vehicles or the modifications undertaken by manufacturers. Those vehicles receive concessional treatment in that they are not subject to the 30 per cent rate; they are taxed at the standard 20 per cent rate. It is not our view that it would be appropriate to exempt manufacturers modifying goods such as these, regardless of who uses the goods. It is not readily apparent why they should be distinguished from modifications to other goods which would make them more useful to people with disabilities but which might be used one per cent, 2 per cent, 3 per cent or 99 per cent of the time by people without disabilities. It is really then just a subsidy for modification rather than assistance to people with disabilities.

I want to come back to this question of the ability of the wholesale sales tax to discriminate with regard to these matters. It is a discrimination which needs to be used in a targeted manner so that the benefit flows to the people for whom it is intended. That is why the Bill exempts parts for use in modifications which are not so extensive as to constitute manufacture. This will deliver the exemption to people with disabilities and to their carers rather than more generally to those who modify vehicles that might be used otherwise.

That is the rationale for the distinction. We have a situation in which the wholesale sales tax does have a capacity, which we are exercising, to discriminate between different types of goods and to tax them at different rates either because of their nature or because of their use. That is a desirable thing, but it is something that needs to be used in a targeted manner. Senator Kernot was correct in her earlier comments about that. I simply want to reinforce that point.

Notice has been given of a number of amendments--I am not talking about the second reading amendment--and, as I said, I will deal with those in the committee stage. It is sufficient to indicate now that the Government will not be supporting any of those amendments, although we can see some need for further examination of at least one about which there has been some correspondence between the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) and the previous Australian Democrats spokesperson on this area. There will be further examination of some of those things, but we will deal with that in the committee stage.

The Industry Commission has made a substantial contribution to the debate on this issue. It has been informative and has put some facts into the discussion. That is always useful. The debate is better for that. That does not mean, as with any other Industry Commission report, that the Government, the Opposition, the Democrats or anyone else will accept every recommendation that the Industry Commission makes or accept all the conclusions to which the Industry Commission comes. That is not the purpose of advisory bodies such as the Industry Commission, but those bodies do enhance the level of public debate about these issues. I welcome its report, for that matter.

There are some other Industry Commission recommendations about which the Government has made a different decision. In each of these instances, the decision has been made in a manner which is more beneficial to people with disabilities than would have been the case had the Industry Commission's recommendations been adopted. For example, the Industry Commission recommended full removal of the wholesale sales tax exemption for vehicles above the threshold, but the Government has only partially removed the exemption, otherwise it might have been too harsh, and we were not prepared to go as far as the Industry Commission. This is a more moderate position. The Industry Commission recommended that the two-year requirement for ownership should be extended to four years, but the Government has decided--I think correctly--to maintain the two-year requirement. That general requirement is in other sections of the legislation and, in the interests of consistency, we decided that we would retain that two-year requirement.

I make that general response to the specific issues raised during the debate. I welcome Senator Kernot to the arcane world of the tax debate. It was her first contribution on behalf of the Democrats in her new role. It tends to be a fairly specialised debate and I am sure she will enjoy her participation in it.

I must turn briefly to the Opposition's second reading amendment. It is not one on which I think the Senate would welcome my wasting a great deal of its time. It is simply an assertion of the impending Opposition policy; it will be debated in many forums. Quite clearly, the Government rejects the amendment, as it rejects the proposal for a goods and services tax and as it rejects the package within which the goods and services tax is embedded: the cuts to public expenditure, the abolition of capital gains tax and cuts to the top rate of income tax to provide benefits to those who are already privileged.

The fundamental elements of our opposition come down to two things: we do not believe the proposal for a goods and services tax is fair; we do not believe the proposal is in the interests of Australia's future. For those reasons, we will not be supporting it. Simply put--the arguments are long and the debate will go on for a long time; this is not the time to rehearse them all--the proportion of income spent by people with lower incomes on goods that will be taxed more highly or taxed for the first time under a goods and services tax is much higher than the proportion that is spent by people with higher incomes. Therefore, the impact will be regressive: poor people will be hit more strongly than the wealthy.

This can be summed up when we look at the simple question: what will be cheaper and what will be more expensive? Luxury cars will be cheaper; basic services, such as health services, will be more expensive. That is what makes it fundamentally unfair. That unfairness in itself would be sufficient, but I believe in 1991--and probably at any time in our future--nothing could be less in the interests of this country than the introduction of a tax that will lead to a massive one-off surge in inflation and destroy the achievements of the Government in breaking the cycle of inflationary expectation that has bedevilled Australia for two decades.

The other arguments that are asserted about the goods and services tax and which were thrown around rather like confetti in the course of this debate concern a theory which tends to continue, notwithstanding facts to the contrary. Of course, Senator Bishop said that it will bring about a massive increase in the incentive to save. I have heard that argument. I understand the economic theory underpinning it. There are two things wrong with it. There is not a skerrick of evidence to support it. When we look at other countries, we either do a vertical or a horizontal analysis. In one country, over the period in which it introduced a value added tax of the type advocated by the Opposition, there is no evidence of an increase in the savings ratios.

TALK.START.PARA: —-No great evidence.
—-There is none. The correlation is nil.
—-Why do we have the lowest savings ratio in the world today?

—-The fact of the matter is that there is no correlation. It has nothing to do with our tax system. That is the Opposition's problem. The fact of the matter is that when we look at different countries at the same time there is no correlation. The countries with the highest savings ratios are not the countries with the highest percentage of indirect taxes, and vice versa. There is no correlation. The facts do not bear out the Opposition's assertion.

SPEECH.PARA: When Dr Hewson was shadow Treasurer, he said in an outbreak of honesty, `A lot of people have been asserting this for years, but there is no evidence to support it'. He was right then, but he has since changed his tune because he wishes he was wrong. He was right then, and it remains the case that there is not one scintilla of evidence. It is like the Opposition's wish list about the amount of money it will get from the black economy. We can all understand the theoretical argument that says it ought to happen. The trouble is that, when Roger Douglas and the fellow from Canada were brought to Australia, they unfortunately stood up and said, `There is no evidence to support the position; it didn't happen'.

TALK.START.PARA: —-But there was a big increase in income tax.

—-They said, `It did not happen in our countries; there was no or perhaps a one per cent increase in the revenue we got'. The Opposition has to keep pretending the increase is there to make the numbers add up.

SPEECH.PARA: We also had this absolute nonsense about the compliance costs of a wholesale sales tax for small business. Notwithstanding the silly assertions made by Senator Bishop, the honest representatives of the Opposition--and there are some--know that all the evidence of expert analysts, including supporters of a goods and services tax, shows that compliance costs are higher under a goods and services tax than under a wholesale sales tax, and that they fall disproportionately on small business. That is quite clearly the evidence and members of the Opposition want to make assertions contrary to the evidence because the facts are uncomfortable.

I will deal with Senator Bishop's arguments about that piece of market research at the Estimates Committee hearing on Friday. All I will say today is that her public position is the most gross misuse of material made available by the public that I have seen in 20 years of public life and 20 years of dealing with market research. Quantum, which is not renowned as a Labor oriented organisation, has made it clear to Senator Bishop as well as to the Tax Office and to the Government that it does not support the analysis she has made. She knows that, but she continues deliberately to distort and misuse the material. The only thing which can be said in mitigation is that, from the way she explains it, it seems that she does not understand that she is misusing the information because she does not understand what it says.

The last point I want to make about the second reading amendment is simply this: this is the starkest example of an inappropriate amendment of any piece of legislation to come before the Parliament. Here we have evidence of the capacity of the wholesale sales tax, for all its faults, to discriminate in favour of goods of a socially worthwhile nature. Here we have the Parliament, I think unanimously, passing a Bill to extend a sales tax exemption to assist people with disabilities. The problem with the goods and services tax--the value added tax--is that it does not have the capacity so to discriminate, and the cost of these things for which we are providing an exemption here tonight will go up.

The capacity to discriminate in favour of people with disabilities, in favour of environmentally desirable goods and in favour of institutions which require and deserve the assistance of the taxpayers will disappear with the goods and services tax as proposed by the Opposition. The hospitals and other bodies which buy sales tax exempt vehicles will lose the capacity to do so. It is arguable what will happen with regard to State and local governments because we do not yet know, but those bodies such as hospitals and schools which receive sales tax exemption at the moment will lose that benefit because the goods and services tax does not have the capacity so to discriminate.

Obviously, the Government rejects the second reading amendment. I would be delighted to have the opportunity to make a longer contribution about this matter on another occasion, but now is not the time to do so. The Government will not be supporting any of the other amendments moved by the Democrats, but I will deal with those in the committee stage.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —-No.

They are contingent upon each other, so I would prefer to move them together. SPEECH.PARA: I would like to take this opportunity to point out to the Government that, if it were to accept our four amendments, the Opposition would find it very hard to justify removing them under a goods and services tax proposal. TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Clause 3, page 2, omit paragraphs 6AE(1)(a) and (b), lines 6 to 9, substitute the following paragraphs:

Amendment No. 1 proposes to amend clause 3 of the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1991, which would insert a new section 6AE into the principal Act. This clause grants a partial exemption from sales tax, currently valued at $6,101, in respect of purchases of luxury motor vehicles by the people covered by the provision. The only people covered in the Bill are certain veterans and other disabled people who qualify for sales tax concessions under items 135 or 135A of the first schedule of the principal Act.

This amendment proposes to extend the partial exemption from sales tax in respect of the purchase of luxury motor vehicles to a variety of organisations. These organisations include item 63A, schools and universities; item 63B(1), organisations promoting the interests of schools and universities; item 74, Commonwealth or State government departments or authorities; item 76(1), the Reserve Bank of Australia; item 77, public transport authorities; item 78, local government, harbour boards or trusts and fire brigade boards; and item 81(1), public and non-profit private hospitals, public benevolent institutions and organisations established and maintained for the relief of unemployed persons.

Although this amendment grants concessional treatment to these bodies, it must be remembered that amendment No. 3 proposes to eliminate the current unlimited exemption which these bodies enjoy with respect to luxury motor vehicles. The rationale for this amendment is simple: if disabled people are to be subject to a cap on the amount of sales tax relief they are entitled to, we believe a similar limitation should apply to other persons or organisations which also benefit from sales tax exemptions. These proposals were distributed to the Government and the Opposition weeks ago. The Treasurer (Mr Kerin) replied to them and I seek leave to incorporate his reply in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows--
Senator S. Spindler
Senator for Victoria
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Spindler
CAP ON ALL SALES TAX EXEMPTIONS FOR MOTOR VEHICLES AT THE LUXURY THRESHOLD

Thank you for your letter of 11 September 1991 seeking the Government's support for your proposed amendment to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1991. I understand that you wish to extend the cap on the value of sales tax exemptions, which under the Bill would apply to exemptions under Items 135 and 135A, to all sales tax exemptions for motor vehicles.
I agree that in principle the sales tax system should not subsidise the purchase of luxury motor vehicles, and acknowledge that there are some arguments in equity for your proposal.

However, I cannot offer you the Government's support for your amendment in these sittings, since the range of sales tax exemptions for motor vehicles is too varied to be subject to a blanket application of a cap. The initial advice that I have received indicates that there are some 27 categories of users that are eligible for an exemption for motor vehicles under the sales tax law alone. In addition exemption is provided to diplomatic and consular staff under separate legislation--the Diplomatic Privileges and Immunities Act and the Consular Privileges and Immunities Act.
Separate issues arise for each of these classes of beneficiaries, and it would be prudent to investigate these issues more fully before making a decision. For example:

. many hospitals and other bodies eligible for sales tax exemption on motor vehicle purchases do not buy luxury vehicles but rather high-valued specialised vehicles, such as ambulances--these would be hindered by an indiscriminate cap;
. to remove the exemptions for State and local governments, and their authorities, without negotiation would hinder the vertical fiscal imbalance agenda of the Special Premiers' Conference;

. the legality of taxing the cars purchased for use by the Governor-General and the State Governors is questionable--since they are the representatives of the Crown, the doctrine of sovereign immunity might apply;
. it would be unacceptable for the Australian Government to remove unilaterally the benefits to the diplomatic and consular corps--this could be a breach of treaties;
. there are also some technical questions such as:
- whether to exclude from the cap other specialist industrial road vehicles, such as buses, and dump trucks used in mining;
- to ensure that the cap does not impinge upon exported luxury motor vehicles which are exempt under Item 110.
I am sure that you can understand that this matter needs a more careful analysis than that afforded by the present passage of the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1991.
Yours sincerely
John Kerin

TALK.START.PARA: —-I thank the new Treasurer for his reply. It is our view that the previous incumbent might not have replied.
—-That is unkind! You wouldn't have got a reply from him for a year.

—-That is what I said. However, we would argue that the Treasurer's reply is wrong. My amendments do not propose, as he says, a cap on all 27 categories of users. We acknowledge that. There is no proposal to end the exemption provided for ambulances, dump trucks or exported vehicles. They are in no way remotely affected under the distributed amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Furthermore, the reference in the Treasurer's reply to the Governor-General's car is a furphy, and is inaccurate in the assumption that the amendments cover that case and the doctrine of sovereign immunity. This Parliament enacted legislation in the late 1980s which removed the general sales tax exemption available to the Governor-General and his staff. I commend these amendments to honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I think some of the issues that have been raised by the Australian Democrats in the debate on the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill highlight the problems inherent in a wholesale sales tax type regime. The emphasis is directed to the goods which have to correspond to certain specifications in order to be eligible. A more humane approach would certainly be to focus on people who require certain types of aids to make their lives more meaningful.

SPEECH.PARA: The reading of the background to the Industry Commission report was interesting. A lot of the participants urged a widening of a tax exemption to cover certain goods which are not necessarily specifically designed for people with disabilities but which are, nevertheless, considered necessary to enable them to enjoy a more independent lifestyle.

I emphasise this because I gained some encouragement from the comments of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) at the conclusion of the second reading debate. I thank him for responding in detail to issues raised during speeches. Not all of the vessels of charity remain on the Government side. I was heartened by the responses. For that reason, I raise this question about the need to improve the lot of people with disabilities to enable them to enjoy a more independent lifestyle.

The sorts of issues that Senator Kernot raised have a great deal of validity. We acknowledge a concession to provide a ramp into a taxi, but the person with the disability really needs the bubble on the top of the car in order to move with some dignity from place to place. It seems just a quirk of the definition inherent in the sales tax procedures that we have run into this particular problem. Therefore, I put it to the Parliamentary Secretary that perhaps we need a system that acknowledges the needs of people with disabilities rather than particular exemptions of goods which have a peculiar adaptation for persons with responsibilities. I think that distinction is indeed important.

Unfortunately, this debate has been used to criticise the Opposition's goods and services tax. A number of the participants have overlooked the fact that it is possible, under a GST regime, to either exempt or zero rate certain categories of people, perhaps those with disabilities. A lot of false assertions have been made when the Opposition has not released the full details. Therefore, much criticism has been levelled at the Opposition's goods and services tax for political expediency and principle. Unless the full detail is there so that people can really evaluate that they are going to be better off in terms of having a higher disposable income with the GST, that criticism is based on false premises.

The central thrust of the Opposition's proposal for a GST is that people will have a higher disposable income after all taxes. To achieve that purpose there will be reductions in income tax at levels which will recognise the needs of people most in need. There will be compensations for those people who are less fortunate in society, including pensioners. I think it is unfortunate that this debate has provided something of a forum for some ill-conceived criticism based on prejudice and political expediency. That is unfortunate.

At the same time, I welcome the Parliamentary Secretary's acknowledgment that there are certain features that the Government is prepared to investigate thoroughly. In regard to the items that I listed, would it be possible to table the ATO publication that was mentioned at the Industry Commission inquiry? The inquiry was told that the ATO was working on it at the time. I presume that it would be ready by now. If it has been finalised, would it be possible for it to be tabled? Could the Parliamentary Secretary give us an indication of how widely that document in relation to the problems of people with disabilities would be distributed? This whole area of sales tax is a real Pandora's box for people with disabilities. I would welcome such a pamphlet. Anything we can do to make the lives of these people much more tolerable, pleasant and humane is to be commended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I would like the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) to clarify something for me. The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill says that sales tax will not be attributed to the modification of a motor vehicle solely for the purpose of adapting it for transferring a person with a disability. If a taxi is modified with a hydraulic lift or hydraulic ramp to enable access for a person in a wheelchair, is that modification sales tax exempt?

SPEECH.PARA: The Parliamentary Secretary, in response to the speeches in the second reading debate, said that a manufacturing modification would not be exempt from sales tax. If I were to buy a standard vehicle and take it to a body builder and have a modification made to it to enable a person in a wheelchair to be transported sitting up in that wheelchair, would that modification be exempted from sales tax?

It seems to me that there might be an anomaly if somebody asks for it to be done by a manufacturer and it is not exempt from sales tax whereas, if somebody buys it and has a modification made, it will be exempt from sales tax under the Act. If there is an anomaly there, it needs to be rectified.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I understand from Senator Kernot that, if it is suitable to the Committee, she would like to speak to amendments 2 and 4 and then to take four separate divisions on each amendment.
—-In other words, there will be one debate on all the amendments and then four votes?
—-Yes.
—-That is agreeable to the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I wish to point to the fact that sales tax exemptions, as was explained in the Industry Commission report, were not the optimum way of providing assistance to people with disabilities. The Opposition certainly agrees with that point. In fact, direct cash assistance is a far more efficient way of compensating people with special needs who are reliant on particular types of goods or services.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, we are stuck with this wholesale sales tax system under the Hawke Government. This is a further demonstration of its inflexibility and of the sorts of problems that arise. We debate Bills of this sort at least two or three times a year. It is unfortunate that we are unable to get this right. We need a better regime than the sales tax regime to try to overcome the problems of people with disabilities. The Government might even like to consider direct cash assistance.

SPEECH.PARA: 2. After clause 3, page 2, insert the following clause:

and the part of the sale value attributable to the modification exceeds the sales tax payable under item 1 of the Fifth Schedule on the motor vehicle if it had not been modified, item 1 of the Fifth Schedule does not apply to that motor vehicle and sales tax is not payable on that motor vehicle.
Sales tax not payable on certain motor vehicle modifications for people with disabilities
`6AG In spite of anything contained in any law relating to sales tax, where a motor vehicle has been modified solely for the purpose of:
