4. Clause 4, page 2, line 20, after paragraph (a) insert the following paragraph:
"(ae) by omitting from item 135A `to and from gainful employment' after `transportation';".

In moving these amendments, I would like to continue to speak on amendment 3, which proposes to amend clause 4 of the Bill. This clause eliminates the exemption from sales tax which would otherwise apply to certain veterans and disabled people under items 135 and 135A of the first schedule of the principal Act. The clause also ensures that the value of any modifications to the vehicle which relate to making the vehicle fit for driving or transporting a disabled person is to be excluded from the sale value of the car.

Amendment No. 3 proposes to eliminate the sales tax exemption which currently applies in respect of the purchase of luxury cars by the organisations I have previously mentioned. In conjunction with amendment No. 1, this will have the effect of limiting the sales tax exemption on luxury cars to the cap of $6,101 which the Government is imposing on the disabled in this Bill.

The Australian Democrats are not advocating the removal of the sales tax exemption which currently applies to these bodies--far from it. We totally support charities being exempt from sales tax in general. Indeed, this is one area of the Opposition's proposed consumption tax that disturbs the Australian Democrats. This measure would result in a net gain in tax to the Commonwealth, although the exact quantum is unknown.

Amendment No. 4 is concerned with item 135A of the first schedule of the principal Act. This provision grants an exemption from sales tax to disabled people who have been certified by the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services as being unable to use public transport. However, the exemption is available only in respect of a motor vehicle purchased to transport the owner to and from gainful employment. The amendment proposes to remove the necessity for the vehicle to be used in connection with travel to and from work.

The reason for the amendment is that the Democrats believe that we should be assisting all disabled people who cannot use public transport--not merely those who enjoy gainful employment. These people still need access to transport to go shopping, to visit the doctor and to conduct like activities. The issue is really one of mobility, and hence quality of life. Tax concessions should not be limited to travel to and from work.

We think there is no doubt that this amendment would involve a cost to Commonwealth revenue. The exact amount is unknown, as we have said. The Industry Commission report quoted a Taxation Office estimate of the cost of the concession at $2.3m in 1988-89. This was about 750 exemptions, each with an average value of $3,000. The amendment would increase the number of eligible people who could benefit from the exemption, but it is unlikely that there would be very many people who do not have a job who would be able to afford to purchase a new car. There would be some people who have retired who have some superannuation or other savings. There would also be people who obtained some compensation payments who would be assisted, and there may be others who will be assisted in purchasing a car by their families.

All these examples are ones which the Democrats believe should be assisted by the Commonwealth. We as a parliament should ensure that disabled people are granted access to transport as easily as possible, and this is one way in which we can assist. It will cost money, but the amount will be a few million dollars a year.

I remind the Committee that the reduction in the luxury car tax, which is agreed to by the Government and the Opposition, has a cost to revenue of $45m a year. I ask what kind of priority this shows if the Committee will not agree to contribute significantly to the quality of life of the most disadvantaged of Australians at a fraction of the cost of the relaxation of the luxury car tax rate. I also remind the Committee that I am proposing to raise some revenue by extending the luxury car exemption cap to other exempt taxpayers, which would raise some revenue.

With reference to Senator Watson's statement, I understand that the Opposition will cut $3 billion from the Commonwealth Budget. One has to ask why Opposition members say that cash grants are the best way to go if they cannot give us some assurance that the disabled would not be part of that trimming operation. I commend the amendments to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Perhaps I may deal with a couple of general comments before I deal with the amendments that are before the Committee. Senator Watson asked me about tabling a document from the Australian Taxation Office concerning issues related to this matter. I do not have a copy with me now to table, but I shall happily table one tomorrow in order to make it available. Indeed, it is a publicly available document, available now.

SPEECH.PARA: In dealing with the generalities in some of Senator Watson's points on these amendments, I share his view--a view that has been expressed in this chamber on several occasions in the past by many people, including me--that it is often the case that it is much better to deal with assistance to people in need, whether by virtue of their disability or otherwise, by expenditure measures rather than by tax assistance, because it is often possible more directly to target that and to focus on those in greatest need.

As a general statement of principle, that is true--and it is something which the Government has generally applied in its approach--but I do not think that should be extrapolated to an argument that there should be no such taxation assistance. I endorse the general point, but he did not extend it--and I do not wish to extend it--to the point that there should be no such use of the tax system. It is one of the things which, by its nature, create complexity. As soon as exemptions and special classifications in differential rates dependent upon criteria defined in legislation are introduced, there are arguments about where boundaries arise, and why it applies to A and not B, or A and B and not C. Those arguments are always lengthy, subjective and difficult. Nevertheless, this is an endeavour upon which we should embark, notwithstanding its difficulty.

With regard to the Australian Democrats' amendments Nos 1 and 3, as Senator Kernot has incorporated the letter from the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) in response to Senator Spindler's approach to him on this matter, who am I to add anything to that argument? The amendment as now before us is somewhat more limited than that to which the Treasurer was responding, so I will make some brief reference to that in additional comment. I reiterate a key sentence of that letter from the Treasurer which stated:
I agree that in principle the sales tax system should not subsidise the purchase of luxury motor vehicles, and acknowledge that there are some arguments in equity for your proposal.

In other words, it is a proposal not without merit. It is an extension which the Government is prepared to examine but, for a variety of reasons which are understandable and not the fault of anyone in particular, the specific proposal is not one that we are ready at this stage to endorse or approve. It has some merit, but it takes the issue a little further than we would be prepared to take it.

We are not absolutely sure that the public hospitals provision, for example, in the way that it is dealt with here will achieve the outcome that we would wish. There are also concerns about the fact that many of the bodies referred to in the list are funded by State or local government. We are likely to find those State or local government bodies coming back to the Commonwealth seeking some sort of compensation for the cost to them of the changes, and we might wind up in a vicious circle.

There is the principle that there should be a cap on the application of benefits to people with disabilities, in this instance, and in other instances to those in public benevolent institutions, for example, so that they cannot get benefits designed to help the needy on luxury vehicles. This has merit, but the amendment is not at this stage in a form that we are prepared to endorse, although I am happy to give an undertaking that it is a matter that we will not let rest; it is something we would wish to pursue. That deals with amendments Nos 1 and 3. It seems logical to deal with them in that sequence.

With regard to amendment No. 2, this is probably the appropriate point at which to deal also with Senator Patterson's concern. There is not the anomaly of which she speaks. If the modification made by a person subsequent to sale was of the same order of magnitude as that which would have been made by the manufacturer in the first place, it would be deemed to be a modification equivalent to manufacture and would still be taxed at 20 per cent and not exempt. Every time a boundary is drawn, people can debate whether it is in the right place. I accept that. There would be an anomaly if identical processes performed in different factories were taxed at different rates. That would be a problem. That is not the case. A line is drawn about the nature of the modifications that apply.

The amendment as proposed would create major problems in the sales tax law in its attempt to exempt the full sale value in this way. We start to get some anomalous situations, and we would undoubtedly immediately get representations to extend similar exemptions to modifications for all sorts of goods where those modifications may be of assistance to people with disabilities but may also be used, and would be likely to be used, by anybody and everybody, whether or not they are people with disabilities.

It comes back to the argument that the use of the tax system is a bit of a blunt instrument. It is not always the best way to provide this sort of assistance but we try, by virtue of targeting and definition, to focus it as precisely as we can so that the benefit flows to the people for whom it is intended. The more we extend it, the more we create the possibility that the cost to revenue will not be commensurate with the benefits because the benefits tend to flow more widely, to a wider audience than the target audience, and a substantial proportion of the assistance will not assist the people for whom it was intended.

It is not an amendment with which we are in sympathy; nor is it one that we wish to support. It is always possible--and it has been done--to mount an argument every time any amendment to the wholesale sales tax legislation comes forward, as it is every time amendments to the income tax legislation come forward, and to say, `The exemptions and concessions in this legislation are all well and good but why not, instead of giving those three, give concession Nos 4, 5 and 6 as well?'.

On questions of public revenue and public expenditure there are always more worthy causes than there is money to go around to finance them. If that was not the case, the management of public policy would be a much easier task and none of us would have such a harrowing time. We would not have to make difficult choices. We do have to make them, and that is one of the dividing lines that has to be sustained.

We have debated amendment No. 4 on the gainful employment test in the chamber before. I do not have much to add to those things which I have said previously. The disability task force may well want to come back and say something to us about that, in which case we would look at it. At the moment, the situation is that this is an item designed to encourage and facilitate access to employment. It is worth while and limited in that manner and it is noteworthy that, as far as I can ascertain, the Industry Commission did not recommend any change to this proposal. As I say, nothing has changed since we debated it in the Senate the last time, as I recall. The Government does not agree with that or any of the other amendments. We hope that we can deal with the committee stage expeditiously and pass the Bill so that the benefits in the legislation can flow to the people for whom they are intended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I thank the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) for his answer. I find it rather strange that there can be sales tax exemption for a modification designed to get people into vehicles, but when they get in they do not fit if they are sitting in wheelchairs. It seems to me to be a bizarre situation. I need to be convinced on this and challenge the Parliamentary Secretary on it. When the vehicle is adapted to transport a person who is suffering from a physical impairment, it does not seem to me that it is said anywhere that if the modification is of the same magnitude as that undertaken in a factory, it is not exempt. If Senator McMullan could explain where that appears in the explanatory memorandum or wherever, I might be more satisfied. It does have budgetary implications and places me, as a member of the Opposition, in a difficult situation.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot imagine any taxi company modifying a taxi by elevating the roof to make it look more beautiful or for any purpose other than transporting somebody with a disability. It will cost more. It will mean that the company's costs of transporting people without disabilities will be increased or that the profits will be reduced. I cannot see any benefit to a company in doing that other than for the purpose of transporting someone with a disability.

I would like the Parliamentary Secretary to look carefully at this matter again. He may come up with some sort of alternative suggestion or give an undertaking to take this anomaly to the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) for his consideration. It seems very odd that one can have all sorts of adaptations to a vehicle except that of lifting the roof so that a person in a wheelchair can sit in a taxi. I do not understand it, and it seems to me to be inconsistent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I do not want to extend the debate, so I will be very brief. If Senator Patterson has more queries, I will drop her a note outlining the rationale and where it fits in the legislation. I am not saying it is not an important issue; it is just not an issue we need to debate backwards and forwards here. We can pursue it otherwise.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments to the legislation essentially deal with the exemption of parts used in particular modifications. The parts, if used by a manufacturer, would be exempt as an input in the process, as an aid to manufacture. What we are saying is that, if individuals who are not registered as manufacturers use those parts for such a modification, they could also get an exemption.

I know that there are other points that Senator Patterson is concerned about. I certainly do not want to brush aside issues that people raise in trying properly to deal with benefits to people in need. Therefore, if Senator Patterson wants to outline any other elements of her concern subsequently, rather than now, I will happily give her a considered response. But I do not think they are going to change the nature of, or the Government's response to, the particular amendments before us now.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Senator McMullan has made much of the costs involved in this matter. I reiterate that we said that the package may well be revenue positive. We do not know for certain, but I did suggest looking at a general anti-avoidance provision in the sales tax law, which we think would be revenue positive, and Senator McMullan did not address that. I ask him whether the Government would consider using such a provision to fund what we are suggesting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The question of general anti-avoidance provisions, their applicability and the way in which other legislation should be modified to take account of that--I will come to the question of what we do with the revenue that might flow from it in a moment--is one that is under a lot of debate both in the sales tax area and in the income tax area. It is often argued that we could deal with a lot of the complexity of the income tax legislation by relying more on general anti-avoidance provisions and the fact that we now have a High Court not so disposed to interpret every tax avoidance scheme in the interests of the avoider, as it did in the Barwick era.

SPEECH.PARA: That may well be a general question worthy of further pursuit, but as it relates particularly to the wholesale sales tax there is a simplification review under way. One of the elements of that is how we should deal with avoidance issues. It may be that emerging from that there will be consideration of a general anti-avoidance provision. We are certainly not going to be in a position--and I know that Senate Kernot is not proposing it--to put one in the Bill at this late stage. Therefore I do not want to spend too much time at the committee stage dealing with something that is not before us.

It is a very complicated matter. We are obviously sympathetic to cracking down on schemes designed to avoid tax in whatever form--wholesale sales tax or otherwise. Whether a general anti-avoidance provision is the best way to do it is not yet a settled question. But I could not give a guarantee, even if we introduced such a clause--and I agree with Senator Kernot that we would assume that that would generate revenue--that this would be the priority to which that revenue would be put. It would go into the pool of revenue that would be considered at Budget time when we decided how the extra revenue ought to be allocated in accordance with Government priorities. It may be that this would be one of them; it may well be that it would be expended on many of the other competing priorities that we all share. I cannot give the assurance that, even if we introduced such a provision--and that will not be decided for a while--this would be given priority in relation to the way we would spend that revenue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-This debate tonight has demonstrated very vividly a situation of lost opportunities, because the catalyst was essentially a very good report from the Industry Commission which highlighted a number of problems. There was wide input from the representative bodies, which are aware of the problems. But I take heart from the fact that the Parliamentary Secretary said he would take note of the matters that have been raised, and we believe that, with charity in his heart, in time we will be able to effect a number of the reasonable issues that have been raised in this debate tonight. I thank him for that.
—-The question is that amendment No. 1 moved by Senator Kernot be agreed to.

DEBATE.TITLE: EXPORT FINANCE AND INSURANCE CORPORATION BILL 1991EXPORT FINANCE AND INSURANCE CORPORATION (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1991

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That these Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows--
EXPORT FINANCE AND INSURANCE
CORPORATION BILL 1991

The Export Finance and Insurance Corporation Bill will re-establish the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation (EFIC) as an independent statutory corporation offering competitive export credit facilities for Australian exporters.

The Bill stems from a report to the Government by the Departments of Industry, Technology and Commerce, Foreign Affairs and Trade, Primary Industries and Energy, Treasury, Finance and Prime Minister and Cabinet on the effectiveness of EFIC and its export finance and insurance services.

The Government's March 12 "Building a More Competitive Australia" statement, recognised the need for Australian exporters to have access to competitive financial facilities to be effective, especially in Asia-Pacific markets. The Government announced its intention in the statement to re-establish EFIC as a separate entity to Austrade, with greater visibility and an extended range of services for exporters. As part of this restructuring, a $200 million dollar callable capital facility is to be provided to supplement EFIC's existing reserves of some $160 million. This will ensure adequate financial backing for its insurance, guarantee and lending operations.

A $50 million performance bonding facility and the more aggressive use of interest subsidy arrangements through Australian dollar financing and the provision of lines of credit to off-shore banks, which were also announced in the March Statement, are now in operation. The performance bond facility already stands to provide vital assistance for projects worth over $200 million.
In considering the Bill, it will be of benefit for members to understand a little of EFIC's background, its core activities and its relationship with Government.

EFIC's services are broadly comparable to those available to our overseas competitors through similar Government backed export credit agencies. It insures exporters against the risk of non-payment by overseas buyers and provides a range of guarantee and bonding services. EFIC covers around 10% of Australia's trade and in 1990/91 supported exports totalling $4.5 billion.
It also insures off-shore investments by Australian companies against non-commercial loss caused by exchange transfer blockages, expropriation or war damage. Cover on investments totals $490 million.

Concessional finance is available for exports of capital goods and related services on internationally competitive terms within trade finance rules set by the OECD. EFIC's lending program presently totals some $1,640 million. Lending is supported by an active program of borrowing on international capital markets. These funds are on-lent, often at subsidised interest rates. This year's Budget provides $14.7 million to meet interest subsidy costs.

EFIC, in one form or another, has been in operation for 35 years. Interest subsidy aside, EFIC's business has been at no cost to the taxpayer. For the past 5 years, EFIC has been a part of the Austrade organisation. To better equip EFIC for today's competitive export climate requires it operate in a more commercial and accountable way. In the Government's view, this will be best assured by establishing EFIC as a statutory corporation, structured along Government Business Enterprise lines. It will continue to fill a market gap by providing services which are not normally available from the private sector.

EFIC also undertakes transactions which the Government considers to be in the National Interest. These are usually high risk and involve important industry, trade or political considerations. Total exposure on the National Interest account is around $1.3 billion, of which the greater bulk relates to commodity exports, particularly wheat and wool. The UN sanctions on Iraq resulted in substantial calls on the Budget last year to fund claim payments to the Australian Wheat Board. A further $255 million has been provided in this year's Budget for this purpose. Although recovery of these debts is expected, this may be a protracted process.

Returning to the Bill. Although structured along Government Business Enterprise lines, EFIC is clearly not a commercial operation in the normal sense and will remain dependent on the Government's ultimate guarantee of its operations.

The provision of a $200 million callable capital facility is a key element of this restructuring. EFIC must have adequate capital to enable it to take-up worthwhile business while observing a proper prudential ratio between capital and reserves and contingent liabilities. Although EFIC has accumulated substantial reserves of around $160 million, independent advice indicates that its total contingent liability requires a more substantial capital base. The $200 million facility will be fully assessable for capital adequacy purposes. However, it will only be drawn upon when EFIC is no longer able to meet expected claims or losses. Provision has also been made for the return of such funding to the Government once the need for it passes.

The Government's control over EFIC will be limited to broad policy oversight. This will mainly occur through the corporate planning process and will include financial targets and accountability for results. Day to day control will rest with the EFIC Board and the Corporation's management. The composition of the Board is an important consideration requiring a blend of expertise in finance and exporting. A number of intended appointments to the new Board with these skills have been announced. The Government has been fortunate to obtain the services of Mr Reg Nicolson, recently retired Deputy Managing Director of the ANZ Bank, to head-up the new Board. To ensure that linkages between EFIC and Austrade are maintained, provision has been made for cross membership of Boards by the Managing Directors of the respective organisations.

In terms of direct financial impact, the Bill is neutral. However, the $200 million callable capital facility contained in the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation Bill is supported with a mechanism for EFIC to access the Consolidated Revenue Fund. This would only occur if, after consultation with the Minister for Finance, it is determined that EFIC's money and other assets are insufficient to meet expected liabilities, losses and claims. It is not anticipated that EFIC will need to call on this facility.

EFIC's overall operations are governed by maximum contingency liability and loan limits. These are prescribed in Regulations. The maximum contingent liability for insurance and guarantee business is $3,600 million. For overseas investment insurance it is $750 million. The maximum amount of loans is set at $1,900 million. Regulations maintaining these limits will be promulgated under the EFIC legislation.

In conclusion, EFIC will continue to work with the financial sector and not in competition with it, to provide Australian exporters with access to competitive credit insurance and export finance facilities. This is an essential part of the international trade environment and especially of the Asia Pacific region. EFIC has proved itself to be an efficient and cost effective organisation. In an increasingly complex global trading environment its financial record is exceptional. It compares favourably with most, if not all, other Export Credit Agencies. The independent and flexible structure proposed in this legislation will enhance EFIC's capacity to match competition from its overseas counterparts and meet the needs of Australian exporters into the future.
I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators.
EXPORT FINANCE AND INSURANCE CORPORATION (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1991

The Export Finance and Insurance Corporation (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill complements the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation Bill by providing transitional arrangements necessary to preserve continuity as export finance and insurance matters are transferred from Austrade to the newly constituted EFIC. The Bill also transfers assets, liabilities and staff associated with export finance and insurance activities from Austrade to EFIC.

Existing provisions of the Australian Trade Commission Act 1985 relating to export finance and insurance are repealed. The opportunity has also been taken to effect administrative changes to the existing Austrade Act.
Consequential amendments to other Acts are covered in the Schedule to the Bill.
The Bill does not have any expenditure or revenue implications for the Commonwealth.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

REPORT NO. 18 OF 1991
The Selection of Bills Committee reports that it has considered the bills scheduled to be debated in the Senate later tonight and recommends:
That the following bills not be referred to committees:
Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill 1991
Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill 1991
Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 September, on motion by Senator Tate:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-This Bill, the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill, is in itself a routine measure but it draws our attention to the whole area of government policy on overseas students and on the export of education services. The Bill, in fact, sets the charges for

SPEECH.PARA: overseas students who are studying in Australia under the former subsidised program. Of course, there have not been any new enrolments under the subsidised program either this year or last year because that program is being phased out and fewer students are in fact paying overseas student charges as defined by this legislation.

The Opposition has no difficulty with the terms of the Bill which are in the form of and according to an index that has been determined and used for several years now. So the Bill's passage has our support. What we do not support is the blundering inadequacy of government policy and administration in recent years over the arrangements which now and in the future provide for overseas students. This has been a disaster area for Australia while the Labor Party has been in power. I can only repeat what is now increasingly well known: despite the pleas in this chamber from the Opposition, the Government still continues with its policies which are inflexible and which are totally inadequate to meet not only the needs of overseas students in higher education but also, with much more pain to us, the needs of Australian students.

Honourable senators perhaps need to be reminded that the problems caused by government misjudgments over the mechanisms for regulation of the education export sector are entirely wrapped up with this inflexibility that Ministers Dawkins and Baldwin have shown. Indeed, we had a detailed debate earlier in the year on the special legislation which the Government introduced to deal with this export industry--education.

The legislation was so badly flawed that it took a Senate committee inquiry over several months and further work by the Opposition to produce by a large number of amendments a Bill which could be sensibly workable. Even then, we in the Opposition added a sunset clause that the whole legislation eventually be withdrawn.

We have seen Australia's reputation badly damaged abroad by sudden changes in policy--such as the sudden tightening of visa requirements at one point--and then the consequent hardship for intending students in other countries who have had an entitlement to refunds of prepaid moneys of the slow pace of repayments. Even now, the repayments to those students have not been completed. It is gross maladministration by this Government, and it has put, most unfortunately, the overseas student program in such bad light around the world, especially in Asia where we do have a market for students to enrol in Australian institutions and where we, in fact, can give positive assistance to so many students from Asia. This is a very real indictment of Mr Dawkins, Mr Baldwin and the Government's decision-making.

One of the most significant developments for Australian higher education in the export education area has been the growth of full fee paying courses for overseas students. In fact, this program has replaced the subsidised program. As of the passage of this Bill which is now before us, those students who remain in the subsidised student program will be paying 55 per cent of the cost of providing a university course, whereas full fee paying students are required to pay an estimated 100 per cent of the average cost of providing a course. With the payment of a full fee there are fewer restrictions--there is not so much of a quota on enrolments--and it has widened the options for those who can pay to come to Australia to gain educational opportunities.

In great contrast to this opportunity afforded to overseas students, the program is not available to Australian students. This is the major criticism that the Opposition has levelled at the Government for several years. It is prepared to afford a benefit to overseas students--and it is a real benefit--but not one part of that benefit is afforded to Australian students, with the exception of a few postgraduate certificated courses in some universities, the full fees of which are paid for mostly through industry.

In relation to all undergraduate courses and the great majority of postgraduate courses, this option for overseas students is denied every Australian student. That is unfair, and the Opposition has been calling for a remedy which will open the door and provide an opportunity for such a program to be made available to Australians. I hasten to add that the Opposition's program would not involve any lessening of the amount of real money that is made available to higher education in this country. This program will not be substituted for any of the current value of Commonwealth funding for higher education.

Indeed, this has provided substantial growth in enrolments for our educational institutions and they are very much in favour of it. Increasingly--especially in the last 12 months--they have been calling for the kind of new options which the Opposition has been calling for. It opens up a market-based approach to the provision of education services in stark contrast to the stubborn refusal of this Government to contemplate such an approach for domestic students. The Government's whole approach to higher education has been to centralise and bureaucratise policy making. It has wanted to control higher education institutions and restrict their autonomy.

Thus we have Mr Dawkins's so-called `unified national system' controlled by Canberra, that is, controlled by the Minister and his bureaucracy. We have the whole process of education profiles which institutions must negotiate with the Federal Department. We have the process of forced amalgamations, many of them not willingly entered into and not able to be justified on educational grounds. This whole centralised approach is rejected totally by the Opposition. When in government, we will allow genuine autonomy to the educational institutions around Australia. We will allow them to enrol students on whatever basis they see fit, and that would include a comparable and equitable basis such as the overseas student program to which I have referred. Indeed, it has been said that the elements of market orientation make the education export sector seem like an island in a murky sea of excessive government regulation.

I now refer to the report put down on 26 September by the Industry Commission. This report was called for by the then Treasurer, Mr Keating. The Commission was to examine every aspect of the important area of the export of education services. In referring to the report, I note that it says a lot of things which the Government ought to take very seriously. I want to highlight a few of these things. One of the report's early observations on page 7 states:
. . . the grafting of a market-oriented export sector onto a highly regulated, largely government-funded sector, has brought tensions to the surface.
The report goes on to explore the broader issues about the funding of student places. On pages 8 and 9 it makes the observation:
Higher education has been gradually evolving towards a system in which demand can play a larger role in the allocation of places.

For example, most domestic students now contribute towards the cost of their courses through the higher education contribution scheme--the current contribution is about 22 per cent--and there are also some full fee postgraduate courses, which are the specialised courses for the minority to which I have referred. However, emerging pressures arising from budgetary constraints are being reflected in growing levels of unmet demand for university places by domestic students. Added to these problems has been a high level of over-enrolment by institutions, as acceptance and re-enrolment rates have risen. The Government will not provide additional funds for these students, requiring their places to be financed from within already agreed allocations. There is this very significant conclusion to the report:
The current arrangements for funding higher education for domestic students are flawed.
I hope the Government heard this conclusion. It goes on:

Without a mechanism which takes better account of the costs and value to society and to the students of education services, decisions by Government and institutions as to how many places there are and how they are allocated will very likely be wrong.
The Industry Commission report continues:
The Commission recommends that the Government accept the need to alter current arrangements so that qualified domestic students are not precluded from a place in public universities.

That is the position which the Opposition has been advocating for the past seven years. It is about time that the Government responded. I think the only way ahead will be a change of government when our policies can be put in place. In drawing to a conclusion, I again quote from the report:

The Commission also recommends that it be sent a further reference on appropriate means to rectify the current system. The Commission sees the main focus of an inquiry as the means by which government and student resources should be allocated to the higher education sector, the need for a better matching of the demand by applicants with the availability of places, and the most efficient means of targeting assistance to meet concerns about access to higher education by disadvantaged groups.

The report goes on to say that, in the absence of such a reference, the Government should immediately implement one of the options for reform set out in the report--the one to which I have referred, which is, effectively, the Opposition policy.

In short, this document is a massive indictment of the Government's approach to funding higher education and its blinkered, ideologically driven refusal to allow domestic students the option of places in full fee courses over and above the places provided by the present funding system. I urge the Government to pay attention to the Industry Commission. So far, however, the indications seem to be that the Government is reluctant to do so and is refusing to consider a review of funding arrangements. This is very short-sighted of Mr Dawkins and Mr Baldwin. Let me make it quite clear that the Opposition would welcome a further public inquiry.

In chapter 8 of the report the Commission sets out the options it believes should be considered as the means of increasing the number of places available for Australian students. These options cover full fee places in addition to the Government-funded places. These full fee places can be paid for up front or, alternatively, paid for through a HECS mechanism, through varying the HECS charge for different courses or having an approach based on some form of voucher. That the Commission is considering alternatives to the present system is very much to be welcomed. It further fortifies the reforming approach I have outlined, which the Opposition has been proposing for some years.

In conclusion, put simply, the present Government has made a monumental mess of its policies towards overseas students and education exports. The Industry Commission has produced a report that is a devastating indictment of present arrangements. Clearly, only a change of government will lead to the policies that Australian higher education needs to get it right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-This topic of overseas students, the export of education and the charges we make to people from overseas who wish to participate in our education program has been the subject of a number of debates, a number of reports, legislation, amended legislation and discussion in general in this place. Quite often during these debates it has been possible to agree with the sentiments expressed on behalf of the coalition by Senator Teague. Little has changed in this instance because I find that Senator Teague has said much that I can agree with.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats see no reason to oppose the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill 1991. As Senator Teague did, I wish to take this opportunity at least to remind honourable senators of the sorts of issues that arise from the topic of export of education from Australia. The Government cannot be proud of its record in administering a program to sell Australian education to overseas students. Since at least 1987 problems have been identified and inequities have operated to the great disadvantage of many people who have made substantial payments to Australian tertiary institutions.

Normally, an important benefit to be derived from conducting a program of inviting overseas students to study in Australia would be the goodwill and the social or cultural exchanges that would take place during those study visits. I speak as a parent participant in the AFS exchange program, which is well known to me and my family. The basis for the existence of many similar programs is the fostering of enhanced international understanding and cooperation. This benefit and benefits like it have been compromised, if not ignored, by this Government's performance in the area of export education.

Australia stands guilty of great inequities brought about by the limp, jittery and uncertain administration of the program. Australia cannot be proud of its overseas reputation in this area. We can be accused rightly of being unreliable, untrustworthy and even inhumane in our administration of this program. Foreign students could be forgiven for thinking that Australia is more interested in their contribution to our balance of payments than in the intellectual and cultural aspects of such programs.

The failings of this program have led directly to the Government's pathetic patch-up attempt that we recently witnessed in the form of the legislation introduced to try to bring some stability and reliability into the program. That legislation was sent to a committee, which conducted an inquiry where numerous witnesses were heard and innumerable amendments proposed. Still that Bill, which was introduced in an attempt to bring some stability and reliability, did not contain a code of practice that could be adopted nationally. In other words, there was no indication of the standard of service overseas students could expect if they ventured into the purchase of Australian education.

Even after the inquiry, which raised a great number of uncertainties about the status of students' financial contributions to Australia, the Bill did not contain sufficient guarantees about the status of students' money. There was mention of the establishment of trust accounts, which were not real trust accounts but were described as such in the legislation. In the end, I share with the other Australian Democrats the inability to believe that the financial investment made by students would be secured by this legislation.

The legislation did not satisfactorily resolve the problems that had been identified previously in our export education program. These problems were also identified in the September Industry Commission report. Again, as Senator Teague has noted, one problem was that, in the words of the Industry Commission quoted by Senator Teague, the grafting of a market oriented export sector of higher education onto a highly regulated, largely government funded sector was bound to create tensions, if not absurdities. The Industry Commission report states:

Currently, numbers of Australians who qualify for entry are turned away from institutions because allocated government funding is not sufficient to provide them with places. To preserve the academic requirement of uniform entry standards, overseas students with similar ability are not admitted. As a result, the market for overseas students is restricted. It can be seen that the Government's regulation of the domestic market for education is also inhibiting the growth of the overseas market.

The Democrats cannot accept the coalition's assertion that that anomaly could be dealt with by enabling government institutions to set their own charges, to determine their own entry requirements and to have the option of charging fees for unfunded places. We argue that the answer is to fund sufficient places to meet those 30,000 or so Australian post-secondary students who are qualified to attend; in other words, to recognise the community benefit to be derived from proper investment in education, to recognise education as the priority it should be, and, I suggest, to match the rhetoric of Government statements about the clever country with actions that will ensure that the cleverness of this country does not continue to be squandered. I believe that this legislation does little to achieve that. Nevertheless, we will not oppose it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill 1991 sets the charges for 1992 for the subsidised overseas students scheme, which the Government is phasing out. New students are covered by a full fee and scholarship program, but a number of students still in the system are covered by the old scheme, and it is for these students that the charges are set by this Bill. My colleague Senator Teague has explained the position of the coalition in relation to the Bill and has said that we will not be opposing it.

SPEECH.PARA: I just wish to mention the obvious fact that Australian education is a highly desirable commodity, packaged, marketed and sold widely overseas. While there is opportunity for all higher education institutions in Australia to benefit from the export of Australian education, a particular opportunity exists and is already being taken advantage of by universities with a geographic and climatic proximity to our near neighbours in the Asia-Pacific region.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —-When I visited Hong Kong, Singapore and Indonesia earlier this year with an overseas parliamentary delegation, a lot of interest was shown by educational authorities for education within Australia. They were interested in education opportunities in regions that have the same climate as they do, particularly Singapore and Indonesia. Some of the educational authorities commented that some of the students who ended up in the more southern universities felt some difficulty in adjusting to the climate. For that reason, they were particularly interested in the James Cook University of North Queensland, which is based in Townsville as you, Mr Acting Deputy President, would know, and which also has a campus in Cairns. Currently, 355 overseas students study at James Cook University, compared with 126 students attending five years ago and only 90 attending about 10 years ago. In other words, in just 10 years there has been an almost 400 per cent increase in the number of overseas students at James Cook University.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst the number of students at James Cook University has grown from 3,737 in 1986 to just under 7,000 now, the percentage of overseas students has increased steadily from 3.4 per cent in 1986 to 5.2 per cent now. There is a very distinct focus in attracting students from Australia's near neighbours in the Asia-Pacific region, with 324 of the 355 students, or over 91 per cent of all foreign students, coming from either the Asian or the Pacific countries. The majority of these students are at James Cook University to take advantage of Australian education in commerce, economics and science. Of the overseas student population, a significant proportion--about 27 per cent--are engaged in postgraduate studies.

The principal attraction of JCU most often cited by foreign students is the climatic and geographic proximity to the Asia-Pacific region. However, there are other reasons why students are choosing James Cook University which are more related to the reputation it has developed in certain fields of study: for example, many overseas students come to James Cook University specifically because of its worldwide reputation in marine biology. It is expected that the reputation of the university will be more significant in the future in attracting foreign students, particularly by way of exchange schemes involving various specialist research centres developed recently at James Cook University: for example, the Tropical Freshwater Research Centre and the Coal-seam Gas Institute.

Currently, all overseas students are based in Townsville, principally due to the limited range of courses on offer and the lack of college support facilities at Cairns. However, as new courses are offered and the Cairns campus expands, that city will play a larger role in the export of Australian educational services. Currently, the breakdown of JCU's overseas student population in the four categories of overseas students is: 140 students sponsored by specific countries in specific disciplines whose fees and living expenses are met to a significant degree by Australian aid programs; 30 subsidised students paying an overseas student charge to the Commonwealth revenue and whom this particular piece of legislation affects; and 121 private fee-paying students and five exchange students and occupational trainees.

Next year it is expected that there will be well in excess of 400 overseas students at James Cook University, and the majority of them will be full fee-paying students. Most of these students have been drawn from Asian countries, including Singapore, Hong Kong, Taiwan and the Philippines as well as a substantial number from Fiji. James Cook University is very cognisant of the relationship with its near Asian neighbours. In fact, as I was told during my visit to Singapore, the Chancellor and Vice-chancellor of James Cook University conducted a graduation ceremony in Singapore at the end of the last student year.

James Cook University is leading the way in developing an international student community on campus. The educational and cultural benefits will be profound for both Australian and overseas students studying at JCU. The university's international student program also contributes financially to the development of the north Queensland university. As my colleague Senator Teague has said, we support the Bill, which in itself is uncontentious, and we support the transition towards a focus on full fee-paying students, a transition which will enhance efforts by our institutions to compete for valuable overseas benefits to be gained from the sale of Australian education.
