SPEECH.SPEAKER: Olsen Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Were I to stand here this evening to tell the Senate that I had in my hand a report which showed that only one young person in every 100 in Adelaide--99 in every 100 not matriculating, not attending a technical and further education college, college or university--received any education after the age of 16 years, it would be a page one scandal around this country. It would attract national media interest and attention for weeks, if not months.

SPEECH.PARA: Instead, I have a report which shows that only one young South Australian in every 100 who lives outside metropolitan Adelaide accesses any form of education after the age of 16 years. I know without any doubt that that dreadful statistic will raise only a whimper across Australia. I know that because two weeks ago I released that particular statistic in Adelaide. There was little media interest and only two radio stations ran the story. The local morning and evening papers both ran a short mention some days after the event, so small that it could be missed by many readers. There was no anger and no real concern from anyone. It was a typical dead issue as far as the media was concerned.

We really are such a hypocritical lot. We wax lyrical about the bush and its people, calling it the real Australia to our tourists. We think we are real Australians. We head out of the cities on holiday in what some would now describe as the city uniform--the four-wheel drive vehicle--but when the real Australian needs help and support, or even a little interest or sympathy, where is it?

TALK.START.PARA: —-What sympathy did you get from Senator Bolkus?

—-Very little from Senator Bolkus, as we have come to appreciate and understand. At present we have a crisis on the land which is so great that, for every hour of the day, somewhere in Australia a farmer closes his gates for the last time. It is a crisis so great that 99 out of every 100 children brought up in the real Australia of my home State of South Australia are being denied what is surely every Australian child's right--access to a full education.

SPEECH.PARA: Other States have nothing to be complacent about. While South Australia's figures are by far the worst, Tasmania and Western Australia are not far behind with an 80 per cent figure, Queensland with 65 per cent and New South Wales and Victoria each with 40 per cent. The latest statistics are contained in Towards a National Education and Training Strategy for Rural Australians, a report by the National Board of Employment, Education and Training. What this report uncovered is no less than a disaster for the future of rural Australia and particularly South Australia.

Rural Australia is not just a few hundred families scattered across the backblocks; it is almost one-third of our population, and almost every one of them is in some type of trouble. We have proof in black and white that a whole generation of rural South Australians is being forced to abandon education before they reach a level which would provide them with the basic trade skills, never mind a profession. In other words, we will not have rural raised doctors, vets, lawyers, architects, accountants, pharmacists or dentists. But, even worse, neither will we have those who make up the very core of those communities' self-sufficiency. I talk of carpenters, mechanics, plumbers, electricians and so the list goes on. We will not have hairdressers, bakers or butchers in our country towns; our country towns which act as the servicing network for the agricultural producers of this country.

Who provides the skills in the long term to keep these communities functioning? What of the teenagers who should be aiming for agricultural college to ensure that our properties are run by the most up-to-date methods, embracing technological change? One generation deprived is more than enough, but if policy is not addressed urgently to ensure that our rural young can attend a TAFE college, matriculate or advance to university, it will become two generations, and what then?

We talk consistently with disgust about racial discrimination and with dismay about age and sex discrimination, but right in our backyard is massive evidence of geographical discrimination. Who mentions that? When has this angle of discrimination even been the subject of heated debate? More than two years ago the Hawke Government declared that its goal was to increase transfer rates of rural students from school to higher education to a level comparable with metropolitan areas. Instead, as farm incomes have dropped--in many thousands of cases to zero during the current rural crisis--the Government has stood idly by doing nothing as rural students have been forced to give up education in their droves.

So much for the aim of the clever country we hear so much about. It is not that those students want to stop learning--they do not. Both they and their parents talk of what has happened with frustration and great despair. Usually, the situation arises when a rural student is advised to leave the local area school because it cannot provide the necessary subjects--that is, there is no curriculum guarantee--or the student needs a TAFE college for a trade.

For a city student that situation means no more than a mere change of bus route, plus some extra travelling time, if unlucky, but for a country student it signals a whole new and expensive way of life. Country students must move to the city and pay for accommodation, food, general education costs, books and city travel. At present, more often than not their parents simply cannot afford to provide that opportunity. Why? Because the Government considers most farming families to be asset rich and so they cannot access Austudy. Yet their so-called assets of land and machinery are no longer accepted as collateral by banks, they cannot borrow to educate their children on those tools of trade and they cannot sell because nobody wants to buy a property which, more often than not, has a negative income.

These families have little or no cash flow, no assets which can be considered of any value except on paper and no government help to educate their children. That is what this report is telling us clearly in black and white terms. Their choice is one of no choice. Their teenagers must drop out of the education system, and they are doing that.

It is worth pointing out that the latest report is not the first to be critical of the present attitude to rural education. The first report, entitled Student Financial Assistance, was released in March by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training and was severely critical of the declining opportunities available to rural students. Significantly, the Government members on the Committee agreed in total with the Committee's report.

The Government has also ignored the coalition's proposals, which were passed in the Senate, for hardship provisions to be included in the Austudy regulations to give some recognition and relief to these families and some financial encouragement to access education in the metropolitan areas. Such provisions would go a long way towards helping the rural community access education by investigating fully the real, as opposed to the paper, value of family assets and providing help accordingly.

We need the rural community. It literally provides us with our daily bread. This should not be forgotten, but unfortunately it is. It seems that most of Australia's city dwellers, the media and certainly the present Government have forgotten how vital the rural community's survival is to our own. There is an urgent need to address this problem. It behoves every member of parliament to recognise the problem and to ensure that the geographical discrimination is removed so that the most urbanised state in the most urbanised country in the world is able to reach out to all of its people and give them all equal access to education.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I shall focus in this adjournment speech on the continuing nuclear perils, notwithstanding the welcome initiatives by Presidents Bush and Gorbachev in recent days. On another occasion I will pay attention to the many worrying nuclear weapons programs still under way. The note of caution expressed by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) in Question Time today is certainly valid. There are many programs still apace, including the Trident submarines, ICBMs, the stealth bomber and the star wars programs which, on the nuclear weapons side of the ledger, are very worrying indeed. Tonight I will give an update of a closely related partner, the nuclear power industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite the decision of the Australian Labor Party not to change its illogical three mines policy at the Hobart conference in June, the uranium mining lobby is continuing its hype about the virtues of nuclear power, seeking to take advantage of the economic recession and fallacious arguments about the greenhouse effect. What all these arguments seem to ignore is the growing crop of warnings from around the world as we learn about the legacy of reliance on the nuclear industry and the long term effects that the safe energy movement has forecast for many years.

Parallel to these warnings come new developments in safe energy which point us on the road not taken, as Amory Lovins put it some 15 years ago in the United States. Thankfully, his voice is being heard a lot more now than it was then. I would like to cite a few examples and draw them to the attention of those who still believe in the benefits of uranium mining and who continue to propose more uranium mines, uranium enrichment facilities and nuclear waste burial sites in Australia.

From India comes a horrific report of birth defects, mystery illnesses and deaths among villagers living near a crippled nuclear power station in Rajasthan in the north-west. Private doctors and nuclear experts conducted a two-week survey of 3,000 villagers living within 10 kilometres of the plant. Village elders and midwives allege that the number of children born with deformities, including paralysis or missing limbs or organs, has doubled in the past two years. Those who conducted the survey believe that scientific analysis of the results will reveal serious radiation contamination and that radiation leaks have damaged people's genes, doubled the number of spontaneous abortions, made at least half the men impotent and many women infertile, caused chronic tiredness and killed thousands of cattle and goats.

India's Atomic Energy Regulatory Board admits that one of the plant's two reactors has had leakage problems since the early 1980s and that the reactor has had to be shut down at least 250 times in its first decade. Predictably, the same regulatory board denies that the villagers' problems are caused by the nuclear plant. Many of the villagers have been hired as temporary workers and claim that they have been left in contaminated areas at times of radiation leaks. They are paid at three times the normal rate to work in areas where the permanent staff refuse to go.

The Rajasthan plant was the prototype copy of a plant built at Douglas Point in Ontario, Canada, which was closed in the mid-1980s after spewing 2,700 litres of heavy water into a nearby lake. The arrogance of nuclear experts is the same all over the world. Despite many accidents and other problems at nuclear plants, such as the Tarapur reactor, which scientists say is the world's worst performing and most polluting nuclear power reactor, India is building 10 more nuclear power plants. Another six are planned after that, including two being purchased from the Soviet Union. I doubt that many people would be confident about Soviet nuclear technology post-Chernobyl.

We have the legacy of nuclear power in eastern and central Europe. The President of Bulgaria has recently said that his country could not afford to close down its sole nuclear plant, even though it has been declared unsafe by experts. After inspecting the plant in June this year, International Atomic Energy Agency officials said that the reactors were in a very poor condition, with a number of safety-relevant deficiencies. The IAEA spokesman said that his agency had recommended that the four reactors be closed. Two of the four reactors had been shut down and the third was working at half capacity because of oil leakage. Of course, the whole plant has not been closed down.

Further north, Austria is worried that a nuclear station at Jaslovske Bohunice, just inside Czechoslovakia, is in such a dangerous state that Vienna is at risk from a Chernobyl-style meltdown. An Austrian expert commission says that the station is obsolete and a serious security risk because it was built in the 1960s with a design life of 25 years. As a result, there is no full containment of the reactor in the modern sense and there are no secondary backup systems for electrical circuits, which are essential. Radioactivity has also caused embrittlement of the steel reactor pressure vessels. The experts are particularly worried about weak joints, which they say are virtually impossible to repair. There is insufficient fire protection in the building and the reactor was not built to withstand earthquakes.

Czechoslovakia claims that it has no money to renovate the plant and has appealed to the European Community for funds to do the job. There was an accident at the plant in 1990 when underground drinking water was contaminated after radioactive waste leaked from a storage tank in the plant, which had already been shut down temporarily after two serious accidents. An investigation was carried out after it was discovered that the liquid had seeped into subterranean streams. The number of people affected in the area is still unknown. The threat of an accident is of sufficient concern to the Austrian health Ministry that it will be, or is already, distributing potassium iodine tablets free to children, pregnant women and nursing mothers. Czechoslovakia has begun providing pills within a 32-kilometre radius of the offending plant in southern Slovakia.

Former East Germany's only reactor at Griefswald has been closed down. Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Bulgaria are now faced with a growing pile of highly radioactive waste that they cannot handle as they do not have long term storage facilities. The Soviet Union will no longer take back spent fuel without charge. None of its former satellites can afford to pay the commercial cost of reprocessing now that the Soviet Union has ended trade with eastern Europe on the convertible rouble basis.

The Soviet Union, too, has more than its fair share of nuclear problems, particularly with the legacy of Chernobyl. We have become aware of this legacy in Australia with the visit of the children from Chernobyl, including those who came to Parliament House earlier this year. In April this year, Soviet scientists who had visited the Chernobyl complex reported that the biggest danger to nearby people is caused by the declining condition of the reactor and its protective concrete shell. If part of the reactor or shell were to collapse, hundreds of tonnes of radioactive dust would be released into the atmosphere, with heavy pollution of the surrounding area, though probably not on the international scale of the original disaster in 1986.

The IAEA-World Health Organisation report on the impact of Chernobyl, which did not contain data for the 30-kilometre exclusion zone or for the emergency workers, painted a picture of little impact from radioactivity, although the severe psychological impact was stressed. The nuclear industry, of course, jumped on the report as proof that the world's worst nuclear accident had little effect. Anecdotal evidence of massive casualties among the liquidators continues to reach the West.

My research officer was in Japan in August this year. He met with one of the Estonians who was sent to Chernobyl as a liquidator in 1986; that is, the army of workers forced to control the disaster, many without protection or monitoring equipment. This man reported many problems amongst those from the Baltic states and other Soviet republics who were sent to Chernobyl in 1986. That is why he was with a Baltic states delegation visiting Hiroshima. That city has finally recognised the victims of Chernobyl as hibakusha, or nuclear victims, despite efforts by the authorities in Japan to make a distinction between the victims of the nuclear power industry and the victims of the atomic bombs dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki in 1945. This is for obvious reasons: Japan has a number of nuclear reactors.

This year is also the year in which Japan's boast of the best maintained nuclear industry in the world has been shattered by a near meltdown at the Miahama No. 2 reactor and revelations of a further series of incidents at other reactors around the country. On 9 February, Miahama No. 2 came close to a meltdown when a steam tube fissured and emergency equipment failed to operate. In a frightening parallel to the Three Mile Island accident, the control room staff were unprepared for the situation and had to operate outside known scenario training. Operators had ignored repeated warnings of rising levels of radioactivity for one and a half hours and continued to run the reactor at full power. At the critical moment, safety valves failed to operate.

It has come to light that a steam tube failed and leaked radioactivity. The main steam isolation valve failed to shut down under operator control and was closed manually seven minutes later. The emergency core cooling system failed effectively to cool the core, raising the cooling water temperature to boiling point and thus rendering the coolant totally ineffective. Radioactive steam had to be vented to reduce pressure in the reactor.

Japanese authorities at first denied that the coolant had boiled, although there were reports that escaping radioactivity was detected. No information has been released on the state of the fuel assemblies. Kansai Electric, the plant's owners, have said that they will not inspect them unless instructed to do so by the Government. Initial investigation found that the steam tube failed because its anti-vibration bar had been incorrectly fitted--in other words, the human error factor, which is common in most of these reactor problems. The most recent reports have shown that a Mitsubishi heavy industries employee had sawed through the bars, not realising their importance. Mitsubishi has since accepted liability for the accident.

Kansai Electric also operate the No. 2 reactor at the Takahama plant in Fukui Prefecture, 320 kilometres west of Tokyo. It was shut down on 21 March after a total of 163 damaged steam generator tubes were found in a regular inspection of the plant. Of the 163 damaged tubes, apparently corroded by chemicals, 133 will be repaired and the others plugged up, a common practice in the nuclear industry. The new work will bring the number plugged to 1,571, or more than 15 per cent of the 10,164 steam generator tubes at the Takahama plant, which began operation in 1975. Steam generators are regarded as the Achilles heel of pressurised water reactors. Despite the seriousness of these accidents, the nuclear industry is still reluctant to be open about these problems. The authorities concerned have released important facts only a few at a time, sometimes long after the accidents have occurred.

There are those who argue that all this proves that nuclear industry is still okay in the advanced industrialised countries, because we have learned from mistakes earlier on and accidents only happen in the Soviet bloc and developing countries where safety standards are not so strict, even if the reactors are designed by North American or European companies. Yet we have only to turn to France, the United Kingdom and the United States to see how they are now being troubled by problems within their nuclear industries. Plagued by generic faults, the pressurised water reactor program of the French nuclear industry has failed to deliver long-promised economies of scale. The Super Phoenix fast breeder reactor has proved to be a complete economic failure. It has been demoted from commercial demonstration status to experimental full scale status.

The industry continues to groan under the weight of its debt. While it claims that its debts are no greater than those of fossil fuel based systems, Electricite de France has been unable to reimburse even a fraction of the $43.8 billion debt contracted for the construction of nuclear power plants. This is a figure worth noting by those who, like the Liberal Party in Western Australia, want to build nuclear power plants in this country. They are enormously expensive. These people fail to recognise the cost involved in paying for a reactor that would have to be imported, thus adding substantially to our balance of payments deficit and the national debt, about which normally they like to rubbish the Labor Government.

As for the coalition's commitment to expand the uranium industry, it too might care to note that the French nuclear giant, Cogema, is to close another uranium mine. This is in line with the company's policy of withdrawal from mining because of the world surplus of uranium and low profitability of French mines.

In the United Kingdom, it having been finally acknowledged that the nuclear industry is not a profitable concern, it has been recently revealed that levels of radioactivity in the lake next to the Trawsfynydd nuclear plant in north Wales are higher than anywhere in Britain, apart from the Sellafield reprocessing plant in Cumbria in the north-west of England.

A confidential report by the Central Electricity Generating Board revealed that radioactive caesium 137 levels were 10 times higher than previously thought. The report was prepared as part of a feasibility study for a pressurised water reactor at the site. The necessity to drain the lake and enlarge it for a pressurised water reactor would have released caesium and plutonium dust and allowed it to blow about. Local people eat fish from the lake and it is also used as a source of power for the Maentrwrog hydro-electric power station.

The British nuclear industry has also decided to create a national nuclear waste dump at the infamous Sellafield nuclear complex, despite the fact that the local geology is widely acknowledged to be unsuitable. Radioactive waste will be stored there for 10,000 years and beyond, and the nuclear industry ultimately envisages the storage of up to 1.4 million tonnes of low level waste and 600,000 tonnes of intermediate waste.

Sellafield was chosen because it already produces 60 per cent of Britain's nuclear waste, and transport costs to other sites considered in northern Scotland would have been prohibitive, adding more than $2 billion in transport costs over 50 years. Conservationists pointed out the irony of the fact that Sellafield was discovered to be so suitable for storing nuclear waste, given that it produces two-thirds of the country's nuclear waste in the first place.

Another enormous forthcoming expense for the British nuclear industry will be the cost of decommissioning the eight Magnox stations which are all due to shut down before the end of the century. The cost of surveillance alone at a shutdown Magnox station runs at around $1.5 million a year, and no-one can calculate the full cost of decommissioning such a reactor. Decommissioning costs around the globe are about to explode. This cost has never been counted or calculated in any way by the nuclear industry. It is never counted as part of the cost of establishing plant, in the same way as disposal of the waste is never counted as a cost when the economics of nuclear power are so promoted by the industry.

In the United States, following an accident in August at the Nine Mile Point nuclear power plant in New York State, officials declared a site area emergency, the second highest level of urgency under federal guidelines. A month before, there was an accident at the Oyster Creek power plant in New Jersey, and a number of analysts have continued to argue that the US nuclear industry is doomed, because of public opposition and high construction costs, even though the nuclear industry continues to wage a relentless campaign to promote nuclear power, arguing that it is non-polluting, would cut United States reliance on imported crude oil and that it has a proven safety record. At the moment only about eight plants are under construction and not one has been ordered since 1978.

The major headache for the US nuclear industry at the moment is the continuation of problems that have come to light around the nuclear weapons production complexes at Hanford, Savannah River and Rocky Flats. The US Government has doubled its budget to repair and modernise the Savannah River site alone, spending more than $2.5 billion this year to do it up, and having spent well over $2 billion to repair three old reactors since late 1988.

The US Energy Department has proposed a huge program, estimated to cost $200 billion to $300 billion and to take at least 30 years, to take old nuclear weapons plants out of service, clean up hundreds of square miles of ground contaminated by chemical and radioactive wastes and to build a more compact nuclear weapons industry. That is all rather worrying, despite the fact that President Bush has made some very welcome cuts to the nuclear weapons arsenal in the last week or so. The latest Bush Administration proposal outlines cuts of 30 per cent to 85 per cent over the next 25 years, reducing production to possibly as few as six or seven sites, instead of the current 13 major facilities scattered over 12 states.

I turn to another disastrous aspect of the nuclear industry. In September this year an IAEA report showed that nuclear weapons or material had been lost at sea more than 30 times over the past 40 years. Reactors or components from submarines and spacecraft, along with missiles that could carry nuclear weapons, were among items involved in maritime accidents. The draft report, an inventory of 31 radioactive accidents or losses since 1950, was prepared for the International Maritime Organisation. It lists nuclear weapons aboard the British warship HMS Sheffield, sunk during the 1982 Falklands-Malvinas war, and a Polaris missile lost off the coast of Florida in 1985 by the Royal Navy submarine HMS Resolution.

A few days earlier Soviet experts were expressing concern about a Soviet nuclear-armed submarine which sank off the coast of Norway in April 1989, and which they say will have to be raised from a depth of 1,700 metres because it could begin leaking radiation. The submarine sank after catching fire, and slammed nose first into the seabed, damaging its bow and the compartment housing two nuclear-tipped torpedoes. In the same week, on 24 September, a Soviet member of parliament from the northern port of Murmansk alleged that the Soviet Union had dumped radioactive waste in leaky containers into shallow waters off its north coast for more than 20 years, while publicly claiming it was being stored on land.

The dumped waste included the damaged core from the Lenin, the nuclear-powered icebreaker which suffered a meltdown in 1966 or 1967, though the records are not quite clear on that. Andrei Zolotkov said that documents showed that containers used to dispose of nuclear waste in the 1960s and 1970s tended to float so `they punched two holes in the sealed containers, the water filled them and they sank'. One container giving off high levels of radiation was washed up on the island of Novaya Zemlya in 1984, but was thrown back into the water.

A British nuclear engineer, John Large, estimated that the Soviets had dumped 6,750 tonnes of solid waste and about 16,000 cubic metres of liquid radioactive waste, although the Soviet military had consistently stated that it had stored all its radioactive waste on land. However, they refused to permit independent inspection of the facilities.

In recent weeks we have been hearing a lot about Iraq's nuclear capabilities, although it is interesting to note that there has been little coverage of how Iraq acquired this technology during the years when Saddam Hussein was a good guy and supported by the West as well as Saudi Arabia and Kuwait when he took on the Ayatollah Khomeini's regime in Iran between 1980 and 1988.

Concern about the revelations from Iraq of the extent of its nuclear program has heightened the need for tougher safeguards on the other nuclear research going on in many other countries. What shocked the United Nations team in Iraq was the ease with which Iraq was able to hide so much, despite IAEA inspections. If Iraq could do this as a signatory of the nuclear non-proliferation treaty, then so could any other country. The IAEA estimates that there are more than 300 research reactors around the world. New nuclear and other technologies, large scale plutonium reprocessing plants, laser isotope separation technology and the spread of super-computers all threaten to make guarding against nuclear proliferation more difficult.

Another worrying trend is that near-nuclear weapon states such as Argentina, Brazil, India, Israel, Pakistan and South Africa can now export a wide range of nuclear materials and plants. Therefore, the pattern of developing states acquiring technology from developed non-proliferation treaty signatory states might well be breaking down.

All this would be bad news if it were not for exciting new developments in alternative safe energy in Australia, which also offer export potential. The main problem seems to be the time warp that older politicians and a handful of mining executives and scientists seem to be caught in, refusing to acknowledge that nuclear power has no future and that the world cannot afford it and does not need it.

Last month there was exciting news that Australian solar energy scientists had scored a breakthrough in materials design that could revolutionise the world's power industry by the year 2000. For the first time, the material will allow the mass production of high efficiency, low cost solar collectors. These will produce steam for power generation at a cost below that of many fossil fuel or nuclear systems. The collectors will also generate power at half the price of the world's most economic solar power station in California. With this advance, solar energy would go from being merely a promising line of research to an economically viable alternative to coal, natural gas or nuclear power. It would also provide one solution to the global impact of burning fossil fuels and respite from the greenhouse effect.

Unlike solar cells, which use silicon to transform sunshine directly into electric power, the new material--dubbed `high efficiency surface' or HES--is an example of solar thermal power because it absorbs the sun's rays to produce steam. Australia now has the world's most efficient solar thermal collector and the most efficient solar cell. For these developments I would like to pay tribute to Dr David Mills, the solar cell's co-inventor with Mr Qi-Chu Zhang, and I wish all the best to these partners in the consortium, who plan to develop the technology further--and they should get full government backing for their project.

Earlier this year in April, Gerald Braun, Research Director for California's Pacific Gas and Electric Utility, which has 12 million customers, told a Canberra workshop on energy efficiency and renewable energy that Australia looks to be in a good position to develop an early market for alternative energy generation technologies, with major global significance and therefore major export potential. He pointed out that Australia's need to move energy to a sparse population over vast distances could be a very expensive proposition in conventional terms and in such cases localised use of renewables such as wind and some solar technology could very clearly be the most economic choice. He said:

Australia really has an opportunity to develop that market internally and then turn that industry's attention to the tremendous markets in parts of the world where the conventional energy distribution grid is not well established but there is still a need for power for development.

It is worth noting that the Pacific Gas and Electric Utility used to be strongly committed to nuclear power in the 1970s but is now committed to both conservation measures and renewable sources of power, such as wind, solar and conversion of waste heat, as both cost effective and environmentally sound. As Mr Braun told his audience:
We decided to be part of the solution, rather than fighting it.

It would be inspiring if some of those people still committed to the nuclear option in Australian politics were prepared to admit that times have changed and, like Mr Braun, to take this exciting new energy path into the next century. What we have to note is that the momentum has changed, with new technologies becoming cheaper and conventional sources, for a variety of reasons, more expensive. As Mr Braun pointed out:
Over the next 10 years with more stringent environmental legislation that trend will accelerate.

There will be those who still argue that we could sell uranium to developing nations such as Indonesia, but they should realise how inappropriate the nuclear option is for these countries as well, particularly when safeguards are not so stringent and when they run into massive debt paying for nuclear reactors that now cost up to $1 billion each. We only need to look at the Philippines to see how much its nuclear power plant is costing it in interest repayments, and the nuclear power plant at Bataan did not even come on stream to produce energy. There are many exciting new developments that Australians could be researching, such as hydrogen, now emerging as the latest dark horse to alter the betting odds in a field dominated by fossil fuels.

Another related area for Australia is our future as a supplier of clean food. I quote the Executive Chairman of ICM Australia, Doug Shears, who told the recent Grains 2000 conference in September that Australia has a marvellous opportunity staring it in the face. In a world that has been contaminated by Chernobyl, acid rain, polluted waterways and overuse of chemicals, Australia is relatively environmentally clean. The National Farmers Federation is beginning to understand the opportunity, and I think it should be promoting even harder than it is the fact that Australia's food is uncontaminated. Of course, it would be on really strong ground if it could claim that our produce was organically grown. Chemical-free food is a huge growth area. Examples of what I am driving at are a packet of Uncle Toby's organic Vita Brits and David Williams, who farms 700 hectares at Breeza, near Gunnedah. He is a biodynamic farmer who got $200 a tonne for his 300 hectares of wheat last year while his neighbours got only $75. There is a very good market for organically grown grains.

Australia needs men and women of vision to get out of this reliance on an old and discredited technology and who are prepared to take advantage of exciting new trends that will create the jobs and export opportunities that we so desperately need.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Just one month ago when the Senate was last sitting I raised what I considered to be a grave injustice that the Australian Taxation Office was perpetrating against the taxpayers of this country. Various articles and evidence led me to believe that the ATO was using its press releases to give an incorrect impression of people and companies in question. I referred to a number of articles printed in the Australian voicing Mr Boucher's comments on the auditing of Australia's top companies and in particular to an incorrect press release, No. 20 of April 1991.

SPEECH.PARA: This press release was being used by tax commentators in this country as a way of informing taxpayers to be aware of using false tax file numbers or of lodging incorrect tax returns. The press release in question intimated that prison sentences and hefty fines would be imposed if the aforesaid occurred. At the time, I pointed out that the ATO needed to be careful of the implications of its comments, that the press release referred to in my speech had been proved to be incorrect and that the ATO had been informed of this in no uncertain terms. Yet at the time no retraction was forthcoming, and my adjournment speech called for a retraction.

I am pleased to say that the ATO has heeded those words. On 30 September I noticed in the Examiner, a newspaper published in Launceston, that a letter from Mr V. T. Mitchell, the First Assistant Commissioner of Tax Audit, was published. This letter retracted the aforementioned press release. I quote the last paragraph:

This error is the result of a mistake in a press release issued by the Tax Office on April 30, 1991. Since that release, the Tax Office checking processes have been tightened to ensure that similar mistakes are not made again.

However, on perusing the various Tasmanian papers and the various taxation, accounting and business journals that came across my desk and my staffer's desk, I have not found that letter in any other publication. I would like to ask Senator Button, who is the Minister representing the Treasurer (Mr Kerin), whether he could investigate the matter further and inform this chamber as to the procedures followed by the Australian Taxation Office in having the retraction more widely circulated.

I believe that there is a need to maintain a good relationship between the Australian Taxation Office and the Australian taxpayer because it is a matter of grave importance under a system of self-assessment, and again I say how pleased I am to see that retraction. However, as we all know, self-assessment implies a trust given to the taxpayer. This trust should be returned by the Australian Taxation Office and should be displayed by the same honesty that it expects from taxpayers.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.19 p.m.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Foreign Investment Review Board: Northern Territory Cattle Industry

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 January 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to the sale of a half interest in Northern Territory (NT) cattle properties owned by Mr Warren Anderson to Indonesian interests, was the FIRB aware that Mr Anderson has a 49 per cent interest in the Indonesian registered company, PT Tipperary Indonesia, which will fatten and slaughter cattle transported to Lampung from the NT.
(2) Is the Taxation Office aware of the potential this creates for profit sharing and the avoidance of Australian tax.
(3) Did FIRB take the potential for tax avoidance into account when making a recommendation on the Indonesian investment in the NT cattle industry in association with Mr Anderson.
(4) Who did FIRB believe was the company buying the half interest in Mr Anderson's NT interests at the time approval was granted.
(5) Who did FIRB believe were the shareholders and directors in this company at the time approval was granted.
(6) What was the company name and those of the shareholders and the directors who first applied for investment approval.
(7) Who does FIRB believe are the directors and shareholders in PT Tipperary Indonesia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government was aware of the intention of Mr Warren Anderson and Indonesian interests to set up a new joint venture company (in which Mr Anderson would hold a 49 per cent interest) which would establish and operate a cattle feedlot in Indonesia. The Government was also aware that the parties proposed to export cattle from the Northern Territory cattle stations to Indonesia where they would be fattened and slaughtered in accordance with Moslem rites.

(2) The Government expects all taxpayers, including foreign investors, to refrain from making use of any profit shifting arrangements, whether by transfer pricing or other means, that could reduce their own proper Australian taxation liabilities or those of Australian enterprises. The provisions of Division 13 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 authorise the Commissioner of Taxation to determine that an arm's length consideration will be substituted for income tax purposes in place of that adopted in a profit shifting arrangement. Subject to powers of remission, a statutory penalty is also imposed where Division 13 is applied.
In addition, for a number of years, the Government has been implementing significant and strategic taxation initiatives to stamp out profit shifting including:
1 July 1987--the introduction of the thin capitalisation rules which deny deductibility of interest payments by companies, trusts and partnerships where certain debt:equity ratios are exceeded;
1 July 1988--the introduction of the debt creation rules which deny deductibility of interest payments in certain capital restructuring arrangements; and
from 1 July 1990 the introduction of the Controlled Foreign Companies legislation which will bring to book unremitted income which had been accruing off-shore in non-taxable forms.

(3) The potential for tax avoidance is taken into account by the Government in its assessment of the national interest implications of foreign investment proposals. The Australian Taxation Office has been notified of this proposal.
(4) The Government believed the purchaser of the 50 per cent interest in Mr Anderson's Northern Territory cattle properties was Tovehead Pty Limited.

(5) At the time approval was granted the Government believed the shares in Tovehead Pty Limited were held by Crosshatch Limited, and its directors to be Mr Nalin Rathod, Mr Todung Barita and Mr Aburizal Bakrie.

(6) The company that first applied for foreign investment approval was P.T. Maha Phala Cakti. The directors and shareholders of that company were Mas Japto Sulistie Suryosumarno and Kanjing Roden Mas Hario Sutaryo-Sumarno.

(7) The Government believes the shareholders of PT Tipperary Indonesia to be Mr Warren Anderson, PT Bakrie Nusantara Corporation and Mas Japto Sulisto Suryosumarno and its directors to be Mr Arifin Prauirakusumah, Mr Yosef Inkiriwang, Mr Peter Rolf Swain and Mr Peter Stubbs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 28 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Minister reconsider the recent draft ruling by the Australian Taxation Office which intends to apply withholding tax to the computer industry for the sales of shrink-wrap software, which could cost the industry $50 million a year and may have a backlash effect, with other countries attempting to impose their own withholding tax for software, which might damage the export potential for Australian software houses.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Commissioner of Taxation is responsible for administering the tax law and ensuring that taxpayers pay the correct amount of tax. Taxation Rulings are issued by the Commissioner to assist taxpayers by advising them of his view of the law. Prior to their issue a draft of the Ruling is circulated to interested parties so that their views can be considered in coming to a final decision. The draft ruling on computer software is currently being reconsidered by the Commissioner's officers in the light of comments made by industry representatives.

The Commissioner advised that the draft ruling is primarily concerned about the nature of receipts from the marketing of computer software including shrink-wrap software. The draft ruling, broadly speaking, states that it is the nature of the agreements between the parties which determine the nature of the receipts and the tax consequences which follow.

If the agreements reflect a licence arrangement between the parties, receipts under the agreements are royalties. In this case, where the licence fees are being remitted to a non-resident, the payer must retain and forward to the Commissioner a part of the fees to meet that non-resident's tax liability. The non-resident's actual income tax liability will be refunded. The non-resident will also get a credit in its home country for any Australian tax paid.

If, on the other hand, the agreements reflect sale of the software between the parties, the receipts will be the proceeds of the sale of goods. In that case the arrangements are structured so that no Australian tax liability will ordinarily arise in the non-resident's hands because the income for tax purposes would be derived from overseas sources where the sale occurred.

The Commissioner, after meeting industry representatives on 24 May 1991, is awaiting a submission from the Australian Information Industry Association before he reaches his final and concluded view on the issue.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 29 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When examining matters referred to it, is the Industry Commission (IC) required to take environmental matters into account in the formulation of its recommendations.

(2) Did the Treasurer, on 6 December 1990, refer the following matter to the IC for inquiry: (a) the costs and benefits for Australian industry of an international consensus in favour of a stabilisation of emissions of greenhouse gases not controlled by the Montreal Protocol on Ozone Depleting Substances, based on 1988 levels, by the year 2000 and a reduction in those emissions by 20 per cent by the year 2005; (b) the new opportunities that could arise for Australian industry as a result of that international consensus; and (c) how Australia would best prepare itself to respond to those costs and benefits.

(3) In its examination of the greenhouse matter referred to it, will the IC be expected to examine, inter alia, the following: (a) tradeable emissions; (b) carbon tax; (c) evaluation of costs; (d) renewable energy; (e) 20 per cent reduction in greenhouse gas emissions - how does Australia cut up the cake; (f) can market measures achieve reductions in greenhouse gases; (g) is Australian industry developing environmentally sound greenhouse strategies; and (h) will consumers pay to reduce the greenhouse effect.

(4) Why has the Treasurer allowed the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to commit at least $150,000 of taxpayers' money to consultancies to consider and report on the same matters as have already been referred to the IC.
(5) What is the total professional staffing of the IC's secretariat engaged on the greenhouse reference.
(6) Has the IC formulated a budget for the greenhouse inquiry; if so, what is it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, under Section 8(4) of the Industry Commission Act 1989.

(3) To assist potential participants in its inquiry the Industry Commission released a paper in January 1991 setting out the issues it saw being important in preparing its report. Given the topic under consideration, a wide range of issues were canvassed, including the appropriateness of different policies to achieve a reduction in greenhouse gas emissions. Participants were asked for information and views on these issues and any other issues they thought should be included in the report. Public submissions and evidence provided at public hearings have addressed all of the matters referred to in the honourable senator's question. The Industry Commission has regard to issues raised in submissions and evidence it receives when preparing its report to Government.

(4) The Industry Commission inquiry is open to submissions from State and Commonwealth Departments, including the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (DASETT). It is therefore the responsibility of the DASETT portfolio to decide whether consultants are engaged to provide material for inclusion in a submission by that Department to the Industry Commission inquiry.
(5) Seven professional staff are engaged full-time and five engaged part-time on the inquiry.

(6) In addition to the salaries of Commissioners and staff, the reference has a budget of $120,000 to cover expenses involved in community consultations (including the conduct of two rounds of public hearings), information gathering, and the production and publication of draft and final reports. Salaries are not separately budgeted.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, upon notice, on 23 July 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many SkillShare local projects are currently operating in each State and Territory and how many of these are operated by: (a) local government authorities; (b) church bodies; (c) non-church, non-government welfare bodies; or (d) any other and what types of agencies.
(2) What is the ASL the department dedicates to SkillShare.

(3) Of SkillShare participants who completed a SkillShare course during 1990-91, what was the average length of time spent on SkillShare courses and how many of these were awarded the formal training allowance.
(4) In what way does the department ensure that funds allocated to SkillShare projects are properly spent and fully accounted for.
(5) In what way does the department assess the success of each SkillShare project to determine whether funding of each particular project ought to continue.
(6) What was the state-by-state allocation for the 1990-91 SkillShare appropriation.

(7) During 1990-91, which SkillShare projects were allowed to commence even though the level of community funding was less than 15 per cent of the total project cost and what were the reasons for this.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The table at Attachment 1 provides information on the number of SkillShare projects in each State and Territory. Data on the types of agencies which operate projects is not collected within the management information system for the SkillShare Program. I asked the Department of Employment, Education and Training to manually categorise project sponsors by type of agency as requested by the honourable senator and was informed that, of the 366 SkillShare projects in 1991:
(a) 27 SkillShare projects are sponsored by local government sponsors;
(b) 46 SkillShare projects are sponsored by identified church bodies; and
(c) the remaining 297 (81 per cent) projects are sponsored by non-church, non-government welfare bodies.

(2) The Department has allocated ASL of 106.9 in 1990-91 and 106.9 in 1991-92 to SkillShare, which has been supplemented by 9.5 ASL associated with the enhancements announced in the 12 March 1991 Statement.

(3) The average length of time spent on SkillShare courses by 93,500 participants in 1990-91 was 116 hours. Of these, approximately 25,750 participants were in receipt of the formal training allowance.

(4) SkillShare Sponsors are funded to operate projects at one of several core levels for each calendar year and may also additionally receive one or more funding modules of fixed amounts to conduct specific supplementary services.
Sponsors are required to sign a formal SkillShare Memorandum of Agreement (MOA) with the Commonwealth before the release of the first instalment of SkillShare funds.

The MOA requires, inter alia, that the Sponsor provides the Department within 21 days of the end of each quarterly funding period, with a satisfactory Program Performance Quarterly Report which incorporates a financial income and expenditure acquittal statement, certified as correct by an authorised project officer.
The MOA further requires that within two months after the end of the annual funding period the Sponsor furnishes the Department, through the Area Director, in respect of that funding period;
(a) a statement of receipts, including interest earned on bank accounts, and expenditure, audited by an independent Auditor,

(b) a certificate signed by an Authorised Officer certifying that SkillShare funds received for the funding period were expended in respect of the project and in accordance with the MOA and a statement from an independent Auditor that, in the Auditor's opinion, the certificate is accurate,

(c) a statement of Contributions in Cash and Contributions in Kind obtained during the funding period prepared by the Sponsor and a statement from an independent Auditor that in the Auditor's opinion the statement is correct; and

(d) a statement of assets purchased wholly or partly from SkillShare funds and assets purchased with SkillShare funds which were disposed of during the funding period and a statement from an independent Auditor that in the Auditor's opinion the statement is accurate.

(5) At the time of signing the SkillShare Memorandum of Agreement (MOA), the Sponsor negotiates an annual program of activities and agreed level of performance, and other conditions, for each project with the Department of Employment, Education and Training. The agreed areas of compliance apply to the following areas of operation:
(i) the delivery of courses and activities offered by the Project;
(ii) the minimum number of participants to be assisted; and
(iii) the per cent Successful Placement Rate, where this measure indicates the number of participants assisted by the Project who obtain employment, or go on to further education or training.
Projects are required to provide regular progress reports in these terms, (as specified in the MOA), to the Department.
Continued payment of grant instalments to the Sponsor is dependent upon continued satisfactory performance by the project on a pro rata basis compared with the agreed levels of performance.
Other matters which are taken into account in assessing project performance are:
(i) other courses/activities planned for the remainder of the year;
(ii) activities completed or underway for which results are not yet known;
(iii) the extent to which any Special Conditions attached to the funding have been met by that date, and
(iv) where the Sponsor was funded in a previous year for that project, the extent to which agreed performance levels were met in that year.

Continued payment of funding instalments is also dependent on compliance by the Sponsor with contractual financial requirements, including satisfactory audited acquittal and finalisation of previous SkillShare funding payments, and the provision of satisfactory quarterly SkillShare Project Returns.

Sponsors who wish to continue a project in the following year, apply for funding and need to meet both the minimum and priority criteria as specified in the published Sponsor Guidelines. Assessment takes account of the level and nature of project performance, with particular attention to the number of participants from the previous year's program who were successfully assisted into employment, further education or training, with consideration also being given to the prevailing conditions in local labour markets.
(6) The state-by-state allocation for SkillShare is set out in the table below.

(1) Support Costs includes: Insurance, Human Resources Development Training, Consultative Committee, Curriculum Development, Enterprise, National SkillShare Association, Management Information Systems, Legal and other Administration.

(7) A list is attached of four Sponsors of SkillShare projects approved for 1991 funding which contributed less than 15 per cent of the total project cost in the form of community contributions in 1990.
Yurri Gurri SkillShare 7 per cent QLD
I have asked the Department of Employment, Education and Training to discuss with the Sponsors of these four projects means to ensure that they can reach the required level of contribution in 1991.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Transport and Communications: Programs and Schemes

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 26 July 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: Name each of the programs and schemes in your portfolio which are accessed primarily by people aged 60 years and over or have been set up specifically for such people and what was the appropriation for each of these schemes in 1990-91.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Transport and Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Within the diverse range of programs delivered within the transport and communications portfolio it is often difficult to establish the exact extent to which a program benefits a discrete group, such as people aged 60 years and over.

The Federal Department of Transport and Communications reimburses the Australian National Railways Commission (AN) for the provision of free and concessional fares and freight on the non-urban rail services in South Australia in accordance with the terms of the transfer Agreement (1975) between the South Australian and Commonwealth Governments. In the 1990-91 financial year an amount of $4.5 million was appropriated for concessions.

AN receives reimbursement in the following categories; VIPs, War veterans, disabled veterans, freight (parcel) concessions, pensioners and sickness beneficiaries. People aged 60 years and over would primarily access pensioners concessions.

Under the provisions of the Waterfront In-Principle Agreement (IPA), an early retirement/redundancy package has been provided to rejuvenate the age structure of the stevedoring and international container depot industries. This package is targeted at stevedoring employees over 55 years of age and will enable restructuring of the industry. In applying the package priorities are as follows:
employees 60 years of age and over with 25 or more years of service
employees of 58 and 59 years of age with 30 or more years of service
employees from age 64 in descending order of age to 55 years with priority in any age group being based on years of service.
In the 1990-91 financial year the actual appropriation under the IPA arrangements was $17,238,000.

The sub-program contains appropriations which include the Government's financial assistance towards the cost of voluntary early retirement schemes for crew reductions under the Government's reform initiatives for the shipping and towage industries. The Government agreed to contribute $24,000 per retiree, up to a maximum of $24 million and $4.6 million for the shipping and shipping and towage industries respectively, in the three year period 1989-90 - 1991-92.

In the 1990-91 financial year 132 shipping industry personnel received packages under the scheme with Government contributions amounting to $3.216 million. The towage industry in this period accounted for 7 persons amounting to $168,000.

While not directed towards any particular age group, the voluntary early retirement schemes allow those with the longest service to leave the industry first. In general these have been people aged 60 years and over.

The Department of Transport and Communications is maintaining an ongoing road safety campaign aimed at pedestrians. The Older Pedestrians Campaign was funded in 1989-90, however, it continues as an active program aimed at the increasing the safety of pedestrians over the age of 60.
Through the campaign information on pedestrian road safety is made available through State Government Transport Organisations, Hospitals, Shire Councils and the Police.

People aged 60 years or over constitute 33% of the Radio National audience nationally in terms of audience reach and over 25% of the ABC FM audience. The Metropolitan radio stations are particularly popular with this age group, with a national reach of over half a million people aged 60 and over, with news and information programs attracting the largest audience.
On TV people aged 55 and over constitute the largest percentage of the ABC's audience based on average share of the 1991 year to date figures for the 6pm to midnight evening slot.

The long established day-time Great Classics series and the new Friday morning series Tea and Symphony performed by the Sydney Symphony Orchestra, attract a particularly large following amongst those aged 60 and over.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 31 July 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: In respect of the economic model being built and used by Treasury `to test the impact of various policy changes',
The Australian, 25 July 1991:
(1) What basic statistical data does the model use.
(2) What is the budgeted total cost to run the model in 1991-1992.
(3) What is the average number of staff working on the model.
(4) What is the budgeted salary cost of running the model in 1991-1992.
(5) Will consultants be used for any purpose in relation to the model; if so, what is the budgeted cost.
(6) What assumptions and coefficients are used in the model.
(7) When will the results of the model to test the impact of various changes to income tax, wholesale sales tax and consumption taxes, be made available to the public.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The model uses highly disaggregated data obtained from the latest published input-output tables, published and unpublished National Accounts statistics, published and unpublished foreign trade statistics, the Household Expenditure Survey, as well as detailed wholesale sales tax and other commodity tax data held within Treasury.

(2) No estimate has been made of the cost in 1991-92 of running the model. Treasury has, however, budgeted for the full costs of model development, which are expected to amount to $225,341. This figure includes salaries (see (4), below), the cost of data supplied by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, $15,061.70 to date, and the cost of three new computer software packages, approximately $60,000, which will have wider application within the Department.

(6) It is not possible to answer this question fully at this stage, since the model is in the process of development. It is intended that full details of the modelling methodology will be published once the model is up and running.

(7) At this stage the Treasury has been asked to develop a permanent modelling capacity to analyse changes in these and other policy instruments, as and when directed. It has not been asked to analyse any particular policy proposal. Accordingly, this question cannot be answered at this time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, upon notice, on 13 August 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister seen a news item in The Australian of 3 June 1991 which reported, inter alia, that a Canadian breast screen study found that the death rate among 40-49 year old women who were given regular mammograms was significantly higher than for women who had only a single physical examination.
(2) Does the department accept the authenticity of this study; if not, why not.
(3) Does the Minister intend to continue with a similar mammography program in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, I have read the article to which you refer.

(2) The Department is not in a position to comment on the authenticity of the study. However, an article in the medical journal The Lancet of 29 June 1991 draws attention to the controversy surrounding the reliability of the data and the methodology of the study concerned.

(3) The National Program for the Early Detection of Breast Cancer will actively recruit women aged 50-69 and will make screening available to women aged 40-49. This was on the recommendation of the Breast Cancer Screening Evaluation Steering Committee to Australian Health Ministers, which acknowledged the lack of international consensus on screening of women aged 40-49.
That Committee cited important practical and ethical considerations for including women aged 40-49 in the National Program. In summary they concluded that:
The Health Insurance Plan Study in New York strongly suggests that breast cancer screening for this age group can reduce breast cancer mortality.

The high demand for screening from women in this age group, revealed in the levels of de facto screening in the diagnostic system, would likely continue if they were excluded from the National Screening Program.

De facto screening conducted in that way, that is, uncoordinated, not integrated and with little quality control and no method of monitoring effect, would be less cost effective and have been less likely to reduce mortality.

The report of the Breast Cancer Screening Evaluation Steering Committee "Breast Cancer Screening in Australia: Future Directions" (SECU Report) recommended that this age group be screened within a context of continuous monitoring to allow evaluation.
I will forward to you a copy of the SECU report for your information.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 15 August 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the circumstances surrounding the engine failure of private aircraft VM-KTK, Serial No. 70983, at Bathurst on 10 February 1991.
(2) What was the specific instruction the owner's representative was given by the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) and was that advice ignored and the CAA's investigation thwarted.
(3) Did the engine manufacturer, Pratt and Witney, Canada, advise in a report that `metal particles were found in the oil' on 1 February 1991, nine days prior to the incident.
(4) Is the owner of the aircraft Dick Smith Adventure Pty. Ltd.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On 10 February 1991, a Cessna 550 aircraft VH-KTK made an emergency descent and landed safely at Bathurst following a reported engine fire. The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI) Sydney Field Office's `Summary of Occurrences' confirmed that there was no evidence of fire, but smoke and fumes did enter the aircraft cabin. The Major Defect Report of 25 February 1991 submitted by Pacific Aviation Pty Ltd, the maintenance organisation associated with maintenance of VH-KTK, advised of smoke in the cabin of the aircraft on 10 February 1991 and that the engine had been shut down in flight.
(2) I am advised by the CAA that, when failures like this occur, the owner's representative is required under Civil Aviation Order 100.8 to prepare a Major Defect Report and this was done.
I am also advised by the Authority that, the Order also provides for the CAA to see the engine in question prior to its being dispatched for repair. In this case that was not done.

However, the CAA has stressed that this is an advisory note and does not have legal effect, ie. the provision is not mandatory. In practice, the applicable legal requirement is contained in Civil Aviation Regulation 53, which provides that an investigation into an aircraft defect may be carried out and that such a requirement be made by notice in writing. The CAA has advised that it does not normally have to take this action and no such notice was given in relation to this particular defect.

Therefore, the CAA's advice was not deliberately ignored, nor was its investigation thwarted. It is, in fact, quite common for engines that experience similar problems to be returned to the manufacturer for repair. Appropriate liaison channels exist with manufacturers to enable a full report on the outcome to be received by the CAA. In this particular case a report was provided by Pratt &Whitney, Canada, to the CAA and the CAA now considers, for all practical purposes, the matter closed.

(3) I am informed by the CAA that there was a report of metal particles in the oil prior to the accident. However, this is not unusual. The particular maintenance organisation concerned (Pacific Aviation Pty Ltd) made a judgement that the contamination was below limits and, provided the oil was regularly monitored for any adverse trends, the engine could continue to operate.
(4) Yes, the owner of the aircraft is Dick Smith Adventure Pty Ltd.

(2) There is no requirement for the activities or outcomes of council meetings to be reported to Cabinet. Again, ministers may choose to raise these matters in the context of general submissions to Cabinet on the subject area where significant policy changes are proposed.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Social Security: Central Computing

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 22 August 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: Given that the 1991-92 Budget contains an initiative for contracting out to the private sector the Department of Veterans' Affairs central computing, estimated to save at least $6.5 million over the next five years, what would be the annual saving in the first full year of operation and the total savings for the next five years if the Department of Social Security were to do the same.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: On information available, there is no reason to believe that there would be any savings if Social Security were to contract out its `central' computing to the private sector.
The DSS response to the DVA tender would, if accepted, also have produced substantial ongoing savings on computing in DVA.
For reasons of cost effectiveness, efficiency and public policy I have no intention of pursuing the course suggested by the honourable senator.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 3 September 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What cooperation in biological warfare defence research and development exists between Australia and its allies under The Technical Cooperation Program (TTCP).

(2) On which technical panels and action groups (of the TTCP Subgroup which handles biological warfare matters) is Australia represented, and has Australia belonged to any technology liaison groups or ad hoc study groups in specialist areas covering biological warfare defensive studies.
(3) Has Australia disclosed and cited its cooperation under the TTCP as an example of activities either encouraged or permitted under Article X of the Biological Weapons Convention.
(4) What laboratories in Australia are engaged in biological warfare defensive studies and what is the nature of this work.
(5) What attempts, if any, has Australia made to share the results of biological warfare defensive studies with parties to the Biological Warfare Convention who are not allies of Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The 1987 Defence White Paper, "Defence of Australia", states:

"The ADF undertakes some basic training in NBC defensive and protective measures, but such training does not command a high priority. A scientific competence in NBCD matters is maintained to advise on policy and to give direction to ADF training."

Maintaining a scientific competence in biological warfare defence in Australia is limited to keeping a watching brief on developments. Australia does not conduct any research into such measures. Consequently, Australia does not cooperate with its allies on biological warfare defence research under The Technical Cooperation Program (TTCP).
(2) The TTCP Subgroup which covers biological warfare matters is Subgroup E - Chemical Defence. Australia is represented on:
Technical Panel 1--Treatment of Chemical Agent Poisoning
Action Group 35--Toxicological Testing of Agents that Affect CBW Filter Performance. (No laboratory activity has occurred under this Action Group in Australia)
In addition, as part of keeping a watching brief on biological defence research developments, an Australian is nominated as point of contact to receive the minutes of the meetings and papers from:

In the 1970's a TTCP Technology Liaison Group (TLG) existed which covered Biological Defence. Australia's involvement with this TLG was limited to the nomination of an officer to be a point of contact for the receipt of correspondence.

Some forms of protection are common to chemical and biological warfare defence. Australia has collaborated with other TTCP countries, through an Ad Hoc Study Group, on the design of chemical protective measures, which incidentally would provide some protection against biological materials. Australia has been concerned with chemical protection only.
(3) Since there is no cooperation under TTCP on biological defence research, there is nothing to disclose under Article X of the Biological Weapons Convention.
(4) There are no biological warfare defensive studies conducted in Defence laboratories within Australia nor does Defence fund such studies in external laboratories.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 September 1991, Senator Archer asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, a question and supplementary question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Can the Minister explain why firms which employ staff on commission are not permitted to claim expenditure for the time spent by such staff attending eligible training programs even though, when calculating the training liability of the business, commission payments made to the same staff are deemed to be part of that firm's payroll?

If the Minister is going to produce this information, will he please tell the Senate what the difference is between earnings paid by way of salary and earnings paid by way of commission to people such as vehicle and machinery agents, insurance and real estate salesman, all direct sellers and all retail staff where bonus commissions are payable?
The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

Similar questions have been addressed in correspondence and discussions with the Real Estate Institute of Australia, involving my office and officials of my Department and the Australian Taxation Office. Commission payments to staff are not `directly attributable' to training, as required under s.25(1) of the Training Guarantee (Administration) Act 1990. Unlike salary or wages paid to employees during their period of training, commission payments are only incurred during periods of work (eg sales activities) and are not a cost to the employer while the employee is in training.

On the other hand, commission must be counted in the employer's payroll, for purposes of determining the training obligation of the employer, as required under the definition of `salary or wages' in s.4 of the legislation. It is wholly reasonable to

include commission in payroll as this is an alternative to other forms of remuneration (such as wages). It would be inequitable to employers in other industries if employers in commission-based industries had a much reduced or no obligation to train because commissions were excluded from payroll.

Salaries and commissions are both forms of remuneration to employees and therefore form part of payroll for purposes of the Training Guarantee. The essential difference is that salaries are paid to employees during their training and work periods whereas commission is only payable when the employees are in a working situation.
